title: Information Panel: Battleground National Cemetery

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a red brick house.
images.title: Battleground National Cemetery
images.caption: Information Panel: Battleground National Cemetery

audioDescription:
(560 words)
Battleground National Cemetery is located in the Brightwood neighborhood of Washington, DC. The one-acre park is on the east side of Georgia avenue, NW between Whittier place to the north and Van Buren street to the south.
The Cemetery sits on a terrace approximately five feet above street level. A bluestone wall along the front edge is separated by two sets of three steps that lead up to a wrought-iron black gate at the Cemetery entrance. Set atop stone pillars on either side of the entrance are two six-foot long black cannons, one pointing north and one pointing south. On the face of the columns are black signs in the shape of a shield that both read in white: U.S. National Cemetery.
To the left about six feet from the front edge of the cemetery and set in a row across the lawn are four granite monuments, each between six and eleven-feet tall. To the right is a two-story red stone building with brown shutters and a gabled roof. A porch extends out on the west side of the building.
Directly back seventy feet from the entrance is a central flagpole, surrounded by forty-one marble headstones. Behind them and the east end of the Cemetery stands a white marble pavilion with four granite pillars.
Set to the right of the walkway about six feet from the top of the entrance steps is a two by three-foot wayside sign. Written across the top in black letters it is titled:
Battleground National Cemetery
The background of the entire sign is a black and white photograph of a small, one-story building with chimney, two windows on one side and one on another. A white picket fence runs behind the backside of the building. In front is a flagpole surrounded by white gravestones. Text in the lower right corner reads:
Battleground National Cemetery
Circa 1865-1870
Text in the bottom right corner reads:
You can download a podcast of Battleground National Cemetery at www.nps.gov/rocr
A smaller four by five-inch picture is set in the upper right corner. It shows a view from across the street at a two-story building set on a raised plot of land bordered by a stone brick wall in front. A staircase leads up through an opening in the wall. Monuments line the left front side of the property. A tall evergreen tree stands over the building, and other trees are set further back in the yard. Text written underneath reads:
Battleground National Cemetery
Circa 1930
Text written on the left side of the side describes the formation of Battleground National Cemetery:
During the late evening of July 12, 1864, 4o Union soldiers that perished while defending Washington, DC from a two-day Confederate attack) known as the Battle of Fort Stevens) were laid to rest here in what was once an apple orchard. President Abraham Lincoln, who attended the burial ceremony, dedicated the land as hallowed ground, making Battleground National Cemetery one of America's smallest national cemeteries.
Between the 1870s and early 1900s a Superintendent's Lodge, rostrum, flagpole, and regimental monuments were added to the cemetery to pay tribute to the brave men who sacrificed all to preserve this nation and its capital city. In addition to the fallen soldiers, the cemetery also holds the remains of the wife and three children of Augustus Armbrecht, the original superintendent of the cemetery.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Battleground National Cemetery: An Act to Establish and to Protect National Cemeteries

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a graveyard
images.title: Battleground National Cemetery
images.caption: Battleground National Cemetery: An Act to Establish and to Protect National Cemeteries

bodyText:
Inscriptions

An Act
To Establish and to Protect National Cemeteries
Approved February 22, 1867.
Section 3.
And be it further enacted. That any person who shall willfully destroy, mutilate, deface, injure, or remove any monument, gravestone, or other structure, or shall willfully destroy, cut, break, injure, or remove any tree, shrub, or plant within the limits of any of said National Cemeteries, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof before any District or Circuit Court of the United States within any State or District where any of said National Cemeteries are situated, shall be liable to a fine of not less than twenty-five nor more than one hundred dollars, or to imprisonment of not less than fifteen nor more than sixty days, according to the nature and aggravation of the offense. And the Superintendent in charge of any National Cemetery is hereby authorized to arrest forthwith any person engaged in committing any misdemeanor herein prohibited, and to bring such person before any United States Commissioner of Judge of any District or Circuit Court of the United States, within any State or District where any of said Cemeteries are situated, for the purpose of holding said person to answer for said misdemeanor, and then and there make complaint in due form.

title: Information Panel: Battleground National Cemetery: General Orders No.80
listingDescription: InscriptionsGeneral OrdersNo. 80War Department Adjutant General's OfficeWashington, September 1, 1875I.Information having been received of the desecration of soldiers' graves by picnic parties in a National Cemetery, and by vending refreshments therein, it is hereby ordered that hereafter no such practices shall be allowed in any National Cemetery, nor any adjoining ground within the control of the United States.II.Visitors Will Not Be AllowedIn the National CemeteriesBefore

images.altText: An informational plaque in front of a grassy area.
images.title: Battleground National Cemetery
images.caption: Battleground National Cemetery: General Orders No.80

bodyText:
Inscriptions
General Orders
No. 80
War Department Adjutant General's Office
Washington, September 1, 1875
I.
Information having been received of the desecration of soldiers' graves by picnic parties in a National Cemetery, and by vending refreshments therein, it is hereby ordered that hereafter no such practices shall be allowed in any National Cemetery, nor any adjoining ground within the control of the United States.
II.
Visitors Will Not Be Allowed
In the National Cemeteries
Before Sunrise of After Sunset.
No refreshments will be taken into these Cemeteries.
III.
In national cemeteries where driving is permitted, the speed must be confined to a walk,
If it is found difficult to enforce this rule at any Cemetery the gates will be closed over the carriageway and all driving prohibited.
IV.
These Orders will be conspicuously posted at the main entrance of each National Cemetery, and will be rigidly enforced by the Superintendents.
By Order of the Secretary of War:
E.D. Townsend,
Adjutant General.

bodyText:
Roll Call
As gallant soldiers that are interred at the cemetery marched onto the battlefield on July 11-12, 1864 during the Battle of Fort Stevens, their regimental flags accompanied them into the fight.
Battleground National Cemetery honors these men of valor by placing the names of the fallen under the flags they bravely fought and died for defending the nation's capital. The inner ring of graves are labeled 1-32, and the numbers 33-41 are in the outer ring.

A bluestone wall along the front edge is separated by two sets of three steps that lead up to a wrought-iron black gate at the Cemetery entrance. Set atop stone pillars on either side of the entrance are two six-foot long black cannons, one pointing north and one pointing south. On the face of the columns are black signs in the shape of a shield that both read in white: U.S. National Cemetery.
To the left about six feet from the front edge of the cemetery and set in a row across the lawn are four granite monuments, each between six and eleven-feet tall. To the right is a two-story red stone building with brown shutters and a gabled roof. A porch extends out on the west side of the building.
Directly back seventy feet from the entrance is a central flagpole, surrounded by forty-one marble headstones. Behind them and the east end of the Cemetery stands a white marble pavilion with four granite pillars.
Set to the right of the walkway and along the left side of the red brick building are two waysides. The second sits about fifty feet along the walkway. The three by three-foot sign has a white background and as is titled in the top left corner in black letters to read:
Roll Call
Text below details the soldiers who are interred at the cemetery:
As gallant soldiers that are interred at the cemetery marched onto the battlefield on July 11-12, 1864 during the Battle of Fort Stevens, their regimental flags accompanied them into the fight.
Battleground National Cemetery honors these men of valor by placing the names of the fallen under the flags they bravely fought and died for defending the nation's capital. The inner ring of graves are labeled 1-32, and the numbers 33-41 are in the outer ring.
Images courtesy from: Maine State Museum, Massachusetts State House Flag Collection, New York State Military Museum, Pennsylvania Capitol Preservation Committee
The remainder of the sign features three columns of the names of the fallen soldiers, grouped by their regiment names and flags. A full list of the names can be found in the main content text.
The listed regiments are:
25th New York Cavalry
61st Pennsylvania Infantry
122nd New York Infantry
139th Pennsylvania Infantry
2nd Massachusetts Cavalry
77th New York Infantry
43rd New York Infantry
49th New York Infantry
98th Pennsylvania Infantry
93rd Pennsylvania Infantry
7th Maine Infantry
37th Massachusetts Infantry
35 Star United States Flag
END OF DESCRIPTION

audioDescription:
(367 words)
Battleground National Cemetery is located in the Brightwood neighborhood of Washington, DC. The one-acre park is on the east side of Georgia avenue, NW between Whittier place to the north and Van Buren street to the south.
The Cemetery sits on a terrace approximately five feet above street level. A bluestone wall along the front edge is separated by two sets of three steps that lead up to a wrought-iron black gate at the Cemetery entrance. Set atop stone pillars on either side of the entrance are two six-foot long black cannons, one pointing north and one pointing south. On the face of the columns are black signs in the shape of a shield that both read in white: U.S. National Cemetery.
To the left about six feet from the front edge of the cemetery and set in a row across the lawn are four granite monuments, each between six and eleven-feet tall. To the right is a two-story red stone building with brown shutters and a gabled roof. A porch extends out on the west side of the building.
Directly back seventy feet to the east from the entrance is a central flagpole, surrounded by forty-one one-foot tall marble headstones. Also set in the ground around the flagpole are three one by three-foot black signs with white lettering on wood stakes which read:
Rest on Embalmed and Sainted Dead,
Dear as the Blood Ye Gave.
No Impious Footstep Here Shall Tread
The Herbage of your Grave.
On Fame's Eternal Camping-Ground,
Their Silent Tents are Spread,
And Glory Guards with Solemn Round
The Bivouac of the Dead.
The Muffled Drum's Sad Roll Has Beat
The Soldier's Last Tattoo.
No More on Life's Parade Shall Meet
That Brave and Fallen Few.
Further to the east behind the flagpole is a marble rostrum. Raised at a three-step elevation, the structure spans thirty feet across, twelve feet deep, and features eight white columns, four in the front, and four in the back that have a marble block wall running between them.
In the northeast corner sits a one-story, red brick building with a flat roof. It features a green door and two windows, along with a wooden sliding barn door.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Campus to Army Camps and Back Again
listingDescription: This information panel covers past uses of Meridian Hill Park, including college campuses and Army hospitals.

images.altText: Two informational panels next to a sidewalk.
images.title: Campus to Army Camps and Back Again
images.caption: Information Panel: Campus to Army Camps and Back Again

bodyText:
The Campus to Army Camps and Back Again outdoor exhibit sits in the northeast corner of Meridian Hill Park. The text describes the Union Army's use of what would become Meridian Hill Park during the Civil War.

During the Civil War, the Union Army commandeered the farmland on which Meridian Hill Park would eventually be built. The Army built camps there with names like Cameron, Relief, Carver, and Barclay. As the war continued, numerous hospitals, including Columbian and Mount Pleasant, were established in the same area. After the Civil War, Meridian Hill became a middle-class African American neighborhood. Wayland Seminary, which had opened in Foggy Bottom to train young African American men and women as preachers and teachers for the South, moved to a building at Chapin and 15th Streets in 1875. The school operated there until merging with Richmond Theological Seminary in 1899 to form Virginia Union University in Richmond. Booker T. Washington, noted African American political leader, educator, orator, and author, was one of Wayland's distinguished alumni.
audioDescription:
(770 words)
The Campus to Army Camps and Back Again wayside sits in the northeast corner of Meridian Hill Park. The urban park in the Columbia Heights neighborhood of Washington, DC is bordered by 15th, 16th, W, and Euclid streets NW, and sits on a prominent hill one and one-half miles (2.5 kilometers) due north of the White House.
From the intersection of 15th street and Euclid street, NW, travel south on 15th street about 93 feet (28 meters) and turn right into the park. About 30 feet (9 meters) into the park, and just beyond a paved path to the left, the wayside will be sitting along the walkway on your left.
Two three-by four-foot signs are placed at this location. The left sign provides a map and details about the entire park area. The sign on the right has a green background and is titled in large letters along the top left corner:
Campus to Army Camps and Back Again
Text below describes the Union Army's use of what would become Meridian Hill Park during the Civil War:
Campus to Army Camp and Back Again
President Monroe signed a charter in 1821 that established Columbian College on a site north of Florida Avenue between 14th and 15th Streets. Columbian College moved to Foggy Bottom in 1912 and became The George Washington University, but the original campus area continued to be called "College Hill."
During the Civil War, the Union Army commandeered the farmland on which Meridian Hill Park would eventually be built. The Army built camps there with names like Cameron, Relief, Carver, and Barclay. As the war continued, numerous hospitals, including Columbian and Mount Pleasant, were established in the same area.
After the Civil War, Meridian Hill became a middle-class African American neighborhood. Wayland Seminary, which had opened in Foggy Bottom to train young African American men and women as preachers and teachers for the South, moved to a building at Chapin and 15th Streets in 1875. The school operated there until merging with Richmond Theological Seminary in 1899 to form Virginia Union University in Richmond. Booker T. Washington, noted African American political leader, educator, orator, and author, was one of Wayland's distinguished alumni.
For more information go to:www.nps.gov/mehi
A color image fills the lower half of the right two-thirds of the sign. The picture is a drawing of a wide landscape of multiple acres. Six rows of ten one and two-story white buildings are in the lower left corner along a hillside. Further right is a five-story building among a line of trees, and at the far-right side more buildings are set in a square with a green campus area in the middle. Even more buildings line the bottom of the image. Written along a white border at the bottom of the picture is:
Carver Barracks, Washington, D.C.
Text above and left of the image reads:
Captain Grover of New York's 76th Regiment wrote home in 1861, "We were encamped in the edge of what must be in summer a beautiful grove, on the estate of Commodore Porter, a few rods only from his mansion, now occupied as a hospital. But beautiful as was the situation...snow and mud, cold fingers and toes, empty stomachs and soiled clothes, concealed every beauty, and compelled us to attend only to the work of arranging the camp."
Two black and white three by four-inch photographs are at the top right corner of the sign. The left image shows military troops lounging in front of a pitched tent. Two men stand in front of the tent while five others pose while seated beside them. All are wearing Civil War-era hats and rifles with bayonets are displayed among the men and in front the tent. Text below reads:
Union troops of the 7th New York State Militia at Camp Cameron on Meridian Hill, 1861
The image to the right shows two rows of beds with white linens in an open building. Windows on both sides of the room provide ample daylight. Garland and party decorations hang from the rafters, along with an American flag with a large star. Men in military uniform sit in between the beds on the right and a couple women are seated further back in the frame. A man in a wheelchair sits in the aisle that runs between the beds. Men seem to be tending to someone in a bed on the left. Text below reads:
Carver Barracks, below, surrounded the campus buildings of Columbian College. The barracks later became Carver Barracks Hospital, above.
Text in the bottom left of the sign reads:
For more information go to www.nps.gov/mehi
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Devils Chair Bridge
listingDescription: The Devil's Chair Bridge, formally the Lyons Mill Footbridge, was one of eight footbridges built in Rock Creek Park as a Public Works Administration (PWA) project during the Great Depression. The structure is a long, sweeping concrete arch measuring 88* long and 10' wide. The creekside abutment supporting its east end is a remnant of Lyons Mill, which once stood at this site.

images.altText: A bridge crosses over a small stream
images.caption: Devils Chair Bridge

bodyText: The Devil's Chair Bridge, formally the Lyons Mill Footbridge, was one of eight footbridges built in Rock Creek Park as a Public Works Administration (PWA) project during the Great Depression. The structure is a long, sweeping concrete arch measuring 88* long and 10' wide. The creekside abutment supporting its east end is a remnant of Lyons Mill, which once stood at this site.
audioDescription:
(181 words)
Devils Chair Bridge carries Rock Creek Trail over Rock Creek, east of the Georgetown neighborhood in Washington, DC.
Travel three hundred seventy-five yards (340 meters) north along Rock Creek Trail from Q street, NW. The trail turns to the right and becomes Devils Chair Bridge.
The bridge structure is a long, sweeping concrete arch measuring eighty-eight-feet (26 meters) long and ten-feet (3 meters) wide. Three-foot tall cement railings line both sides of the bridge. The bridge abutments underneath on both sides are made of blue stone.
The west side of the bridge is heavily wooded along Rock Creek and along a steep hillside that runs up to the west. On the east side of the bridge Rock Creek Trail turns to the left and continues north along the creek. A twenty-foot (6 meter) wide strip of grass runs between the trail and Rock Creek Parkway to the east.
A trail at the west side the bridge leads to steep steps that carry through thick woods up five hundred feet (152 meters) to Mount Zion Cemetery at the top of the hill.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Fort DeRussy

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a forest with orange and yellow leaves
images.title: Information Panel: Fort DeRussy
images.caption: Information Panel: Fort DeRussy

bodyText: This is an information panel at Fort DeRussy.
audioDescription:
(497 words) Fort DeRussy is located in Rock Creek Park in northwest Washington, DC, bordered by Military Road NW to the south, Oregon Avenue to the west, and Rock Creek to the east. From the northeast corner of the intersection of Oregon Avenue and Military Road, travel two hundred fifty feet north on the east side of Oregon Avenue, along a cement paved path into the edge of a forest. A four by three-foot wayside titled Fort De Russy sits at the right side of the path. Follow the path around the wayside to the right and proceed one-hundred twenty feet east at a slight incline into the forest to a fork in the road with a dirt path to the left. Follow the dirt path four hundred thirty feet where two waysides sit to the left of the path. The left wayside is three by two feet and titled in the top left corner: Fort DeRussy. The sign features an image of men in military dress standing in a circular bunker around a cannon lowered in the circle and on a wheeled turret. Six men stand atop a four-foot-tall wall that encircles the cannon. Eight other men stand within the lowered cannon space. Text below describes the cannon and Fort DeRussy: Built in 1861 to protect the Rock Creek Valley during the Civil War, Fort DeRussy's cannon fired a total of 109 projectiles into the northern countryside as 12,000-15,000 Confederate soldiers attacked the city under the command of Confederate General Jubal Anderson Early on July 11-12, 1864. During this two day battle (known as the Battle of Fort Stevens) Fort DeRussy aided the surrounding forts by providing the main suppressive fire to ensure a Union victory on the battlefield. The largest piece of armament which Fort DeRussy utilized was the 100-Pound Parrott Rifle. This cannon, shown above at nearby Fort Totten, could hurl 100 pound projectiles several miles into the Maryland countryside. During the Battle of Fort Stevens, Fort DeRussy halted the Confederate advance into the city by firing this deadly and accurate cannon a total of 28 times. The top right corner features a black and white photograph of a man standing at attention in a plain coat, pants and boots with a strap across his chest and holding a rifle and bayonet at his right side. Text beneath him reads: Private Samuel Strawser, a member of the 151st Ohio Volunteer Infantry, was stationed at Fort DeRussy during the Battle of Fort Stevens. A black and white oval photograph in the bottom right shows a bearded man in a hat, suit and vest. Text to his right reads: "On the right was Rock Creek running through a deep ravine which had been rendered impassable...every appliance of science and unlimited means had been used to render the fortifications around Washington as strong as possible"
General Jubal Anderson Early Commander of Confederate forces during the Battle of Fort Stevens You can download a podcast of Fort DeRussy at www.nps.gov/rocr END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Fort DeRussy-2

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a forested trail.
images.title: Information Panel: Fort DeRussy-2
images.caption: Information Panel: Fort DeRussy-2

bodyText: This is an information panel at Fort DeRussy. This page exists for the audio description.
audioDescription: (310 words) Fort DeRussy is located in Rock Creek Park in northwest Washington, DC, bordered by Military Road NW to the south, Oregon Avenue to the west, and Rock Creek to the east. From the northeast corner of the intersection of Oregon Avenue and Military Road, travel two hundred fifty feet north on the east side of Oregon avenue, along a cement paved path into the edge of a forest. Set on the right side of the path is a four by three-foot wayside. The yellow sign is written across the top in brown letters to read: Fort De Russy Earthworks of Fort De Russy are visible; follow path to your right for 200 yards. Text written across a blue border below reads in white letters: Civil War Defenses of Washington 1861-1865 Below on the left is a diagram titled at the top: Fort DeRussy. Below is a sketch of a trapezoid shaped area surrounded by similar shaped walls on the outside. Other sketches around show various bunkers of the fort. The right side features a map of the northern corner of Washington and the Civil War Forts in the area. Identified on the map from left-to-right are Battery Kemble, Fort Bayard, Fort Reno, Fort De Russy, Fort Stevens, Fort Slocum, Fort Totten, and Fort Bunker Hill. Rock Creek Park runs north-south through the middle of the map and is highlighted in green. Text below reads: Other Civil War fort locations administered by Rock Creek Park. The bottom third of the sign shows a black and white photograph of Civil War soldiers standing in a fort around an eight-foot long cannon on a rotating platform, aimed to the left. The fort sits atop a tall hill with a vast view in the background of open spaces and rolling hills. The caption below reads: During the Civil War, Washington's forts overlooked farm land. END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Fort Slocum

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a grassy field on the left and a sidewalk on the right.
images.title: Information Panel: Fort Slocum
images.caption: Information Panel: Fort Slocum

bodyText: Information Panel: Fort Slocum
audioDescription:
(429 words)
Located in the Brightwood neighborhood in the northeast quadrant of Washington, DC, Fort Slocum Park is bordered by Kansas avenue, NW to the east, 3rd street, NW to the west, Oglethorpe street, NW to the north, and Madison street, NW to the south.
At the intersection of 3rd and Madison streets, a two by five foot-brown sign sits in the corner of a large grassy field. Across the top in white letters the sign reads: Fort Slocum. Beneath is written:
Fort Circle Parks
National Park Service
U.S. Department of the Interior
A row of twenty-foot-tall trees line the area behind the sign. Further along Madison street and Kansas avenue a large hill sits along the east side of the park. A pavilion with a picnic table is set about fifty feet west of Kansas avenue at the middle of the block. To the north and west is a heavily wooded forest area that spans the northeast corner of the park.
From the intersection of Madison street and Kansas avenue, travel north on Kansas avenue along the sidewalk about four hundred feet. On your left set just off the sidewalk is a four by three-foot wayside. Written across the yellow sign in brown lettering it reads:
Fort Slocum
No visible evidence remains of Fort Slocum, which stood here and across Kansas Avenue to your left.
Text below across a blue border reads:
Civil War Defenses of Washington
1861-1865
Below on the left side is a diagram view of a fort from above, showing its outer walls and borders. Text below reads:
Fort Slocum from U.S. Army Corps of Engineers drawing.
Cannon mounted at Fort Slocum helped repulse a Confederate attack on Fort Stevens July 11-12, 1864.
To the right is a map of the top corner of Washington, DC, showing the locations of Civil War forts. From west to east they are: Battery Kemble, Fort Bayard, Fort Reno, Fort De Russy, Fort Stevens, Fort Slocum, Fort Totten, and Fort Bunker Hill. A red dot indicates the Fort Slocum location.
Text below reads:
Other Civil War for locations administered by Rock Creek Park.
The bottom third of the sign features a black and white photograph of a fort setting. About one dozen men in Civil War military uniform stand in and around a gun turret atop a hillside. One man stands on a cannon base with wheels that is at the center of the picture. Rolling hills and tree lines can be seen in the distance. Text underneath reads:
During the Civil War, Washington's forts overlooked farm land.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Fort Stevens
listingDescription: Fort Stevens, now partially restored, was built to defend the approaches to Washington from the 7th Street Pike (now Georgia Avenue) which was then the main thoroughfare from the north into Washington. Confederate General Jubal Early's troops attacked here on July 10-11, 1864. Abraham Lincoln famously stood on the parapet and exposed himself to enemy fire.

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a large grassy field.
images.title: Information Panel: Fort Stevens
images.caption: Information Panel: Fort Stevens

bodyText: Fort Stevens, now partially restored, was built to defend the approaches to Washington from the 7th Street Pike (now Georgia Avenue) which was then the main thoroughfare from the north into Washington. Confederate General Jubal Early's troops attacked here on July 10-11, 1864. Abraham Lincoln famously stood on the parapet and exposed himself to enemy fire.
audioDescription:
(525 words)
Fort Stevens is located in the northern corner of Washington, DC, within the center of a block bordered by 13th Street, NW to the west, Georgia Avenue to the east, Rittenhouse Street to the north and Quakenbos Street to the south.
The park area rises about thirty feet from street level at the northwest corner of 13th and Rittenhouse Streets about two-hundred yards to the eastern end where the fort is situated. A flagpole in the center of the hilly field marks the fort location.
Lined in front to the east of the flagpole are a wall of grassy bunkers, about four-feet tall. One eight-foot tall hill to the left has a white wooden double-sided door on its face.
A cement bunker wall with wood-log designed vertical ridges spans about one hundred yards (90 meters) across the top of the hill. The wall stands about five feet tall with six three-foot wide, three-foot tall openings. Pointed out of two of those openings are sixteen-foot long cannons set on cement platforms and directed out to the north.
Set at the low-end corner of the block at 13th and Rittenhouse Streets is a four by three-foot wayside. The yellow sign is written in brown letters across the top:
Fort Stevens
The partial reconstruction of Fort Stevens that you see today was done by the Civilian Conservation Corps in 1937. No visible evidence of the original fort remains.
Across a blue border just below, text reads in white letters:
Civil War Defenses of Washington
1861-1865
Text in the middle left describes the Battle of Fort Stevens:
Battle of Fort Stevens
July 11-12, 1864
On July 11-12, 1864, Fort Stevens was the focal point of a Confederate attack by Gen. Jubal Early with his force of 15,000 soldiers. Defended by a meager force of convalescents, quartermaster employees and 100 day militia volunteers, Fort Stevens held back an attack by Confederate skirmishers on July 11. Reinforcements from the Union 6th and 19th Corps on the second day checked and turned back the only Confederate threat against Washington, DC, during the war. Late in the afternoon of July 12, President Abraham Lincoln was exposed to Confederate fire while observing this battle where approximately 900 soldiers were killed, wounded, or missing.
Nearby Battleground Cemetery, which was dedicated by President Lincoln soon after the battle, contains the graves of 40 Union soldiers who died in defense of Fort Stevens.
To the right is a map of the top corner of Washington, DC, showing the locations of Civil War forts. From west to east they are: Battery Kemble, Fort Bayard, Fort Reno, For De Russy, Fort Stevens, Fort Slocum, Fort Totten, and Fort Bunker Hill.
Text below reads:
Other Civil War for locations administered by Rock Creek Park.
The bottom third of the sign shows a black and white photograph of Civil War soldiers standing in a fort around an eight-foot long cannon on a rotating platform, aimed to the left. The fort sits atop a tall hill with a vast view in the background of open spaces and rolling hills.
The caption below reads:
During the Civil War, Washington's forts overlooked farm land.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Fort Totten
listingDescription: Information Panel about Fort Totten's History

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a grassy field.
images.title: Information Panel: Fort Totten
images.caption: Information Panel: Fort Totten

bodyText:
Built in 1861 and named after Brigadier General Joseph Gilbert Totten, Chief of the Army Corps of Engineers, Fort Totten commanded the northeastern countryside of Washington, DC during the Civil War. Heavily armed with massive cannon that could hurl 100-pound projectiles several miles, Fort Totten halted the eastward advance of Confederate invaders inside Washington, DC during the Battle of Fort Stevens in July,1864.

the late 1920s the historic earthworks inside Fort Totten showed significant signs of erosion which threatened the preservation of the fort. To stabilize the fort vegetation was planted. Removal of vegetation from the fort and its grounds is prohibited.

Additional information on Fort Totten available at www.nps.gov/rocr
audioDescription:
(448 words)
Fort Totten Park is located in Northeast Washington, DC, about three hundred yards east of Rock Creek Cemetery. The park is bordered by Fort Totten Drive NE to the west, Brookland avenue NE to the north and east, and Bates road NW to the south.
From the intersection of Fort Totten Drive and Crittenden street, travel north on Fort Totten Drive one hundred fifty feet. An entrance into Fort Totten Park will be on the right.
Proceed east uphill on the park entrance road about two hundred fifty feet. A two by three-foot wayside is set about five feet off the road to the right. The sign is set on a grassy lawn that covers most of the park area. About fifty feet further east is a wooded forest area.
The left two-thirds of the sign shows a brown and white photograph of Civil War-era military soldiers in center-button jackets and hats. Five men stand posed and facing the camera. A dog lies at their feet. Dozens of other men with rifles stand around the area, some along three cannons that are pointed facing out over the top of the fort's walls.
In the bottom left corner of the sign is a six by twelve-inch black and white photo of six military men standing in front of a cannon under a white gateway. Atop the gateway is written: TOTTEN. Text in the top right corner reads:
Entrance gate to Fort Totten, 1865
The right third of the sign has a gray background. In the upper left is a black and white photograph of an older man with gray hair and double-breasted military uniform. Below the photo he is identified as:
Brigadier General Joseph Gilbert Totten
Text to his right reads:
Built in 1861 and named after Brigadier General Joseph Gilbert Totten, Chief of the Army Corps of Engineers, Fort Totten commanded the northeastern countryside of Washington, DC during the Civil War. Heavily armed with massive cannon that could hurl 100-pound projectiles several miles, Fort Totten halted the eastward advance of Confederate invaders inside Washington, DC during the Battle of Fort Stevens in July,1864.
Below on the left is a color photo of a forest of trees in fall or winter with no leaves. The ground beneath them is brown and covered in leaves.
Text to the right reads:
By the late 1920s the historic earthworks inside Fort Totten showed significant signs of erosion which threatened the preservation of the fort. To stabilize the fort vegetation was planted. Removal of vegetation from the fort and its grounds is prohibited.
Text at the very bottom of the sign reads:
Additional information on Fort Totten available at www.nps.gov/rocr
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: From Seaport to National Park
listingDescription: This information panel describes the transformation of the waterfront from commercial area to green space.

images.altText: A informational panel in front of the Potomac river.
images.title: From Seaport to National Park
images.caption: Information Panel: From Seaport to National Park

bodyText:
During America's early days, the Georgetown waterfront thrived as a port lined with wharves and seagoing vessels. It later became an industrial site. Now it is a national park. How does an old port and industrial site become a national park?

In the 1960s, the Georgetown waterfront was condemned for an interstate highway, which was never built. Planning began then to convert the waterfront into a park.

Progress slowed until, in 1985, the District of Columbia transferred the waterfront land to the National Park Service (NPS). Ten more years passed. Then, in the late 1990s, a surge in interest brought a partnership that would highlight the Potomac's signature sport: rowing. The Georgetown Waterfront Park Commission, a volunteer organization, galvanized local residents, the rowing community, regional leaders, and the NPS in an effort which would bring the park to fruition.

A green column lines the right third of the sign, and on top is a photograph of ten people standing in a field flanked by uniformed park rangers on either end. A post holds up a line in front of them and the man in the center is cutting the ribbon. Text above reads: Dignitaries cut the ribbon to dedicate the park in 2008.

Just below in an oval picture is a smiling man in suit and tie with white hair. Text beside him reads: Senator Charles H. Percy. Text beneath him reads: Senator Charles H. Percy was pivotal in the creation of the Georgetown Waterfront Park. Senator Percy - a Georgetown resident, lover of the waterfront, and supporter of local high school rowing - chaired the Georgetown Waterfront Park Commission that was instrumental in the park's creation.

The Commission and its successor organization, the Friends of Georgetown Waterfront Park, helped redesign plans and raise funds to build the park. With the generous support of the Friends of the District of Columbia, coupled with an NPS Centennial Initiative grant and the tireless dedication of citizens and public officials, the Georgetown Waterfront Park is now a national park for all to enjoy.

In the bottom right corner of the sign is a black and white photograph set at an angle. It shows an industrial riverfront, with a raised highway running a block off the river's edge, a large industrial building set to the left, a set of buildings with smokestacks towards the center, and smoke billowing from a set of buildings on the left along the river.
audioDescription:
(690 words)
Located along the north edge of the Potomac River at the east end of Georgetown Waterfront Park in Washington, DC is the From Seaport to National Park wayside.
From the Wisconsin avenue and Water street, NW intersection, travel south about one hundred eighty feet (54 meters), pass the water fountain in Wisconsin Avenue Park on your right, and proceed through a walkway that runs parallel to the Potomac River. The wayside will be sitting on the south side of the walkway and you will be facing the river.
The three by four-foot sign is set just off the walkway on a thin three-foot strip of grass. A four-foot-wide cobblestone walk runs in front of the grass, and just before a one hundred-foot (30 meter) wide set of granite stairs that lead down to the edge of the river. Along north side of the walkway are two black metal pergolas that span about one hundred fifty feet (45 meters) and granite benches are set on a four-foot wide cobblestone strip underneath.
The left two thirds of the sign feature an overhead color image of a sprawling park area set along a calm river. People are walking, bike riding, and playing in the park and rowers and kayakers float in the river. A promenade lines the river edge and a circular labyrinth sits in a grassy lawn area in the foreground. Lush trees inhabit the land across the river, and the Kennedy Center and tip of the Washington Monument are visible on the horizon.
Written across the top of the sign in black letters is: From Seaport to National Park. Text below describes the transformation of the Georgetown Waterfront:
During America's early days, the Georgetown waterfront thrived as a port lined with wharves and seagoing vessels. It later became an industrial site. Now it is a national park. How does an old port and industrial site become a national park?
In the 1960s, the Georgetown waterfront was condemned for an interstate highway, which was never built. Planning began then to convert the waterfront into a park.
Progress slowed until, in 1985, the District of Columbia transferred the waterfront land to the National Park Service (NPS). Ten more years passed. Then, in the late 1990s, a surge in interest brought a partnership that would highlight the Potomac's signature sport: rowing. The Georgetown Waterfront Park Commission, a volunteer organization, galvanized local residents, the rowing community, regional leaders, and the NPS in an effort which would bring the park to fruition.
A green column lines the right third of the sign, and on top is a photograph of ten people standing in a field flanked by uniformed park rangers on either end. A post holds up a line in front of them and the man in the center is cutting the ribbon. Text above reads:
Dignitaries cut the ribbon to dedicate the park in 2008.
Just below in an oval picture is a smiling man in suit and tie with white hair. Text beside him reads: Senator Charles H. Percy. Text beneath him reads:
Senator Charles H. Percy was pivotal in the creation of the Georgetown Waterfront Park. Senator Percy - a Georgetown resident, lover of the waterfront, and supporter of local high school rowing - chaired the Georgetown Waterfront Park Commission that was instrumental in the park's creation.
The Commission and its successor organization, the Friends of Georgetown Waterfront Park, helped redesign plans and raise funds to build the park. With the generous support of the Friends of the District of Columbia, coupled with an NPS Centennial Initiative grant and the tireless dedication of citizens and public officials, the Georgetown Waterfront Park is now a national park for all to enjoy.
In the bottom right corner of the sign is a black and white photograph set at an angle. It shows an industrial riverfront, with a raised highway running a block off the river's edge, a large industrial building set to the left, a set of buildings with smokestacks towards the center, and smoke billowing from a set of buildings on the left along the river. Text below reads:
Georgetown waterfront, circa 1960
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Hi, I'm Rocky the Black Rat Snake

images.altText: An informational panel surrounded by green foliage.
images.title: Hi I'm Rocky the Black Rat Snake
images.caption: Information Panel: Hi I'm Rocky the Black Rat Snake

bodyText: Informational Panel: Hi I'm Rocky the Black Rat Snake
audioDescription:
(322 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
Beyond the front doors of the Rock Creek Nature Center is a thirty by forty-foot space featuring a gift shop, an exhibit space in the back, restrooms to the left, and a staircase to the right of the front desk which leads downstairs to a younger kids learning area.
From the front entrance of the Nature Center, proceed around the right side of the building and walk back thirty feet. Turn left at the corner of the building and down four steps to a twenty by forty cement brick plaza area. A garden lines the space on its south, east, and north sides and wood picnic benches are along the building on the left and at the north end of the space. Stairs on the east side lead down to a walkway to the Edge of Woods Trail.
At the back, west, side of the plaza a one by two-foot metal sign is set in the garden. The light blue sign features an image of a black snake along the bottom, and is titled across the top in red letters:
"Hi, I'm Rocky the Black Rat Snake"
Text below reads:
I live in the garden with my family and sometimes climb the trees! I'm not poisonous, but I'm also not really interested in you. If you see me, don't do anything. I'll probably just slither away to chase mice!
Below, the black snake slithers through grass in the drawing. Below reads:
Goldenrod: My flowers are yellow in the fall. I don't cause allergies (that's my cousin, Ragweed!)
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Home for the Summer / Veranear en casa

images.altText: An informational panel in front of trees and plants.
images.title: Home for the Summer / Veranear en casa
images.caption: Information Panel: Home for the Summer / Veranear en casa

bodyText:
Rock Creek's forest makes an ideal summer home--with food, shelter, and ideal nesting sites-for the wood thrush, a songbird. But climate change and other factors could end this long relationship. Rising temperatures disrupt the seasonal patterns of plants and animals. What will happen in these woods? We need your help to find out. Take photos on the nearby picture post and help us record changes.

This panel has text and captions in both English and Spanish.
audioDescription:
(646 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
The Home for the Summer wayside is located on the back, east side of the Nature Center. A wood pedestrian ramp on the right side of the Nature Center switches back and leads down to the backside of the Nature Center.
A small patio space about eighty feet long and forty feet wide is located in the back amid the forest of Rock Creek Park. A picnic table is set beside the building. Steps on the opposite, north, end of the building also lead down to this area. A wood balcony on the building's first floor sits on the north side of the plaza.
Facing east, a three by four-foot wayside is set at the plaza's edge, facing the forest. To its right is a wood photo stand.
The left half of the sign features a color photo image background of a lush forest with the sun shining through tall trees and the forest floor covered with leaves. The title in the upper left corner reads:
Home for the Summer
Text below, and further below in Spanish, reads:
Home for the Summer
Rock Creek's forest makes an ideal summer home--with food, shelter, and ideal nesting sites-for the wood thrush, a songbird. But climate change and other factors could end this long relationship. Rising temperatures disrupt the seasonal patterns of plants and animals. What will happen in these woods? We need your help to find out. Take photos on the nearby picture post and help us record changes.
A picture of a brown bird with brown-spotted white breast sits in the lower left corner, its mouth open as it chirps. A one-inch round, black button sticks out from the sign to the right of the bird image. Text above, and beneath in Spanish reads:
Hard to spot, the reclusive wood thrush is easy to hear. Lift the handset and press this button to hear its ringing, clear call.
The right side of the sign features three one by two-inch color pictures. The top image is looking up from below as the sun shines through a lush forest. Text below reads:
Shaded by the woodland canopy, the forest floor stays moist for insects and fruit eaten by wood thrushes.
The middle picture shows a brown bird with a brown-spotted white breast standing on the edge of a nest, over three small baby birds. Text below, and further below in Spanish, reads:
See the smaller saplings? Wood thrushes nest and raise their young in them.
The bottom image is of a brown bird with a brown-spotted white breast standing on the forest floor. Text below and further below in Spanish, reads:
Wood thrushes eat insects and other invertebrates in leaf litter. As the climate changes, temperature and moisture changes could mean less food for them.
The right third of the sign features a map of the eastern half of the United States, Canada, and Central America. Canada and the U.S are shown in brown, and Rock Creek Park is identified in black along the East Coast. The area is labeled Summer May-September. A strip of the Midwest and southern U.S. is colored yellow and labeled Migration, October and April. Further below in blue, Central America is labeled Winter November-March.
Text above, and beneath in Spanish, reads:
A Traveling Life
Wintering in Central America, wood thrushes migrate to this area in May. Cued by changes in light, the migration timing will likely stay the same. But a warming climate could change the forest, reducing this songbird's food supply.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: How High is the River?
listingDescription: This informational panel in Georgetown Waterfront Park explains the stream gauge and educates visitors about the river.

images.altText: A colorful information panel
images.title: How High is the River
images.caption: Informational Panel titled "How High is the River"

bodyText:
This wayside panel sits close to the edge of Georgetown Waterfront Park and overlooks the Potomac River.

The top third of the sign features a background of tall green trees, and below is a calm blue river. Two large boulders sit along the river's edge at the tree line, and a kayaker paddles in the river below. Text beneath the kayaker reads:Learn more about the USGS at www.usgs.govGeorgetown Waterfront Park is managed by Rock Creek Park (National Park Service). For more information, visit www.nps.gov/rocr and www.georgetownwaterfrontpark.org.

The sign is titled across the top left corner in white lettering: How High is the River?Text below reads:How High is the River? The structures to your right contains a streamgage that records water levels in the Potomac River. The hydrograph below shows the Potomac River reached flood levels in Jun 2018. Water levels at this site are measured by sensing the air pressure required to force air bubbles into the river. The water in the river at this location is affected by the same tides that affect the ocean and the Chesapeake Bay, but the water here is fresh, not salty or even brackish.The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) monitors water quantity and quality. USGS data is used for studying, managing, and/or forecasting:
  • Water resources and water supply
  • Floods and droughts
  • Climate change
  • Bridge and infrastructure design
  • Reservior operations
  • Water quality
  • Stormwater and stream restoration
  • In-stream flows for habitats
  • Recreational safety
A column of text on the lower left side titled Streamgages describes the gray box that sits to the right of the wayside:StreamgagesThis is USGS Streamgage 01647600, Potomac River at Wisconsin Avenue, Washington, D.C. Check out waterdata.usgs.gov to find out how high the river is or learn other facts about water.The USGS operates this streamgage in cooperation with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the National Park Service. The USGS has measured water levels on the Potomac River in Georgetown since 1935. The USGS operates more than 100 streamgages along the Potomac River and its tributaries and over 8,200 stremgages across the Nation.Above the kayaker in the center of the sign, is text that reads:The streamgages on the Potomac River are crucial to Chesapeake Bay restoration efforts. The only way to determine the amount of pollution flowing to the Bay is to know the concentration of the pollution and the amount of water flowing to the Bay.To the right of the kayaker is a two by four-inch white box with green border along the top that reads: Measuring the Water Level. A graph on the right side is titled: 01647600 Potomac River at Wisconsin Avenue, Washington, DC. The graph shows how water levels during an eight-day period spiked over flood stage levels to eight feet for two days during the timespan.Text to the left reads:Measuring the Water Level. The streamgage measures the height of the river as it rises and falls with the tides. In the hydrograph (right), the height of water is shown over eight days in June 2018. Between June 4 and 6, 2018, the river rose more than 3 feet due to high river flows caused by heavy rains across the Potomac River watershed. During those days, the river was above the flood level.The far right column of the sign features a white box with blue top border that reads: Monitoring the Potomac River Watershed. Below, a map is displayed of Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Maryland, Virginia, and Washington, DC. The Chesapeake Bay is shown on the far right. Text beneath details the nature of watersheds:Monitoring the Potomac WatershedA "watershed" is an area of land from which water drains into a particular body of water. The Potomac River receives its water from an area that covers nearly 15,000 square miles in four states and the District of Columbia. The Potomac River empties into the Chesapeake Bay 112 miles downstream from this site.If you live or work in the area, you may be one of the nearly 5 million people who receive drinking water from the Potomac River watershed. Monitoring water quantity and quality in the entire watershed is vital, because what happens upstream
