title: Information Panel: Jean Jules Jusserand Memorial

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a grassy field.
images.title: Information Panel: Jean Jules Jusserand
images.caption: Information Panel: Jean Jules Jusserand Memorial

bodyText: Information Panel: Jean Jules Jusserand Memorial
audioDescription:
(586 words)
The Jean Jules Jusserand Memorial sits along the north side of Beach Dr NW, about seven hundred feet (640 meters) south of the intersection of Beach Dr NW and Tilden St. NW in Rock Creek Park.
Access is difficult, as there is no walkway across Beach Drive to access the memorial from the south. The memorial is set at the edge of thick woods and access from the north is also difficult.
The wayside sign is badly faded and in poor condition. Along its top in large black letters it is titled: Jusserand. At the top left is a photograph of Jusserand, facing to the left and wearing a beard, labeled: Ambassador J. Jusserand 1856-1932. Text beneath him is written in French.
At the center of the sign is a faded round emblem with five ornamental details. Below it is labeled:
Legion of Honor
"A diplomat, a scholar and a friend of America
Jusserand Memorial Committee, 1937
Text above and below the emblem reads:
The granite bench before you commemorates the scholarship, wisdom and skilled diplomacy of Jean Jules Jusserand, French Ambassador to the United States from 1902 to 1925. The memorial's inscription, "Personal Tribute of Esteem and Affection" reflects the admiration felt for him locally, nationally and internationally. Jusserand loved Rock Creek Park and frequently walked here with family and friends. We can only wonder how the world was affected by the thoughts he pondered while enjoying the beauty of this place.
Diplomacy - Jusserand served as French Ambassador to the United States under five presidential administrations and throughout the First World War.
Scholarship - Jusserand's writings earned him recognition at home and abroad. He won the first Pulitzer Prize in History for With Americans of Past and Present Days, a book recounting the key contributions of many Frenchmen to the history of the United States, including Pierre Charles L'Enfant, designer of the city of Washington.
Friendship - A leader in Franco-American relations, Jusserand received the Grand Croix,"of the French Legion of Honor, the highest French distinction. His efforts to promote friendship between the two countries led him to create the American Society of the Legion of Honor that recognizes Americans who make significant contributions to France.
At the opposite right end from the Jusserand photo is a picture of President Theodore Roosevelt, wearing round glasses and speaking as he faces to the left. Text beneath him reads:
Soon after his arrival in Washington, Jusserand earned the confidence of President Theodore Roosevelt and became a member of his unofficial "tennis cabinet". Roosevelt and Jusserand shared a love for the outdoors and spent many long hours hiking in Rock Creek Park. In his memoir "What Me Befell," Jusserand describes their outings.
"President Roosevelt gave me that unique proof of trust and friendship; he asked me to a â€˜walk'...What the President called a walk, was a run, no stop, no breathing time, no slacking of speed, but a continuous race, careless of mud, thorns, and the rest. The Rock Creek Walk usually ended at the cliff overhanging the river, near the Zoo."
"Almost we can say -- he was a great American as well as a great Frenchman. We shall link Mr. Jusserand's name forever with the names of Lafayette and Rochambeau and De Grasse and the other valiant Frenchmen whose services in this country entitle them for all time to the grateful remembrance of all Americans."
Franklin Delano Roosevelt at the Jusserand Memorial dedication, 1936
Crossed flags of France and America sit at the bottom center of the sign.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Machine in a Stone Box

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a stone house.
images.title: Information Panel: Machine in a Stone Bo
images.caption: Information Panel: Machine in a Stone Box

bodyText:
The wayside is titled in the upper right-hand corner: Machine in a Stone Box. It features a large color photo of a three-story brick building with two windows on each level. A diagram showing the working mechanics of a water wheel is drawn in white over the center of the building from top to bottom, with water wheel included to show it sitting in the water passing by below.

Peirce Mill represents the beginnings of the Industrial Revolution in America. For centuries, small water-powered mills had ground grain into flour, using human labor in every step of the process. This 1829 mill, on the other hand, was a mechanized marvel, incorporating the latest laborsaving technologies pioneered by American inventor Oliver Evans. Water turned the wheel, which spun a shaft that drove gears, belts, a grain elevator, and a variety of machines. Assisted by gravity and a single miller, the mill's machinery automatically turned grain into flour.
audioDescription:
(436 words)
About thirty feet (9 meters) northeast from Peirce Mill at the northwest corner of Tilden Street and Beach Drive NW in Rock Creek Park is the Machine in a Stone Box wayside.
The three by four-foot sign stands in front of a ten-foot wide cement area with five bicycle racks set on a grassy hillside. Facing west, Peirce Mill is about thirty feet in the foreground. A wooden-railed fence runs alongside the mill and guards a water channel that exits the building on the right, makes a right-hand turn, and runs alongside the mill and water wheel just beyond the fence.
Still facing west, a bike/walking path runs north-south about twenty feet behind, and Rock Creek is about fifty feet behind you.
The wayside is titled in the upper right-hand corner: Machine in a Stone Box. It features a large color photo of a three-story brick building with two windows on each level. A diagram showing the working mechanics of a water wheel is drawn in white over the center of the building from top to bottom, with water wheel included to show it sitting in the water passing by below.
Text in the top right corner reads:
Peirce Mill represents the beginnings of the Industrial Revolution in America. For centuries, small water-powered mills had ground grain into flour, using human labor in every step of the process. This 1829 mill, on the other hand, was a mechanized marvel, incorporating the latest laborsaving technologies pioneered by American inventor Oliver Evans. Water turned the wheel, which spun a shaft that drove gears, belts, a grain elevator, and a variety of machines. Assisted by gravity and a single miller, the mill's machinery automatically turned grain into flour.
A three by six-inch picture of a working water wheel is set on the right. Text to the right of the photo reads:
As the water drops over the wheel, its momentum and weight provide power equivalent to about 30 pulling drafthorses.
The left corner of the sign shows a map depicting Rock Creek flowing from bottom to top past Tilden street. A side channel to the right, labeled Headrace, diverts water to Peirce Mill, and is labeled Tailrace as it passes the building and returns to Rock Creek. A road marked Historical runs parallel to the creek on the right and further right an orchard is indicated. An arrow points to the Tailrace location and reads: You Are Here.
Text below the map reads:
A dam diverted water from Rock Creek into a headrace, which channeled the water to the mill's waterwheel. Water returned to Rock Creek via a tailrace.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Orchards, Fields, Gardens, Pastures

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a grassy field.
images.title: Orchards, Fields, Gardens, Pastures
images.caption: Information Panel: Orchards, Fields, Gardens, Pastures

bodyText:
The wayside shows a drawing of seven enslaved working men and women working in a wheat field that spans the top of the sign. They stack hay into a pile in front of a one-story brick building with two windows. An ox-drawn carriage sits in a grass field by a dirt road in front of them, and an orchard with red fruit lines the right side of the image.

A five by five-inch black and white map in the lower left corner indicates that you are near Peirce's Mill and Pierce Shoemaker is to the south. Text below the map reads: This detail from an 1861 map shows the mill, several other buildings, and the rows of trees on the hillside that made up the Peirce family orchard. To the right of the map, the sign is titled in large white letters:Orchards, Fields, Gardens, Pastures. Below, the text reads: Even in the mill's heyday, the Peirce family ran a diversified farm. They grew vegetables, tended bees, raised livestock for meat and dairy, and cultivated fields of wheat, corn, rye, and oats. On this hillside they maintained a substantial orchard. Some of these products were consumed by the family, their tenants, and their enslaved workers. Others were sold at market.
audioDescription:
(352 words)
Traveling 200 feet north from Peirce Mill is the Orchards, Fields, Gardens, Pastures wayside.
A walkway of gravel and soft rubber runs north to south in front of this three by four-foot sign. Facing the sign and directed uphill to the west, a garden area about 100 by two hundred feet sits across a gravel path about thirty feet in front of you. The gravel path continues past the garden to the left and reaches a small parking area on the right side after about fifty feet.
Beyond the garden is a lush forest area of fifty-foot trees and bushes. Behind you is a downward-sloping field area about 100 feet long and wide with picnic tables and thirty-foot tall trees. A dirt path runs along the bottom of the hill and Rock Creek is about thirty feet past the path.
The wayside shows a drawing of seven enslaved working men and women working in a wheat field that spans the top of the sign. They stack hay into a pile in front of a one-story brick building with two windows. An ox-drawn carriage sits in a grass field by a dirt road in front of them, and an orchard with red fruit lines the right side of the image.
A five by five-inch black and white map in the lower left corner indicates that you are near Peirce's Mill and Pierce Shoemaker is to the south. Text below the map reads:
This detail from an 1861 map shows the mill, several other buildings, and the rows of trees on the hillside that made up the Peirce family orchard.
To the right of the map, the sign is titled in large white letters:
Orchards, Fields, Gardens, Pastures
Below, the text reads:
Even in the mill's heyday, the Peirce family ran a diversified farm. They grew vegetables, tended bees, raised livestock for meat and dairy, and cultivated fields of wheat, corn, rye, and oats. On this hillside they maintained a substantial orchard. Some of these products were consumed by the family, their tenants, and their enslaved workers. Others were sold at market.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Parrott Ropewalk
listingDescription: In 1804, rope-maker Richard Parrott purchased his Washington, DC, property and developed his estate. Before long, he added a "Ropewalk" for manufacturing rope, a Federal-style mansion, and gardens and orchards. The property was purchased by the United States Government in 1911 for the creation of a public park. Landscape architects George Burnap and Horace Peaslee prepared designs for the park that integrated features from the former estate's landscape and incorporated new el

images.altText: An informational panel in a wooded area with a trail to the left.
images.title: Information Panel: Parrott Ropewalk
images.caption: Information Panel: Parrott Ropewalk

bodyText: In 1804, rope-maker Richard Parrott purchased his Washington, DC, property and developed his estate. Before long, he added a "Ropewalk" for manufacturing rope, a Federal-style mansion, and gardens and orchards. The property was purchased by the United States Government in 1911 for the creation of a public park. Landscape architects George Burnap and Horace Peaslee prepared designs for the park that integrated features from the former estate's landscape and incorporated new elements for public park use.
audioDescription:
(408 words)
The Parrott Ropewalk wayside is located along a walkway off the north side of R Street NW in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, DC.
From the intersection of R Street and Avon Place NW, travel north along the red brick-lined cement walkway on the north side of R street. The walkway is lined on both sides with four-foot tall holly bushes and covered in shade from fifty-foot tall trees set along the path. The lane continues eight hundred feet (243 meters) further into the park to the north.
Proceed seventy feet (21 meters) north on the path and the wayside will be sitting on your right. Beyond the sign is a tree-lined open grass field. The faded tan sign is titled across the top in black letters to read:
Parrott Ropewalk
Text below reads:
Here the Richard Parrott Ropewalk manufactured rope and rigging used on sailing vessels that plied their trade in old Georgetown through the early 19th Century.
The ropewalk receives its name from the long path used for the laying out of the individual yarns of rope prior to twisting them together.
Rope making was accomplished by first combing hemp and attaching it to a clockwise revolving hook spinning it into yarn.
Several yarns were then attached to separate hooks and twisted together counterclockwise to form strands. These three strands were twisted together clockwise again making rope.
Because of the constant change in direction, the rope would not unravel. If a larger rope was needed, three smaller ropes could be twisted together to form anchor cable.
Below on the right are four sketches of types of rope, titled at the top: Some common types of rope. Text to the left describes each example
HAWSER-LAID 3 strands and right-handed, with the sun
SHROUD-LAID 4 strands, with the sun
CABLE-LAID 3 strands of 3 yarns each, laid against the sun
A strand is made up of two or more rope yarns
The entire bottom of the sign features a sketch of men working on a rope line. Three men at the left end of the line appear to be turning a crank from a structure of connected wood beams. Further along the line to the right past a triangular support, two more men work on the line by a wooden beam structure. Two more men to the right work along the rope line, and two additional men stand at the end of the line, turning a hand crank.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Robert Emmet Memorial

images.altText: An informational panel in front of shrubs and trees.
images.title: Information Panel Robert Emmett Memorial
images.caption: Information Panel: Robert Emmett Memorial

bodyText: Information Panel: Robert Emmett Memorial
audioDescription:
(806 words)
The Robert Emmett Memorial sits in a small triangular park along Massachusetts Avenue, NW, and is bordered by S street, NW to the north and 24th street to the east. There are crosswalks at each corner, but the only sidewalk is on the Massachusetts Avenue side. Massachusetts frequently carries heavy traffic.
The triangle is a grassy patch of land and the memorial sits about thirty feet (9 meters) from the 24th and Massachusetts Avenue intersection, near the center of the triangle. From the intersection of Massachusetts and 24th, walk about thirty feet (9 meters) northwest along Massachusetts. On the right, a path of three-foot wide asphalt circles lead to the statue. There are bushes on either side of the path.
On the right, just before reaching the pathway to the statue, a three by four-foot wayside sits about ten feet from the sidewalk. The wayside displays the following text:
Robert Emmet
Irish Patriot
"I wish to procure for my country the guarantee which Washington procured for America"
The centerpiece of this small park is a sculpture of Irish patriot Robert Emmet that serves as a tribute to how American democracy inspired the independence of Ireland. Emmet, born in Dublin in 1778, was strongly influenced by the American Revolution. Educated at Trinity College Dublin, Emmet was remembered by contemporaries for his oratorical brilliance.
An oval shaped image assumed to be Emmet is at the top center of the sign. The man faces to his left, with a stern look on his face and is wearing an early 19th century military uniform. A sword rests on his left arm.
To the right is text describing the process of establishing the memorial park. The full text reads:
Establishing a Park
In 1912, the Smithsonian Institution offered space for a statue of Robert Emmet in the rotunda of the U.S. National Museum, and a group of Irish-Americans commissioned Jerome Connor to create the sculpture. President Woodrow Wilson and members of Congress attended its dedication in 1917. The Smithsonian American Art Museum loaned the sculpture to the National Park Services in 1966 to serve as the centerpiece for this park to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Easter Rising. President Lyndon Baines Johnson sent this message for the 1966 dedication:
"...The sheer patriotism and the gallant courage of Robert Emmet have inspired Americans no less than Irishmen...We Americans are proud to accord a place of honor here in the Nation's Capital to Robert Emmet, whose struggles and sacrifices bespeak the yearnings of mankind throughout the ages."
In 2016 the park was refurbished and re-dedicated to commemorate the 100th Anniversaries of the Emmet statue, the Easter Ring, and the National Park Service.
The bottom half of the sign is a color drawing of Emmet speaking to a crowd from a raised platform with a waist high rail. He appears to be speaking from the witness stand in a courtroom. Red-coated British troops are among those in the crowd.
Text in a black panel on the bottom left details an armed rebellion led by Emmet against British rule. The full text reads:
In 1803, Emmet led an armed rebellion against British rule, proclaiming the establishment of an Irish Republic. The uprising was quickly suppressed. Emmet fled, but was captured upon returning to Dublin to see his fiancÃ©e Sarah Curran. Tried for treason on September 19, 1803, he was immediately found guilty and sentenced to death by hanging. Emmet's "Speech from the Dock" motivated the movement that led to independence for Ireland following the Easter Rising in 1916:
"...I appeal to the immaculate God that my conduct has been governed only by the conviction...of the emancipation of my country from the super inhuman oppression under which she has long and too patiently travailed. Let no man attaint my memory by believing that I could have engaged in any cause but that of my country's liberty and independence...Let no man write my epitaph. When my country takes her place among the nations of the earth, then and not till then, let my epitaph be written."
Emmet was executed the next day, on September 20, 1803. His stirring words continue to inspire Irish patriotism.
The lower right side of the sign features a black and white image of a man in suit and tie, and is titled: Jerome Connor, Master Sculptor. Text to his right reads:
Jerome Connor, Master Sculptor
Jerome Connor was born in County Kerry, Ireland in 1874. After immigrating to Massachusetts in 1888, Connor trained as a stonecutter and bronze founder. He attended Elbert Hubbard's esteemed Roycroft artisan community, and in 1910 established a studio in Washington, D.C., where he lived until returning to Ireland in 1925. His sculptures included Bishop John Carroll (1912), Nuns of the Battlefield (1924), Bronx Victory Memorial (1925), and the Lusitania Peace Memorial in Cobh, Co. Cork (posthumous).
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: A Living Cycle

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a wooded area.
images.title: Rock Creek Park nature center trail
images.caption: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: A Living Cycle

bodyText: Informational Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: A Living Cycle
audioDescription:
(317 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
The "A Living Cycle" wayside is located on the Edge of the Woods Trail, which begins on the west side of the Nature Center, a one-quarter-mile paved loop through a forested section of Rock Creek Park that is wheel-chair accessible, and a rope lines the right side of the path as you proceed through. The Edge of the Woods Trail begins seventy feet west of the Nature Center building, proceed right at the fork in the pedestrian walkway.
The one by two-foot wayside is about four hundred ninety feet into the trail, along the right side of the path. A similar sign is set about twenty feet before, also on the right. A bench separates the two signs. The yellow sign is titled across the top in black letters:
A Living Cycle
A color drawing at the bottom of the sign shows a log lying on the ground amongst leaves. Mushrooms are growing on the log, worms and caterpillars borough through the log. Ants, centipedes, potato bugs, and other insects can be seen along the ground and a bee hovers above.
Text above reads:
When leaves, branches, and trees fall to the forest floor, bacteria and fungi begin the process of decay. Although some of these organisms may be microscopic in size, they are very important to the forest. Without them the valuable minerals in the dead materials could not be broken down and used again by growing plants. This process of growth, death, and decay is a never-ending cycle that helps maintain the forest community.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: Animal Homes

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a wooded area.
images.title: Nature Center Trail: Animal Homes
images.caption: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: Animal Homes

bodyText: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: Animal Homes
audioDescription:
(320 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
The "Animal Homes" wayside is located on the Edge of the Woods Trail, which begins on the west side of the Nature Center, a one-quarter-mile paved loop through a forested section of Rock Creek Park that is wheel-chair accessible, and a rope lines the right side of the path as you proceed through. The Edge of the Woods Trail begins seventy feet west of the Nature Center building, proceed right at the fork in the pedestrian walkway.
The Animal Homes wayside sits at the north side of the trail, about three hundred fifty feet from the trailhead, and on the left side of the trail when traveling through in a clockwise direction. The yellow sign is set about two feet back of the path in tall grass and is titled across the top in black letters:
Animal Homes
The sign features a color drawing of a tree with a racoon peeking out from a hole towards the top. A fox sits in another hole at the bottom of the tree, and a bird stands on a branch above on the left as it feeds its young in a nest.
Text to the left reads:
The forest provides a home for many types of animals. While walking on the trail look closely for these homes: nests made of materials such as grasses, twigs or leaves; holes in the ground, in trees, or fallen logs. During the summer months many of these homes are hidden by leaves, but in winter, animal homes are easier to see. How many can you find?
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: Forest Food
audioDescription:
(401 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
Beyond the front doors of the Rock Creek Nature Center is a thirty by forty-foot space featuring a gift shop, an exhibit space in the back, restrooms to the left, and a staircase to the right of the front desk which leads downstairs to a younger kids learning area.
The "Forest Food" wayside is located on the Edge of the Woods Trail, which begins on the west side of the Nature Center, a one-quarter-mile paved loop through a forested section of Rock Creek Park that is wheel-chair accessible, and a rope lines the right side of the path as you proceed through. The Edge of the Woods Trail begins seventy feet west of the Nature Center building, proceed right at the fork in the pedestrian walkway.
The "Forest Food" wayside sits at the end of the trail as it loops back to the Nature Center, on the right side of the path. The yellow sign is titled across the top in black letters:
Forest Food
A color drawing on the right shows a plant growing through soil and receiving sunlight, while its roots grow in the soil below towards water. Labeled photosynthesis at the top, arrows point from the sun to the plant's leaves. Arrows point to the leaves, indicating carbon dioxide is coming to the plant leaves, and the plant release oxygen shown on the other side of the plant leaves. Below the leaves are identified as having chlorophyll. Further below, water is shown by the plant roots in the soil.
Text to the left of the image reads:
Plants from the tiny mosses at your feet to the towering trees above, are the basic food makers of the woodland community.
Chlorophyll in the leaves along with sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide are the basic ingredients in making food (sugar and starches) for the plants and the forest animals. During this process, called photosynthesis, the trees return oxygen to the air and the great cycle of nature replenishes itself. Can you find any evidence of forest food being eaten?
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: Giants of the Forest
audioDescription:
(359 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
Beyond the front doors of the Rock Creek Nature Center is a thirty by forty-foot space featuring a gift shop, an exhibit space in the back, restrooms to the left, and a staircase to the right of the front desk which leads downstairs to a younger kids learning area.
The "Giants of the Forest" wayside is located on the Edge of the Woods Trail, which begins on the west side of the Nature Center, a one-quarter-mile paved loop through a forested section of Rock Creek Park that is wheel-chair accessible, and a rope lines the right side of the path as you proceed through. The Edge of the Woods Trail begins seventy feet west of the Nature Center building, proceed right at the fork in the pedestrian walkway.
The one by two-foot wayside is about one hundred feet (30 meters) into the trail, along the left side of the path. The yellow sign is titled across the top in black letters:
Giants of the Forest
A drawing along the right side of the sign shows an oak tree with a group of five bright green chestnut oak leaves with small chestnuts displayed in the left foreground. Writing in the lower right corner reads:
Chestnut oak
Text on the left side of the sign reads:
Trees dominate the forest. By controlling the amount of sunlight that reaches the forest floor, they influence all woodland plants and animals. Some of the tallest and oldest trees in the park are chestnut oak which you see here. Like all oak trees in the park, this tree produces acorns in the fall which are eaten by squirrels and deer. You can identify the chestnut oak by its sawtooth edged leaves in summer and its deeply ridged bark in winter.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: Living on the Edge
audioDescription:
(270 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
The "Living on the Edge" wayside is located on the Edge of the Woods Trail, which begins on the west side of the Nature Center, a one-quarter-mile paved loop through a forested section of Rock Creek Park that is wheel-chair accessible, and a rope lines the right side of the path as you proceed through. The Edge of the Woods Trail begins seventy feet west of the Nature Center building, proceed right at the fork in the pedestrian walkway.
The two by three-foot wayside is about four hundred sixty feet into the trail, along the right side of the path. A similar sign is set about twenty feet further, also on the right. A bench separates the two signs. The yellow sign is titled across the top in black letters:
Living on the Edge
Along the right side is a black sketch of a forest scene with trees, flowers, ferns, a butterfly to the left, and bird on the right side of the wayside.
Text on the left side reads:
Look around you. Grasses, wildflowers, birds, insects and butterflies live and visit here. Small mammals such as mice and voles live in the grasses. Watch and listen for the activity around you. Rock Creek Park has 19 other meadows.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: Meadow's End
audioDescription:
(260 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
The "Meadow's End" wayside is located on the Edge of the Woods Trail, which begins on the west side of the Nature Center, a one-quarter-mile paved loop through a forested section of Rock Creek Park that is wheel-chair accessible, and a rope lines the right side of the path as you proceed through. The Edge of the Woods Trail begins seventy feet west of the Nature Center building, proceed right at the fork in the pedestrian walkway.
The two by three-foot wayside is about five hundred feet into the trail moving clockwise from the beginning of the trailhead, set in the woods on the left side of the path. A bench is along the path about four feet to the left as you face the sign.
The faded light-brown sign is titled across the top in black letters:
Meadow's End
Text below reads:
As you leave the meadow and return to the manicured lawn of the Nature Center, think about the abundance and variety of life found here. The constant change of plants and animals in the meadow contributes to the variety of Rock Creek Park's natural environment. Meadows serve a valuable role in the preservation of biological diversity.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: Preserving a Community
audioDescription:
(312 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
The "Preserving a Community" wayside is located on the Edge of the Woods Trail, which begins on the west side of the Nature Center, a one-quarter-mile paved loop through a forested section of Rock Creek Park that is wheel-chair accessible, and a rope lines the right side of the path as you proceed through. The Edge of the Woods Trail begins seventy feet west of the Nature Center building, proceed right at the fork in the pedestrian walkway.
The one by two-foot wayside is about fifty feet from the beginning of the trailhead, set in the woods on the right side of the path. The yellow sign is titled across the top in black letters:
Preserving the Community
A color drawing at the bottom half of the sign shows different types of wildlife walking, crawling, and flying around the forest. A squirrel grabs onto the bottom of a tree, a robin flies through the trees, a deer eats grass on the forest floor, a chipmunk sits on a log, a fox peers out from behind a tree, a racoon lurks on the forest ground, and an owl sits calmly on a tree branch.
Text above reads:
Each plant and creature occupies a special place within the forest community and plays a vital role in keeping it in balance. The more places within a community the more diverse it is. To preserve the natural woodland of Rock Creek Park, we must protect even the smallest life so the forest maintains its diversity.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: Two Types of Trees
audioDescription:
(406 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
Beyond the front doors of the Rock Creek Nature Center is a thirty by forty-foot space featuring a gift shop, an exhibit space in the back, restrooms to the left, and a staircase to the right of the front desk which leads downstairs to a younger kids learning area.
The "Two Types of Trees" wayside is located on the Edge of the Woods Trail, which begins on the west side of the Nature Center, a one-quarter-mile paved loop through a forested section of Rock Creek Park that is wheel-chair accessible, and a rope lines the right side of the path as you proceed through. The Edge of the Woods Trail begins seventy feet west of the Nature Center building, proceed right at the fork in the pedestrian walkway.
The one by two-foot wayside is about one hundred fifty-five feet moving clockwise on the trail, along the right side of the path and about two feet beyond the roped fencing. The yellow sign is titled across the top in black letters:
Two Types of Trees
Text below reads:
There are two basic kinds of trees: evergreens, like spruces or pines, and deciduous, like oaks or maples. Evergreen trees usually have needle-like leaves with small surface areas, while deciduous trees have flat leaves with large surface areas. Since trees allow moisture to escape through their leaves, deciduous trees drop their leaves in the fall to avoid the cold, dry winter months. Evergreen trees can keep their needles year-round, continuously shedding and growing new ones.
Along the bottom of the sign are drawings of two trees and their leaves. On the left is an evergreen tree with dark green pine needles. To its right is a picture of a brown pinecone and a pine needled-branch with green spiky needles. The images are labeled underneath: White pine.
On the lower right side of the sign is an image of a green leave with a round green acorn attached to the branch. To its right is a tree with dark green leaves. The images are labeled: Red oak.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Rock Creek Park nature center trail: What Happened Here?
audioDescription:
(316 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
The "What Happened Here?" wayside is located on the Edge of the Woods Trail, which begins on the west side of the Nature Center, a one-quarter-mile paved loop through a forested section of Rock Creek Park that is wheel-chair accessible, and a rope lines the right side of the path as you proceed through. The Edge of the Woods Trail begins seventy feet west of the Nature Center building, proceed right at the fork in the pedestrian walkway.
The two by three foot sign sits at the north end of the trail, about four hundred feet from the trailhead, and on the right side of the trail when traveling through in a clockwise direction The path opens up about two feet on the right at this location, and a bench sits to the right of the sign. The rope line passes behind the bench, and in front of the sign by about one foot. The faded tan sign is titled across the top in black letters:
What Happened Here?
On the left side is a sketch of a deer standing at the bottom of the sign, its head turned to facing forward. Behind is a lush forest area.
Text on the left side reads:
Did you notice? A change occurred when you left the wood edge for the meadow. Grasses and flowers are plentiful. The smaller meadow plants cannot survive in the forest. However, we must cut the meadow or trees will eventually return. This process of change from meadow to forest is called succession.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Rock Creek's Mills

images.altText: A wooden circular mill surrounded by a stone canal
images.caption: Pierce Mill at Rock Creek Park

audioDescription:
(586 words)
The "Rock Creek's Mills" wayside sits just off an asphalt bike path, to the right as you face north, about 350 feet north of Peirce Mill , on the west side of Rock Creek, and at the northwest corner of Tilden Street NW and Beach Drive NW.
A tree-lined strip of land about twenty-feet wide stands between the sign and the creek, to the east.
The three by four-foot wayside sign features a gray and blue background of a map of the southwest corner of Washington, DC, showing the Potomac River and Eastern River (the present-day Anacostia River) connecting at the southern tip of the city.
The top right corner of the sign features a four by six-inch black box titled with large white lettering: Rock Creek's Mills. Below is text which reads:
Rock Creek's Mills
At one time, Rock Creek hosted a large number of flour mills, saw mills, and other industries. The force of the creek's waters, dropping more than 160 feet over 33 miles, gave the mills their power. The region's farms provided abundant raw materials. Wagon paths allowed farmers to transport their grain to the mills and their flour to market. The nearby port of Georgetown offered access to more distant customers. It was a near-perfect combination.
Five pictures are shown in four by three-inch boxes around the left side. All but the picture titled Parrott Mill are of two and three-story A-frame buildings. The Parrott Mill photo is of stone ruins.
Rock Creek is indicated on the map as it passes north to south through these pictures on the left side of the map. An arrow points to a spot along the creek that states: You Are Here.
The following text describes the five photos in clockwise order from the top left.
Blagden/Argyle Mill
(ca. 1850-1889)
Flour and fertilizer mill. Remnants evident one-half of a mile upstream.
The Blagden/Argyle Mill image is a black and white photo showing an empty two and one-half story stone building with open windows on the side and a large rectangular opening at the front of the building. A creek runs along the side of the building at the bottom of the image.
Lyons Mill
(1780-1875)
The earliest mill built along Rock Creek.
The Lyons Mill photo is a black and white image of an empty shell of a two and one-half story building.
Parrott Mill
(early 1880s)
Turned cotton and wool into thread.
The Parrott Mill image is a black and white photo showing about an eight-foot high stone wall of ruins. It sits in a wooded area amongst stones and trees.
Columbian (Adams) Mill
(ca. 1800-1867)
A wheat mill bought by President John Quincy Adams.
The Columbian (Adams) Mill photo is a black and white image of an empty three and one-half story stone building with open windows. A twenty-foot tree sits on the front right side of the building and Rock Creek runs along the righthand side.
Peirce Mill
(1829-1897)
The last remaining flour mill on Rock Creek, it replaced an earlier mill on the site.
The Peirce Mill photo is a color image of a three and one-half stone building with white frames windows. A mill wheel on the right side of the building sits in a four-foot wide trough that runs from right to left across the picture.
In the lower left corner of the sign is a surveyor's mark that reads:
Topographical Map of the District of Columbia
Surveyed in the years 1856, '57, â€˜58', and â€˜59
By A. Boschke
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: The Chesapeake Bay and Its Rivers Yours to Protect
listingDescription: An information panel about the Chesapeake Bay watershed.

images.altText: Informational panel on the Chesapeake Bay
images.title: Chesapeake Bay Wayside
images.caption: Informational Panel on the Chesapeake Bay

bodyText: An information panel about the Chesapeake Bay watershed.
audioDescription: (1141 words)From the intersection of Virginia Avenue and Rock Creek Parkway, NW, travel west on Virginia Avenue. The road will turn into a parking lot. Proceed through on the left side, pass over a bridge, and continue about fifty feet (15 meters) southwest. Chesapeake Bay and Its Rivers Yours to Protect wayside will be about ten feet beyond the path to the west and sitting along the river's edge.As you face the sign a boat pier will be directly in front of you on the Potomac River. The Thompson Boat Center is to the left. The sign sits on a grassy patch just beyond a thin dirt trail that runs behind it. A wood bench is to the right. Two forty-foot tall trees are at either side of the sign, about twenty feet away.The three by four-foot sign is badly faded. Written in white letters across a brown border on the top is written:The Chesapeake Bay and Its Rivers...Yours to ProtectText below on the left reads:The Chesapeake Bay, one of the largest and most productive estuaries in the world, is healthier today than it was just 10 years ago. Famous for its blue crabs, oysters and striped bass, the Bay has bounced back from its environmental low point in the 1970s thanks to an ongoing cooperative effort by the citizens and government. Although there are many positive signs, the Bay is far from restored. It still needs your help.What Makes the Bay Unique?In the Bay, freshwater from over 150 rivers and streams mixes with saltwater from the Atlantic Ocean to create the unique "estuarine" conditions that support over 2,700 plant and animal species. The Bay supplies millions of pounds of seafood, functions as a major shipping hub, provides a home for wildlife, and offers an incredible array of recreational opportunities.What's the Problem?We're the problem! We're also the solution. Take the first step toward a healthier Bay by realizing your everyday activities can contribute to the pollution in the rivers and Bay. Products including drain cleaner, lawn fertilizer, pesticides, gasoline, oil, and antifreeze when not properly handled can harm the rivers and the Bay.The Bay is Shallow and Vulnerable!The Bay is nearly 20 miles long and 20-miles wide, but it's only 21 feet deep on average. This shallowness limits the Bay's capacity to dilute the pollutants that drain into the Bay from its watershed.You Can Make a Difference!You can help protect the Bay and its crabs, fish and critters that call it home. Start a compost pile. Keep your car tuned up. Recycle. Use non-toxic alternatives for cleaning and for controlling pests. Try Bay-friendly landscaping with native plants and shrubs. Conserve water and electricity. Get involved! The Bay and rivers are yours to restore, yours to conserve.In a blue box in the center beneath the title text describes history of the Potomac River:Spectacular scenery is typical of the Potomac River, which begins stream in Fairfax Stone, West Virginia, and ends 380 miles later at the Chesapeake Bay. Upstream from here at Great Falls the river begins its dramatic change from a free flowing freshwater stream into a tidal estuary - a mixture of fresh and saltwater - which flows past the District of Columbia and for another 110-miles before it empties into the Bay at Point Lookout, Maryland.The Potomac also known as the "Nation's River" is rich in history. In 1632, two ships landed at what is now St. Mary's City on the lower Potomac and established the colony of Maryland. Less than a decade later, colonization of the Northern Virginia shore followed. Soon thriving ports were established here at Georgetown and downstream in Alexandria, Virginia. Our nation's capital was carved out of a Potomac swamp in the 1800s. As early as 1900, population growth and development caused serious water quality problems in the Potomac. Poorly treated sewage was the major culprit. By the 1950s, this stretch of the Potomac was so polluted it was declared unfit for human contact. But, in the 1960s, a massive publicly-funded clean-up effort began. By the 1970s water quality in the river began to improve. Today, the Potomac River at Washington is dramatically better. It's also a great place to fish for largemouth bass, perch, catfish and rockfish.A faded map of Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Maryland, Washington, Delaware, and Virginia sits in the center of the sign. A brown box to the left reads:The Chesapeake Bay drains the water for all or parts of Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, the District of Columbia, New York, West Virginia and Delaware. The Bay drainage basin or "watershed" covers 64,000 square miles of land.Three faded pictures to the right of the map, appear to be scenes of boating activity on the river.The faded right column has information about ways to help keep the river clean and other ways to help protect the river. Below is a faded picture of people standing by a riverbank.Below a faded picture in the lower left corner of two baby chicks in a nest, is text that reads:BAY WATCHERS - Above, two young osprey

title: Information Panel: The Color Purple

images.altText: An interpretive marker with a purple butterfly on it surrounded by several leafy green bushes
images.caption: "The Color Purple" Interpretive Marker

bodyText: n/a
audioDescription:
(394 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
Beyond the front doors of the Rock Creek Nature Center is a thirty by forty-foot space featuring a gift shop, an exhibit space in the back, restrooms to the left, and a staircase to the right of the front desk which leads downstairs to a younger kids learning area.
From the front entrance of the Nature Center, proceed around the right side of the building and walk back thirty feet. Turn left at the corner of the building and down four steps to a twenty by forty cement brick plaza area. A garden lines the space on its south, east, and north sides and wood picnic benches are along the building on the left and at the north end of the space. Stairs on the east side lead down to a walkway to the Edge of Woods Trail.
Facing west at the staircase leading down to the walkway below, to the right is a two by one-foot metal sign on a post in the garden. The sign has a light blue and gray background and features a large purple butterfly in the center with images of white flowers over its wings.
Titled at the top in purple letters reads:
The Color Purple
Text below reads:
Look for shades of this color in the Purple Coneflower, and Joe Pye Weed. And remember that, in the words of the character Shug in Alice Walker's book, you shouldn't walk by the color purple without giving it some praise.
In the bottom left corner is a purple weed-like image sprouting up with leaves on its bottom and middle and flowers toward its top. Text to the right reads:
Milkweed:
No, I don't have milk, but if my stem breaks, you'll see a milk-like substance. It doesn't taste good, but Monarch butterflies need me for food, and doctors use the fluid for medicine, so don't cut me down if I'm in your garden. I also make soft seeds, hidden inside my pods in fall.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: The Peirce Family Estate

images.altText: An informational panel in front of a house and a field.
images.title: The Peirce Family Estate
images.caption: Information Panel: The Peirce Family Estate

bodyText:
The sign depicts a country estate, with creek flowing left to right across the top. An ox can be seen drawing a carriage across a thin strip of land over the creek. Lush trees are above and a dirt road runs past a three-story building, two two-story buildings, and a small house towards the bottom. A hay field is in the lower left corner and an open grass field on the right. An orchard sits on the left side of the picture.

The sign title is in large white lettering on the lower right side: The Peirce Family Estate. Below is text that reads: The stone mill was an important part of the Peirce family's business. Like most farms in the 1800s, this was also a diversified and constantly evolving operation. The family managed hundreds of acres devoted to fields, pastures, and orchards. A sawmill, a nursery, barns, and bee hives dotted their landscape. The Peirce estate also contained housing for the large family, enslaved people, and tenants who made the business a success.
audioDescription:
(500 words)
This three-foot by four-foot sign sits on the right front side of the Peirce Barn at Tilden Street and Shoemaker Street NW in Rock Creek Park.
The sign sits about five feet in front of Peirce Barn, and faces Pierce Mill, about one hundred feet (30 meters) to the southeast. A fifteen-step cement staircase with metal railing on both sides leads down from the left side of the wayside to a gravel path than runs in between the barn and mill.
The sign depicts a country estate, with creek flowing left to right across the top. An ox can be seen drawing a carriage across a thin strip of land over the creek. Lush trees are above and a dirt road runs past a three-story building, two two-story buildings, and a small house towards the bottom. A hay field is in the lower left corner and an open grass field on the right. An orchard sits on the left side of the picture.
The sign title is in large white lettering on the lower right side: The Peirce Family Estate. Below is text that reads:
The stone mill was an important part of the Peirce family's business. Like most farms in the 1800s, this was also a diversified and constantly evolving operation. The family managed hundreds of acres devoted to fields, pastures, and orchards. A sawmill, a nursery, barns, and bee hives dotted their landscape. The Peirce estate also contained housing for the large family, enslaved people, and tenants who made the business a success.
Text above the orchard on the left side reads:
Orchard
The Peirce family grew apples and other fruits here.
Text by the creek running along the top of the image reads:
Rock Creek
Running water for the mill's operation
Text by the three-story building reads:
Mill
A significant part of the Peirce family's agricultural operations, the mill turned grain into flour and meal.
To the right of the mill, text along the creek reads:
Creek Crossing
This low-water ford, later replaced by a bridge, provided farmers access to the mill and markets.
Towards the middle of the picture and a two-story building along the road, text reads:
Distillery/Barn
(Currently a private residence. Not open to the public.) The Peirce family made fruit brandies and hard apple cider. This building also served as a barn.
A square is identified on the north side of this building that is labeled Miller's House.
Further down the road and by the smaller one-story building, text reads:
Spring House
Spring water flowing through the basement of this building kept produce and dairy products cool.
South of the Spring House, on the other side of the road, an area by the hay field is identified with a square and is labeled Family House.
Another square area along the southern edge of the orchard is labeled Agricultural Building, and a square area in the lower right corner of the picture, on the right side of the road, is labeled Peirce Family Home.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panel: Through the Eyes of a Scientist
listingDescription: This information panel is primarily about Rachel Carson and her involvement in the modern environmentalist movement. The panel also discusses how Glover Archbold Park came to be.

images.altText: A green and white information panel about author and scientist Rachel Carson
images.title: Information Panel: Rachel Carson
images.caption: Information Panel: Through the Eyes of a Scientist

bodyText:
Information panel about Rachel Carson and her time in Glover Archbold Park

 

Through the Eyes of a Scientist: 

Rachel Carson (1907-1964), a renowned writer and scientist who helped launch the modern environmental movement, once walked these woods. In her groundbreaking book, Siling Spring (1962), Carson warned citizens that the widespread use of pesticides posed a risk to the natural world and to their own health. Her writing helped lead to the foundign of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

Silent Spring also led to the banning of many persistent pesticides, including DDT. The ban resulted in the resurgence of the bald eagle population, which had previously been on the verge of extinction due to unrestrected pesticide use. The iconic eagle has since returned to the nearby Potomac River Valley and other natural areas throughout the Washington, DC region.

Carson encouraged children and their parents to share "joy, excitement, and mystery" in anture. She found beauty, healing, and "reserves of strength that...endure as long as life lasts" there herself.

It is easy to imagine Carson, who lived in nearby Silver Spring, Maryland, discovering inspiration in the region's many parks. Soon after the publication of Silent Spring, these photos of Rachel Carson bird watching were taken here in Glover Archbold Park.

A Capital City Oasis


Rachel Carson would never have been able to wander this forest without the preservation work of Charles Glover (1846-1936) and Anne Archbold (1873-1968). These visionaries wanted to preserve scenic and recreational opportunities within Washington, DC. In a city that was expanding quickly at the turn of the century, Glover managed to successfully advocate for the creation of Rock Creek Park, Potomac Park, and Fort Dupont Park. In addition, he created Glover Archbold Park by donating nearly 80 acres of his own land as a gift to the United States and its people. To complete the project, Anne Archbold, a landowner and philanthropist, donated an additional 23 acres with the instruction that the land "remain and be enjoyed by all as a natural sanctuary."
audioDescription: (967 words)From the intersection of 44th Street and Reservoir Road, NW, walk south on the east side of 44th Street about 100 feet. Turn left onto a dirt path and continue about 150 feet downhill into Glover Archbold Park. Turn right and proceed down the grass hill fifty feet. A two by three-foot wayside is set under and slightly to the right of a one hundred-foot-tall tree. Beyond the tree is an open grass field, about two hundred yards deep which extends out of view into the surrounding forest to both left and right.The sign has a green background and is titled across the top on black letters:Through the Eyes of a ScientistBelow towards the center of the sign is a black and white photograph of a woman with black hair and headscarf, wearing a fall jacket and holding a book in her left hand as she stands in front of a leafy tree. She also has a notepad and pen/pencil in her right hand. She looks off to her left and has a camera slung over her left shoulder.. Text beneath her reads:Rachel Carson was an important scientist and author who laid the foundation of the modern environmental movement.Further below, at the center bottom of the sign in large text reads:"Those who dwell among the beauties and mysteries of the Earth are never alone or weary of life."Rachel Carson â€˜The Sense of Wonder'Text along a white column that spans the left side of the sign details the life of Rachel Carson:Rachel Carson (1907-1964), a renowned writer and scientist who helped launch the modern environmental movement, once walked these woods. In her groundbreaking book, Silent Spring (1962), Carson warned citizens that the widespread use of pesticides posed a risk to the natural world and to their own health. Her writing helped lead to the founding of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.Silent Spring also led to the banning of many persistent pesticides, including DDT. The ban resulted in the resurgence of the bald eagle population, which had previously been on the verge of extinction due to unrestricted pesticide use. The iconic eagle has since returned to the nearby Potomac River Valley and other natural areas throughout the Washington, DC region.Carson encouraged children and their parents to share "joy, excitement, and mystery" in nature. To complete the project, Anne Archbold, a landowner and philanthropist, donated an additional 23 acres with the instruction that the land "remain and be enjoyed by all as a natural sanctuary."Set vertically in the top right corner are two black and white photographs. The top picture shows a man gazing off to the left in a three-piece suit with high collar, tie, and straw boater hat. A label in the lower left corner reads: Charles Glover.Below is a photograph of a smiling woman in a broad-brimmed white hat with black band, black beaded necklace, and white outfit standing in front a group of well-dressed people behind her. A label in the lower left corner reads: Anne Archbold.Text in the top right corner above both pictures reads:These two Washington, D.C. philanthropists donated the land that became Glover Archbold Park.An image of a bird sitting on a tree branch is set in the bottom left corner of the sign.
