This appears to be the same outfit she wears in the other photo of her (Rachel Carson) on the sign. The woman next t

title: Information Panel: We Got Da Blues

images.altText: An interpretive marker titled " We Got Da Blues" is in front of a leafy bush
images.caption: "We Got Da Blues" Interpretive Marker

audioDescription:
(306 words)
The Rock Creek Nature Center is located in upper northwest Washington, DC, just south of Military Road, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
From Military Road, NW, travel east and turn right onto Glover Road, NW. Travel four hundred twenty yards then turn left. Proceed six hundred fifty feet, and the Rock Creek Nature Center and Planetarium will be on your right.
Beyond the front doors of the Rock Creek Nature Center is a thirty by forty-foot space featuring a gift shop, an exhibit space in the back, restrooms to the left, and a staircase to the right of the front desk which leads downstairs to a younger kids learning area.
From the front entrance of the Nature Center, proceed around the right side of the building and walk back thirty feet. Turn left at the corner of the building and down four steps to a twenty by forty cement brick plaza area. A garden lines the space on its south, east, and north sides and wood picnic benches are along the building on the left and at the north end of the space. Stairs on the east side lead down to a walkway to the Edge of Woods Trail.
On the right at the bottom of the steps is a one by two-foot metal sign with a light blue background and an image of a guitar covered with flowers in white. The title of the sign at the top in black reads in quotes:
"We Got Da BLUES"
Text in the lower right reads:
There are several blue flowers in this garden. Blue Vervain, near the front, blooms in the summer. Spiderwort is scattered throughout and its blue flowers close at mid-day. Down the slope of the garden, near the fence, is a large clump of Virginia Bluebells, which bloom in April.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Information Panels: Creating Meridian Hill
listingDescription: Visionary and Park ChampionMeridian Hill Park might never have been built had it not been for the determination of Mary Foote Henderson (1846-1931). For 22 years, she lobbied Congress for funds to buy the land and build the park. Congress's 1910 vote to authorize construction of Meridian Hill Park is a testimony to her resolve.Henderson's efforts in urban development weren't limited to promoting Meridian Hill Park.

images.altText: Three informational panels in front of trees.
images.title: Information Panel: Meridian Hill
images.caption: Information Panel: Meridian Hill

bodyText:
Visionary and Park Champion


Meridian Hill Park might never have been built had it not been for the determination of Mary Foote Henderson (1846-1931). For 22 years, she lobbied Congress for funds to buy the land and build the park. Congress's 1910 vote to authorize construction of Meridian Hill Park is a testimony to her resolve.
Henderson's efforts in urban development weren't limited to promoting Meridian Hill Park. She engaged the services of some of the country's foremost architects for her grand schemes, including an enormous new presidential mansion and two Lincoln memorials, none of which were ever built.
Henderson had nearly a dozen elaborate residences built on 15th and 16th Streets for use as embassies and other diplomatic missions. She then planned to line 16th Street with the busts of former presidents and change the name of the street to "Avenue of the Presidents." Although she succeeded in getting the street renamed for a short time, her grand vision for 16th Street was never realized.

Creating the "City Beautiful"


At the beginning of its second century, the nation's capital was changing dramatically. In 1902, the United States Senate adopted a number of recommendations from the Senate Park Commission, popularly known as the McMillan Commission. By 1910, a federally appointed group of architects and designers, the Commission of Fine Arts, was directing the rehabilitation of the National Mall. Under their supervision, construction began on several new buildings near the Capitol, including the monuments to Lincoln and Jefferson, and on a series of new parks.
Two principles guided both commissions. The first was Pierre L'Enfant's 1792 plan of the city, which had never been fully realized and had nearly been lost during the 19th century. The second was creation and maintenance of grand public spaces, as endorsed by the proponents of the City Beautiful movement of the 1890s, and exemplified by the Beaux Arts designs of the French and Italian Renaissance revivals. Serving as a "monumental entrance to Washington," Meridian Hill Park demonstrates both principles.
According to Meridian Hill Park's National Historic Landmark nomination (1994), "the creation of a Renaissance villa landscape in the midst of an American city to serve as a public park has no true parallel."

Design Challenges


Limited funds and the dramatic change in elevation at the Meridian Hill Park site - falling 75 feet from north to south - challenged the Commission of Fine Arts and their designers. The 16th Street edge required massive retaining walls to transition from the upper park to the sidewalk at street level.
Budget constraints meant the designers could not specify natural stone for the desired Renaissance forms. To find a solution, the park's architect in charge, Horace Peaslee, turned to the Earley Studio in Arlington, Virginia, renowned for its artistry and craftsmanship.
"For John Earley, Meridian Hill Park was the beginning of an involvement with concrete that was to last nearly thirty years. Eventually, he became the world's foremost expert on the practical aspects of concrete making, and under his direction the Earley Studio executed works of such unusual complexity and beauty that they have never been equaled,"
Frederick Cron, historian

Park Designers


Noted landscape architects George Burnap and Horace Peaslee, who worked in the Office of Public Buildings and Grounds, designed Meridian Hill Park under the guidance of the Commission of Fine Arts. By 1914, Burnap had completed his basic design: a linear series of elements that included the Mall, the Great Terrace, the Hillside Gardens with Cascades, and the Lower Plaza with memorial to President Buchanan.
After Burnap returned to private practice in 1917, Peaslee submitted revision that greatly simplified the Mall. As automobiles were rapidly replacing horse-drawn carriages in the city, he eliminated vehicular access into the park. He added a pedestrian entrance on 15th Street and shifted the Buchanan Memorial off the main axis to the east side of the Lower Plaza.
When park construction began in 1918, landscape designer Ferruccio Vitale was hired to develop a planting plan for Meridian Hill Park. Following Peaselee's lead, Vitale greatly simplified the lower park. He eliminated the 16th Street entrance to the Great Terrace, the bridge over the Cascades and the oval amphitheater, and simplified the pathways of the Hillside Gardens.
audioDescription:
(138 words)
The Meridian Hill exhibits are a set of four wayside signs, each three by four feet in Meridian Hill Park, an urban park in the Columbia Heights neighborhood of Washington, DC. The park is bordered by 15th, 16th, W, and Euclid streets NW, and sits on a prominent hill one and one-half miles (2.5 kilometers) due north of the White House.
The waysides sit at the edge of the park, along a cement pedestrian walking path that winds north and south on the park's east side. From the 15th and Chapin street entrance into the park, go up three steps from the sidewalk into the park, and, turn immediately right along the path. Travel north two hundred forty feet (73 meters), and the waysides will be on your left. Restrooms are on the right another thirty feet north.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: James Buchanan Memorial
listingDescription: James Buchanan (1791-1868) was 15th president of the United States. This memorial is in Meridian Hill Park.

images.altText: A bronze seated statue of President Buchanan. The platform is granite, with two figures representing Law and Diplomacy.
images.caption: President James Buchanan Memorial at Meridian Hill Park

bodyText:
James Buchanan (1791-1868) was 15th president of the United States. He was born in Pennsylvania and served in the War of 1812. Before he was elected to the office of President of the United States, he served as a Representative in Congress, U.S. Minister to Russia and to Great Britain, Senator and Secretary of State. His presidency (1857-1861) came at the brink of the Civil War, and some have faulted Buchanan for his failure to avert the sectional crisis that finally boiled over as he left office. Buchanan's niece, Mrs. Harriet Lane Johnston, who had served as the unmarried president's hostess, left a bequest to build this memorial upon her death in 1903. Many opposed the memorial's construction, finding it improper to honor Buchanan ahead of presidents such as Adams or Jefferson. After many years in limbo, the memorial was finally approved by Congress on June 27, 1918 (40 Stat. 632). 

Cost: Harriet Lane Johnston left $115,000 for the memorial to be built.

Dedicated: June 26, 1930

Sculptor: Hans Schuler

Memorial Description

The memorial consists of a bronze seated statue of President Buchanan. The platform is granite, with two figures representing Law and Diplomacy.

Inscriptions

Statue, corner
Hans Schuler 1929

Left wall
James Buchanan of Pennsylvania / President of the United States / MDCCCLVII MDCCCLXI

Right wall
The Incorruptible Statesman Whose Walk was Upon the Mountain Ranges of the Law
audioDescription:
(453 words)
The James Buchanan Memorial is a bronze and granite memorial in the southeast corner of Meridian Hill Park. The park is bordered by 15th, 16th, W, and Euclid streets NW, and sits on a prominent hill one and one-half miles (2.5 kilometers) north of the White House.
From the northwest corner of the intersection of 15th street and W street NW, enter the park and proceed up the inclined walkway about two hundred twenty feet. The walkway includes many steps. You will enter a plaza landing area and the memorial will be on your right.
The eight-foot tall bronze sculpture of Buchanan sits in a chair with arms, atop a two-tiered six-foot high six-foot wide pedestal in front of an eighteen foot tall, ten foot wide white granite wall. He is flanked by two granite figures that sit at either end of the eighty-foot wide granite memorial. An eight-foot tall, twenty-foot long back wall spans both sides between the Buchanan sculpture and the side figures. Two steps lead up to the memorial platform from the plaza. The pedestal sits on a t-tiered base.
Buchanan has a sullen look on his face. His eyes are cast downward and he holds a newspaper in his left hand which lays across his left leg. He wears a long coat, suit vest, and bow tie. The sculptor's signature is etched in the lower right corner of the statue and reads:
Hans Schuler 1929
The figure seated forty feet to his left is of a topless woman with a band in her hair. She wears a robe on her lap and wrapped around her right arm, and her legs are crossed at the ankle. Her left hand rests on her left thigh and her sandaled feet can be seen below the robe. She has a long narrow piece of paper or cloth spread across her lap. Text beside her inscribed along the wall reads:
James Buchanan of Pennsylvania
President of the United States
MDCCCLVII MDCCCLXI
At the right end of the memorial, the other figure is that of a man. He wears sandals, with a robe around his waist and his legs crossed at the ankle. He holds a sword across his lap with his right hand and holds fasces upright with his left. Text to his left reads:
The Incorruptible Statesman Whose Walk was Upon the Mountain Ranges of the Law
Between the man and woman figures and the Buchanan statue are 1.5 foot tall granite benches that run along the base of the eight-foot tall back wall, on both sides.
Trees hang over the top of the memorial wall from behind, and the plaza area is ringed with trees, providing ample shade throughout the space.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: James Cardinal Gibbons Memorial
listingDescription: This park was designed and built in 1918. The statue of James Cardinal Gibbons, archbishop of the Diocese of Baltimore, was erected in 1932.

images.altText: A large green statue of a man surrounded by trees and buildings.
images.title: James Cardinal Gibbons
images.caption: James Cardinal Gibbons

bodyText:
Cardinal Gibbons, born in Maryland, served as priest, bishop, and chaplain at Ft. McHenry. He was also instrumental in establishing Catholic University in Washington, DC. He was created cardinal in 1886 over the Archdiocese of Baltimore.

The statue was erected by the Knights of Columbus without expense to the United States under an Act of Congress approved April 23, 1928 (45 Stat. 453). 

Cost: $35,998

Dedication: August 14, 1932

Sculptor: Leo Lentelli

Memorial Description

The bronze statue shows him seated, in official robes of the church, on a granite pedestal with a granite, marble and concrete reinforced platform.

Inscriptions

Front
JAMES / CARDINAL / GIBBONS / MDCCCXXXIV / MCMXXI

back
ERECTED BY / THE KNIGHTS / OF COLUMBUS / MCMXXXII
audioDescription:
(270 words)
James Cardinal Gibbons is located in a triangular park in the Mount Pleasant neighborhood of Washington, DC, bordered by Park Road, NW to the north, 16th Street NW to the west, and Pine Street NW to the east. Shrine of the Sacred Heart Catholic Church is located across Pine Street NW to the east.
From the intersection of Pine and 16th Streets, enter the cement and brick plaza area and proceed about one hundred fifty feet (45 meters) north.
The bronze statue features Cardinal Gibbons seated and wearing robes. In his left hand he holds a cross which hangs from his neck. His right hand is raised, the middle two fingers are extended, and his head faces down slightly, as if he is blessing the person standing in front of him. The granite base stands eight feet tall and ten feet wide.
Two cross designs are carved at each top corner of the base, as well as on the front and back center, amidst other floral and leaf patterns as a border. An inscription on the front face of the pedestal reads:
JAMES
CARDINAL
GIBBONS
MDCCCXXXIV
MCMXXI
An inscription on the back reads:
ERECTED BY
THE KNIGHTS
OF COLUMBUS
MCMXXXII
The left and right sides of the base feature ornate shield designs, the left with a cross in the shield and above, and the right with a cross and three faces of lions in the shield and cardinal's hat above on the left.
The statue sits in a circular brick area at the north end of the plaza and faces the pointed end of the triangular area to the south. Bushes and trees surround the entire plaza area.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Jean Jules Jusserand Memorial
listingDescription: Jules Jusserand was the French ambassador to the United States from 1902 to 1925. Jusserand was an accomplished author and close associate of many of Washington's elite, including President Theodore Roosevelt.

images.altText: A large stone monument in a wooded area.
images.title: Jean Jules Jusserand Memorial
images.caption: Jean Jules Jusserand Memorial

bodyText:
Jules Jusserand was the French ambassador to the United States from 1902 to 1925. Jusserand was an accomplished author and close associate of many of Washington's elite, including President Theodore Roosevelt. The memorial was erected by the Jusserand Memorial Committee at no expense to the United States. It holds the distinction of being the first memorial erected on Federal property to a foreign diplomat and was approved under an Act of Congress on June 17, 1935.

Cost: $5,461
Dedicated: November 7, 1936
Sculptor: J.H. Friedlander

Memorial Description

The memorial is constructed of pink granite and is carved in the shape of a bench. The bench is semi-circular with four steps and is 10-feet long. 

Inscriptions

Jusserand
Personal Tribute of Esteem and Affection
1855 - 1932
audioDescription:
(222 words)
The Jean Jules Jusserand Memorial sits along the north side of Beach Dr NW, about seven hundred feet (640 meters) south of the intersection of Beach Dr NW and Tilden St. NW in Rock Creek Park.
Access is difficult, as there is no walkway across Beach Drive to access the memorial from the south. The memorial is set at the edge of thick woods and access from the north is also difficult.
The Peirce Mill Tennis courts about two hundred feet to the east and through the woods.
From Peirce Mill, walk east about fifty feet. Turn right and proceed south along the bike/walkway. At about seven hundred feet (213 meters), cross the pedestrian bridge over Rock Creek. Continue along the trail three hundred feet (91 meters). Here sits a three by four-foot wayside sign on the left side of the asphalt trail. Across Beach Drive to the north about sixty-five feet is the Jean Jusserand Memorial.
The memorial is a semi-circular bench of pink granite that sits on a hillside along the edge of a thick forest. Four granite steps lead to the bench, which is adorned with ornate, winged carved arms on each end. The bench spans about ten feet long, four feet high, and is inscribed along its back with:
Jusserand
Personal Tribute of Esteem and Affection
1855 - 1932
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Joan of Arc Statue
listingDescription: The Joan of Arc Statue is the only equestrian statue of a woman in Washington, DC. Joan of Arc was a heroic French figure who claimed to receive religious visions telling her to fight for France and overthrow the English during the Hundred Years' War. Upon her capture and trial at the hands of the English, she was burned at the stake, leading the Catholic church to recognize her as a martyr in 1456. She was beatified in 1909 and canonized in 1920.

images.altText: A large statue of Joan of Arc in a plaza surrounded by trees with orange leaves.
images.title: Joan of Arc Statue
images.caption: Joan of Arc Statue

bodyText:
The Joan of Arc Statue is the only equestrian statue of a woman in Washington, DC. Joan of Arc was a heroic French figure who claimed to receive religious visions telling her to fight for France and overthrow the English during the Hundred Years' War. Upon her capture and trial at the hands of the English, she was burned at the stake, leading the Catholic church to recognize her as a martyr in 1456. She was beatified in 1909 and canonized in 1920. This statue, a copy of the original at the Rheims Cathedral, was erected in 1922. The statue was a gift from the Society of French Women in Exile in New York. Approval for the statue occurred under an act of Congress on March 20, 1922 (42 Stat. 468) and the casting of the monument was supervised by the Ministre des Beaux Arts in Paris.

Cost: Unknown. Statue was erected at no cost to the United States.

Dedicated: January 6, 1922

Sculptor: Paul Dubois

Memorial Description

The statue is made of bronze which has aged to have a green tinge to it. Joan's horse has the front left and right rear foot in the air, indicating motion. The horse's mane also indicates motion. Joan holds the reins of her horse in her right hand. She is wearing armor with the visor of her helmet up. Her left arm is slightly raised and in her fist she holds a sword. The bronze statue sits on a granite plinth.

Inscriptions

Jeanne D’Arc / Liberatrice / 1412-1431 / Aux Femmes D’Amérique / Les Femmes De France / 

An inscription on the back of the pedestal reads:
Offert Par / “Le Lyceum” / Société Des Femmes De France / À New York / Le 6 Janvier 1922
audioDescription:
(272 words)
At the very southern end of the upper field and plaza area of Meridian Hill Park sits the Joan of Arc Statue. The urban park in the Columbia Heights neighborhood of Washington, DC is bordered by 15th, 16th, W, and Euclid streets NW, and sits on a prominent hill one and one-half miles (2.5 kilometers) north of the White House.
The seven-foot tall bronze equestrian statue depicts Joan of Arc riding a horse, clad in full plate armor and brandishing a long sword in her right hand. The horse is atop a 5 foot high, three by eleven-foot by 5 foot, three-tiered granite base, with its right front and left rear hooves in the air. Her body is twisted slightly, and her right arm is raised behind her holding a sword. She is wearing a helmet with a raised visor and she looks skywards. In her left hand she holds the reins to her horse. The statue, which faces south, is centered east to west in the plaza and is about 34 feet from the south end of the plaza.
The front face of the pedestal is inscribed to read:
Jeanne D'Arc
Liberatrice
1412-1431
Aux Femmes D'AmÃ©rique
Les Femmes De France
An inscription on the back of the pedestal reads:
Offert Par
"Le Lyceum"
SociÃ©tÃ© Des Femmes De France
Ã€ New York
Le 6 Janvier 1922
The statue faces south from the Meridian Hill Park terrace in the direction of the Washington Monument far in the distance. Below are the cascades waterfall fountains. The terrace extends about two hundred feet to the east and west, and features boxed in trees and fountains on each end. Stairs leading to the south lower end and fountains are about fifty feet apart along the south terrace perimeter wall, a three-foot high concrete railing with balusters.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Joaquin Miller Cabin
listingDescription: The Joaquin Miller Cabin was relocated from the neighborhood near Meridian Hill Park and reconstructed in Rock Creek Park. Joaquin Miller was a poet and writer from California who briefly lived in the cabin when he lived in Washington, DC in the 1880s.

images.altText: A small wooden cabin in the woods
images.title: Joaquin Miller Cabin
images.caption: Joaquin Miller Cabin

bodyText:
The Joaquin Miller Cabin was home to the eccentric poet when he was a resident of Washington, DC between 1883 and 1885.  

The L-shaped cabin was originally built near the present day intersection of 16th St NW and Belmont St NW. In 1911, when the area was being developed into Meridian Hill Park, the cabin was almost demolished. Fans and supporters of Miller petitioned to have the cabin saved and it was painstakingly taken apart and re-built in Rock Creek Park.

The Board of Control, who was managing Rock Creek Park at the time were against the move. California Senators intervened and had the cabin moved to Rock Creek Park. It was dedicated in 1912. The cabin was used for a time as a shelter and then as a concession stand for visitors to the park. Pherne Miller, Joaquin Miller's neice rented the cabin for over twenty years between 1931 and the 1950s. She not only sold candy and soda to park visitors, she taught art on the grounds surrounding int. In the 1970s, the Joaquin Miller Cabin poetry series began. The group originally held their meetings inside the cabin but crowds eventually exceeded the space avilable and the series was moved outside. The series was moved to the Rock Creek Park Nature Center auditorium in 2011 and renamed "The Joaquin Miller Poetry Series."
audioDescription: The Joaquin Miller Cabin is a one and a half story log cabin. Concrete fills the gaps between the logs. The roof is made of wooden shingles and has a steep peak. There are two windows at the highest points of the peaked roof while on the first floor every wall has either a door or a set of windows. Doors and window sashes are painted brown. The cabin sits among trees near Milkhouse Ford.

title: Kahlil Gibran Memorial
listingDescription: Gibran was a Lebanese-born poet most famous for his 1923 book "The Prophet," a collection of 26 prose poems. The book grew in popularity through the 1960s counterculture movement. Because of its popularity, Gibran is reported to be the third-best-selling poet in world history, behind Shakespeare and Lao Tsu.

images.altText: A man on a bench in front of a stone and grassy plaza.
images.title: Kahlil Gibran Memorial
images.caption: Kahlil Gibran Memorial

bodyText:
Gibran was a Lebanese-born poet most famous for his 1923 book "The Prophet," a collection of 26 prose poems. The book grew in popularity through the 1960s counterculture movement. Because of its popularity, Gibran is reported to be the third-best-selling poet in world history, behind Shakespeare and Lao Tsu.

Be sure to visit our Fountains page to learn the operating status of the fountain at the memorial.

Inscriptions

Wall, front
KAHLIL GIBRAN
Poet Philosopher
Marble wall
Presented to the People of the United States
By the Kahlil Gibran Centennial Foundation
May 24, 1991

Architect: Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum
Sculptor: Gordon S. Kray
1883
Kahlil Gibran was born in the village of Besharri near the biblical Cedars of Lebanon.
In boyhood, he emigrated to Boston where he began his career as artist and author.
His books, written in both Arabic and English, have been translated into numerous languages and are widely quoted.
He died in New York City.
1931
Kahlil Gibran's Legacy is the powerful simplicity of his words, which continue to inspire those who long for peace, search for love, and strive for justice.
Work is Love Made Visible
I love you my brother whoever you are
Whether you worship in
Your church, knell in your temple or pray in your mosque.
You and I
Are children of one faith
Fingers of the loving hand of one supreme being
A hand extended
To all
Limestone benches
Life without freedom is like a body without a soul and freedom without thought is confusion.
That which sings and contemplates in you is still dwelling within the bounds of that first moment which scattered the stars into space.
Do not the spirits who dwell in the ether envy man his pain?
We live only to discover beauty. All else is a form of waiting.
We extract your elements to make cannons and bombs but out of our elements you create lilies and roses. How patient you are Earth and how merciful!
When you love you should not say God is in my heart, but rather I am in the heart of God.
Upper plaza
THINK OF ME WHEN YOU SEE THE SUN COMING DOWN TOWARD ITS SETTING
SPREADING ITS RED GARMENT UPON THE MOUNTAIN
audioDescription:
(405 words)
The Kahlil Gibran Memorial is located on the east side of Massachusetts Avenue NW in the Embassy Row neighborhood of Washington, DC. The memorial park is about four hundred fifty-five yards (415 meters) northwest of Rock Creek. Directly across Massachusetts Avenue to the west is the Winston Churchill Memorial, and across the street to the northwest of the Churchill Memorial is Observatory Circle.
The memorial sits on two acres recessed from the sidewalk and along the edge of Woodland-Normanstone Terrace Park, a wooded forest along its western back side.
A twenty-five-foot long concrete foot bridge leads from the sidewalk across a shrub and flower-lined grassy area into the memorial. There are no steps in the area and although the backside is at a slight elevation, it is very wheelchair accessible.
The foot bridge leads to a circular arrangement of benches, paths, and walls. In the front-center is a three-foot high, fifty-foot long semi-circular gray marble wall with two-foot high curbed front, and adorned with a bronze head of Kahlil Gibran. An ornate star design encircled with a twelve-inch ring of granite adorns the ground in front of the wall and sculpture. The sculptured head emerges from a group of branches, foliage, and two foot-long doves to the right, along the wall. Inscribed on the front of the wall is:
KAHLIL GIBRAN
Poet Philosopher
A sidewalk leads around from either side of the wall and joins a thirty-five-foot wide, circular arrangement of benches at a slightly higher elevation than the marble wall. In the center of the benches is a small pool in the shape of an eight-pointed star, ten feet across. The limestone benches, ten feet long each and three on each side, are inscribed with the details of Gibran's life and quotes from his writings.
The plaza floor is designed with granite stars, octagons, and other geometrical shapes. Around the front edge of the upper plaza area is an inscription on the ground that reads:
THINK OF ME WHEN YOU SEE THE SUN COMING DOWN TOWARD ITS SETTING
SPREADING ITS RED GARMENT UPON THE MOUNTAIN
An outer walkway encircles the entire memorial and spans two hundred twenty-five feet around with a three-foot tall stone block outer wall.
Bushes and trees hang over the outer area and the forest behind provides an abundance of shade. A grass lawn lines the front of the memorial fountain area and a garden bed sits at its front edge.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Key Bridge Boathouse
listingDescription: Key Bridge Boathouse is managed by Boating in DC and provides visitors the opportunity to rent kayaks, canoes, and stand-up paddleboards.

images.altText: rows of paddle boards and stacks of kayaks beneath Key Bridge
images.title: Key Bridge Boathouse
images.caption: Paddle boards and kayaks at the Key Bridge Boathouse

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Key Bridge Boathouse is located at 3500 Water Street NW in the Georgetown Neighborhood of Washington, DC.

It is managed by Boating in DC and provides rentals of stand up paddleboards, kayaks and other water craft.

Information on rentals and lessons are available on the Boating in DC website.

title: Klingle Trail south

images.altText: A paved road curves out of forested area. Two cement blocks prevents cars from driving into a pullout
images.caption: Klingle Trail South

audioDescription:
(227 words)
Klingle Trail south is located in the northwest quadrant of Washington, DC along the west edge of Rock Creek Park.
Traveling northwest on Porter Street, NW, turn right onto Klingle Road, following the road around to the left, under Porter Street, and traveling eight hundred eighty-five feet (269 meters). Klingle road turns to the right at this point, and the asphalt trail head of Klingle Trail is to the west.
To the right of the trailhead is a six by ten feet cement block plaza, set with two black benches at its east end. The trail leads uphill through lush forest of tall trees on either side and a creek running down left of the trail.
The path is marked down the center with a yellow dividing line and a three-foot tall wood guard rail lines the left side. A drainage trench of stone lines the right side of the path. Black metal streetlights are spaced twenty feet apart along the right side.
The trail runs north about one half of a mile (804 meters) under the Connecticut Avenue bridge, past apartment buildings partially visible through the woods. Benches and turnout areas are set at various points along the trail.
Klingle Trail becomes Klingle road again at its northern end, about one hundred fifty feet (45 meters) south of the intersection with Cortland place in Cleveland Park.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Klingle Valley Trail top

images.altText: A paved bicycle path leads into a forested area
images.caption: Klingle Valley Trail Top

audioDescription:
(496 words)
Klingle Valley Trail top is located in the northwest quadrant of Washington, DC in the Cleveland Park neighborhood of Washington, DC.
From Klingle road and Cortland place, NW travel south on Klingle road about one hundred fifty feet (45 meters). Two, two-square foot cement blocks guard the trailhead of the asphalt Klingle Valley Trail.
On the south side of the cement blocks is a forty by forty-foot cement plaza set with two black metal benches in front of a black iron fence along the left side.
The trail runs south about one half of a mile (804 meters) under the Connecticut Avenue bridge, past apartment buildings partially visible through the woods. Benches and turnout areas are set at various points along the trail. There are benches in four areas along the trail, at the beginning and end of the trail, as well as at the .3 Klingle Valley trail marker, and the .5 Klingle Valley trail marker.
The path is marked down the center with a yellow dividing line and a three-foot tall wood guard rail lines the right side. A drainage trench of stone lines the left side of the path, and black metal streetlights are spaced twenty feet apart along the left side. Klingle Valley trail markers are spaced every tenth of a mile on the lamp posts.
About six feet behind the plaza benches and set among low vegetation about one foot off the plaza is a three by two-foot wayside.
Down hill slope sign.
The upper left corner features a black and white photograph of a dirt path running straight through a forest of trees with no leaves. Below the sign is titled in black letters:
Klingle Valley Trail
Text below reads:
Welcome to Klingle Valley Trail, a place for peaceful public recreation. This 0.7-mile trail is a steady, moderate incline through a small wooded stream valley leading to the rugged and picturesque Rock Creek. This trail is built on the remains of old Klingle Road. Part of the road was built in the early 1830s by Joshua Peirce, son of local land owner Isaac Peirce, to connect his estate and grist mill. The historic 1820s Peirce Mill, a visitor attraction, still sits on the bank of Rock Creek north of your present location.
Below is a map showing Klingle Valley Park to the left and National Zoological Park to the right, divided by Connecticut avenue. A dot stating You Are Here indicates your location at the west end of Klingle Valley Park.
A chart below shows distances to other nearby locations:
North from here Miles
Maryland Border 6.3
Rock Creek Park Nature
Center and
Planetarium 5.6
South from here Miles
Lincoln Memorial 3.8
Thompson Boat Center 3.4
The right side of the sign is a map of Rock Creek Park, indicating your location within the central core of the park, with Military Road along the top end of the map, and the Godfrey Lime Kilns of Georgetown at the southern end.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Lee Feed and Grain
listingDescription: Former location of Lee Feed and Grain, listed as the oldest African American owned business in the 1940s when it closed due to the industrialization of Georgetown.

images.altText: A large red building at an intersection of two roads.
images.title: Lee Feed and Grain
images.caption: Lee Feed and Grain

bodyText:
Lee Feed and Grain was established by a free black man named Alfred Lee in the early 1800’s. Family owned and operated, the feed and grain operated well into the 1940s and was listed as the oldest family owned African American business in America. The modernization of Georgetown forced them out of business. The feed and grain store sat on the corner of 29th and M streets for the entire time it was in operation. 

The building now at 2900 M Street NW is a private business. Please obey and respect posted signs.

quickFacts.value: Former location of African American owned business
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Little Forest Park
listingDescription: Little Forest Park is located in Northwest Washington, DC near Rock Creek Park. It is bordered by Military Road NW, 28th Street NW, Kanawha Street NW and 30th Street NW.

images.altText: A sign in front of woods
images.title: Little Forest Park
images.caption: Little Forest Park

bodyText:
Little Forest Park is located in Northwest Washington, DC near Rock Creek Park. It is bordered by Military Road NW, 28th Street NW, Kanawha Street NW and 30th Street NW. It is sometimes called Francis G. Newlands Park. 

The park has no amenities. Street parking is limited. DC public Transit has a bus stop on Military Road near the park.

title: Major General George B. McClellan Statue
listingDescription: This is an equestrian monument to Major General George Britton McCllean, U.S. Army, who served as general-in-chief and first commander of the Army of the Potomac during the American Civil War. The statue was sculpted by American Artist Frederick William MacMonnies and dedicated in 1907.

images.altText: A large monument of a man on a horse in front of buildings.
images.title: Major General George B. McClellan Statue
images.caption: Major General George B. McClellan Statue

bodyText:
This is an equestrian monument to Major General George Britton McCllean, U.S. Army, who served as general-in-chief and first commander of the Army of the Potomac during the American Civil War. 

Cost: $50,000
Dedicated: May 2, 1907
Sculptor: Frederick William MacMonnies

Monument Description

The bronze sculpture depicts General McClellan on his horse. The statue sits on a tall granite base with other bronze works attached to the plinth. The monument stands at the crest of a hill overlooking Connecticut Avenue NW.

Inscriptions

Shields
Yorktown
Malvern Hill
Fair Oaks
South Mountain
Antietam
Williamsburg
Rich Mountain
Gaine's Mill

Pedestal, front
MAJOR GENERAL / GEORGE BRINTON McCLELLAN / 1826-1885

Pedestal, back
Erected by the / Society of the Army of the Potomac / And the / Congress of the United States / 1907
audioDescription:
(330 words)
The George B. McClellan Memorial is located on a triangular median at the intersection of California Street, Connecticut Avenue, and Columbia Road, N.W. in the Kalorama neighborhood of Washington, DC. The Washington Hilton is across Columbia Road to the east.
The memorial stands amid busy traffic, though there are three walkways to access the triangle at its NW, NE and southern corners.
The thirteen-foot tall bronze equestrian statue faces south down Connecticut Avenue towards Dupont Circle, and downtown Washington beyond. McClellan is dressed in full military uniform including gauntlets, hat and sash and his sword hangs at his left side. He holds his horse's reins with his left hand and his right hand placed on his hip. The horse's right front hoof is raised, and its head curled downward.
The eighteen-foot tall, nine-foot long oblong granite pedestal rests on a forty-four-foot long, thirty-foot wide base. On either side of the pedestal is a bronze relief featuring an array of armaments - spears, axes, eagle-capped staffs, and a pair of crossed cannons draped in a shroud. An inscription on a bag at the bottom left corner of the east side relief reads: 57. An inscription in the lower right corner reads: Mac Monnies.
Encircling the pedestal base is a bronze oak and laurel garland that runs between bronze eagles standing atop spheres in each corner. Bronze shields line the top of the pedestal and are inscribed with the names:
Yorktown
Malvern Hill
Fair Oaks
South Mountain
Antietam
Williamsburg
Rich Mountain
Gaine's Mill
An inscription on the front face of the pedestal reads:
MAJOR GENERAL
GEORGE BRINTON McCLELLAN
1826-1885
Six granite steps lead up to the memorial from all four sides. Lush foliage and overgrowth line the front and back of the memorial and a tall evergreen tree sits at its east side.
Featured in back of the statue is raised lettering and the words:
Erected by the
Society of the Army of the Potomac
And the
Congress of the United States
1907
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Marconi Memorial
listingDescription: Guglielmo Marconi (1874-1937) was the inventor of the first radio wave communication system. Congress approved legislation for the memorial on April 13, 1938, and President Franklin Roosevelt signed the bill into law the next day. The monument was erected with funds collected by the Marconi Memorial Foundation and was completed on June 30, 1941.

images.altText: A large golden statue of a woman pointing on top of a golden stone.
images.title: Marconi Memorial
images.caption: Marconi Memorial

bodyText:
Guglielmo Marconi (1874-1937) was the inventor of the first radio wave communication system. Congress approved legislation for the memorial on April 13, 1938 (52 Stat. 217) and President Franklin Roosevelt signed the bill into law the next day. The monument was erected with funds collected by the Marconi Memorial Foundation.

Cost: $32,555

Dedicated: June 30, 1941

Sculptor: Attilio Piccirilli

Memorial Description

The memorial consists of a branze portrait bust of the Italian inventor. It sits on a double pedestal made of pink granite.

Inscriptions

front
MARCONI / 1874-1937

back
ERECTED BY POPULAR SUBSCRIPTION / AND PRESENTED TO THE CITY OF WASHINGTON / THE MARCONI MEMORIAL FOUNDATION / 1940

right
A. Piccirilli 1940
audioDescription:
(246 words)
Set at the north end of a small park along the west side of 16th Street, NW in the Mount Pleasant neighborhood of Washington, DC is the Marconi Memorial.
The memorial is bordered by Lamont Street, NW to the north, 16th Street NW to the east, and southbound 16th Street to the west.
The statue consists of a pair of pedestals on a granite base. Two steps lead up to the memorial platform. A gilded bronze bust of Guglielmo Marconi, three feet in height, sits on the smaller rectangular pedestal, which is seven feet high. Behind Marconi is a larger granite pedestal, approximately thirteen feet tall, topped with a gilded bronze figure of a nude woman atop a globe. Her left arm extends east, and her right arm is bent and pointing to the sky. Her legs are draped with a cloth and her wavy hair blows to the west. Curvy horizontal lines are carved into the bronze base beneath her.
On the front of the lower pedestal base, an inscription reads:
MARCONI
1874-1937
An inscription on the rear of the base reads:
ERECTED BY POPULAR SUBSCRIPTION
AND PRESENTED TO THE CITY OF WASHINGTON
THE MARCONI MEMORIAL FOUNDATION
1940
An inscription on the right-side base behind the sculpture reads:
A. Piccirilli 1940
The memorial sits at the northern curved edge of the park. A red brick sidewalk, lined with two benches, separates the memorial from trees and shrubs that line the memorial to the north.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Meridian Hill Park
listingDescription: Meridian Hill Park, a few blocks north of the White House, features unique statues, concrete aggregate architecture, and the largest cascading fountains in North America.

images.altText: Visitors by the fountains at Meridian Hill Park.
images.title: Cascades Fountain
images.caption: Visitors by the fountains at Meridian Hill Park.

bodyText:
A Garden Fit for an Aristocrat, Open to the Public

In 1819, John Porter erected a mansion on Meridian Hill. The site was called Meridian Hill because it was on the exact longitude of the original District of Columbia milestone marker, placed on April 15, 1791. In 1829, the mansion became departing President John Quincy Adams' home. After its conversion to a public park, Union troops encamped on the grounds during the Civil War.

The U.S. government purchased the grounds in 1910. Landscape architects George Burnap and Horace Peaslee planned an Italian style garden. The structures made revolutionary use of concrete aggregate as a building material.

For more information about Meridian Hill Park, visit the History and Culture Page.

Notable Features

The Lower Plaza includes the following features:

  • The thirteen basin cascading fountain is one of the longest in North America.

  • Below the cascading fountain is a reflecting pool.
  • James Buchanan Memorial 
  • The Noyes Armillary Sphere was a prominent feature in the lower plaza of the park. It was damaged in the 1960s and later disappeared. The National Park Service is working to have it replaced.
  • Dante statue

Upper Level plaza features include:

  • The Joan of Arc Statue is the only equestrian statue of a woman in Washington, DC.
  • Serenity

Hours:

Meridian Hill Park is open until 9PM in the winter and midnight in the summer.

Accessibility:

The lower level of the park features accessible paths from the corner of 16th St. NW and Florida Ave. NW / W St. NW continuing east to the plaza at the President James Buchanan Memorial.

The upper level of Meridian Hill Park's paths are made from an aggregate concrete. It can be bumpy and rough in places. Due to terracing and stairs, several of the entrances from the 16th street side are not wheelchair accessible.

For more, visit Rock Creek Park Accessibility.
passportStampLocationDescription: The passport stamp for Meridian Hill park is located at the Rock Creek Park Nature Center and Planetarium

passportStampImages.title: Rock Creek Park- Meridian Hill

title: Milkhouse Ford
listingDescription: This historic ford is still visible though no longer used.

images.altText: An embankment next to a river surrounded by woods.
images.title: Milkhouse Ford
images.caption: Milkhouse Ford

bodyText:
Milkhouse Ford had long been used as a place for wagons and horses to traverse Rock Creek. First paved in 1904, people used to drive through the creek—a major thoroughfare at one time—until the 1990s. The ford is still used by equestrians when conditions permit.

For health and safety reasons, swimming and wading in Rock Creek is prohibited.

title: Montrose Park
listingDescription: Montrose Park is a 16-acre park located on the heights overlooking Georgetown in northwest Washington, DC.

images.altText: A long trail with trees on the left and shrubs on the right.
images.title: Montrose Park
images.caption: Montrose Park

bodyText:
In 1804, rope-maker Richard Parrott purchased his Washington, DC, property and developed his estate. Before long, he added a "Ropewalk" for manufacturing rope, a Federal-style mansion, and gardens and orchards. 

Some of the defining features of Montrose Park originated during the period when the property was a prominent estate, between 1804 and 1911: the Ropewalk, Summerhouse, Boxwood Gardens, and several mature canopy trees along the edge of the plateau.

The property was purchased by the United States Government in 1911. The campaign to purchase the land was led by Sarah Louise Rittenhouse who changed public opinion on the idea of a park. The Office of Public Buildings and Grounds (OPBG) assumed the responsibility for transforming the property. Together, OPBG landscape architects George Burnap and Horace Peaslee prepared designs for the park that integrated features from the former estate’s landscape and incorporated new elements for public park use. 

Today, Montrose Park is a sixteen-acre park located on the heights overlooking Georgetown in northwest Washington, DC. An armillary sphere stands as a monument to Sarah Louise Rittenhouse in gratitude of the work she did to see the park established.

The park includes tennis/pickleball courts and a playground.
passportStampLocationDescription: Stamp is located at Old Stone House site. Round stamp. "Montrose and Dumbarton Oaks Parks" across top of circle, Date across diameter, Washington, DC across bottom of circle.

title: Montrose Park Playground
listingDescription: Montrose Park playground is located in Montrose Park off of R Street NW in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, DC.

images.altText: A jungle gym and play ground with large monkey bars.
images.title: Montrose Park Playground
images.caption: Montrose Park Playground

bodyText: Montrose Park is located off of R Street NW in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, DC. This playground has several sets of swings and a fenced in area with slides and other equipment for children. Benches surround the low fence for people to sit on and monitor the activiy of the children.

title: Mount Zion and Female Union Band Cemeteries
listingDescription: Historic African American Cemeteries with interments dating back to 1809

images.altText: A plain brick wall with a brown metal door
images.title: Burial Vault at Mount Zion Cemetery
images.caption: Vault at Mount Zion Cemetery is rumored to have been used as a stop on the Underground Railroad.

bodyText:
The Mount Zion Cemetery dates back to 1808 when it was the Old Methodist Episcopal burying ground, purchased by Dumbarton Street M.E. Church. The church’s congregation at that time was 50% black and was a mix of both freed and enslaved individuals. By 1816, black members of the church separated and created Mount Zion Methodist church. They took over the burying ground from Dumbarton Street M.E in 1879.

In 1842 a group of free black women created a society—the Female Union Band Society—that pledged to care for one another “in sickness and in death”. They had an adjoining plot of land to the Old Methodist Burying ground.

The two cemetery plots have collectively known as Mount Zion Cemetery.

In the beginning at the twentieth century, many of the families with connections to the burial were forced from the area. Headstones toppled over. Grass grew tall and wild. Trash littered the grounds. In the 1960’s developers saw an opportunity to build town homes and apartments here. While some people saw an opportunity to profit from the sale of the land, others saw a painful loss of their collective community history. They saw the loss of a vital chapter---the path to freedom. Just beneath the hill, there is a vault that has long been believed to be a stop on the Underground Railroad. In 1976 volunteers from the Afro-American Bicentennial Corporation cleared away the tall grass, the garbage and cleaned up the cemetery. They petitioned for it to be protected—and won. 

Today the cemetery is managed by The Mt. Zion / Female Union Band Historic Memorial Park, Inc. For more information and a tour of the cemetery visit their website at https://www.mtzion-fubs.org/
managedByOrg: The Mt. Zion / Female Union Band Historic Memorial Park, Inc.

quickFacts.value: National Register of Historic Places  Designated a UNESCO Slave Route Project site of memory

title: Muhlenberg Park
listingDescription: John Peter Gabriel Muhlenberg (1746-1907) was a clergyman, soldier, and statesman best known for his involvement in the American Revolution.

images.altText: A statue of a man on top of a stone monument.
images.title: Muhlenberg Park
images.caption: Muhlenberg Park

bodyText:
John Peter Gabriel Muhlenberg (1746-1807) was a clergyman, soldier, and statesman best known for his involvement in the American Revolution.
Muhlenberg fought in many major battles of the American Revolution and retired from the Army as a General. He had been a pastor when the war began, serving both Lutheran and Episcopal congregations. When he decided to become a soldier, he told his parishioners: "in the language of Holy Writ there is a time for all things... there is a time to pray and a time to fight... and that time has now come." Three hundred men from his congregations joined the Army.


Cost: $59, 430
Dedicated: October 26, 1980
Sculptor: Caroline Muhlenberg Hufford
Architect: John F. Harbeson

Memorial Description

The memorial consists of a bronze bust on a limestone pedestal located in a plaza surrounded by a low wall on which are bronze plaques highlighting the three phases of Muhlenberg's career: soldier, clergyman and statesman. 

Inscriptions

pedestal
John Peter/ Gabriel / Muhlenberg / 1746-1807

(star here)
Serving / His Church / His Country / His State 

Wall, front
In Gratitude / to / John F. Harbeson. FAIA 

Architect
A listing of the principal donors to the memorial is given in the south side entrance to the Narthex of St. Paul's Lutheran Church

Wall, plaque
STATESMAN
Returned from military service to Woodstock, Virginia 1783
Received land grant of 11,662 acres in Ohio River Valley
"In Consideration of Seven Years Service as Brigadier General in the Virginia Continental Line"
Founder - Member of the Society of the Cincinnati
Elected Vice President of Pennsylvania 1787
Elected to First National House of Representatives 1788
Re-elected Third Congress 1791-1795, Sixth Congress 1799-1801
Elected to United States Senate 1801
Served as Collector of Customs, Port of Philadelphia 1801-1807
Died October 1, 1807 at Age 61

Wall, plaque
SOLDIER
Commissioned Colonel of Virginia Militia 1775
Commanded Eighth Virginia Regiment
Which Became the "German Regiment" of the Continental Army
Fought at Charleston and Philadelphia
Promoted to Brigadier General 1777
Wintered with his Troops at Valley Forge 1777-1778
Fought at Brandywine, Germantown, Monmouth and Stony Point
Member, Royal Arch Masonic Lodge, Philadelphia 1779
Named Commander of All Forces in Virginia 1780
Fought at Portsmouth and Yorktown
Promoted to Major General 1783
Retired November 3, 1783

Wall, plaque
CLERGYMAN
John Peter Gabriel Muhlenberg
Born at Trappe, Pennsylvania October 1, 1746
Eldest Son of Anna and Henry Melchior Muhlenberg
Attended University of Halle Germany 1763
Ordained Lutheran Minister 1768
Pastor Lutheran Churches New Jersey
Married to Anna Meyer 1770
Ordained Episcopal Minister 1772
Pastor Lutheran and Episcopal Churches Woodstock, VA 1772
Preached His "Time to Pray, Time to Fight" Sermon 1776
And Recruited a Regiment from Virginia
He was the "Fighting Parson of the American Revolution"
audioDescription:
(381 words)
Muhlenberg Park is located in a park bounded by Connecticut Avenue, Ellicott Street, and 36th Street NW in Washington's Wakefield neighborhood. Crosswalks at each corner provide pedestrian access.
A twelve-step cement staircase leads up to the memorial plaza from Connecticut Avenue on the east side. A seventy-foot wide, thirty-five-foot deep plaza area stands in front of the statue, with a forty-foot wide, twenty-foot deep grass area in the middle. Two cement benches on each side of the plaza. Each bench is about six feet long and 1.5 feet high.
Just on the west side of the plaza, opposite and facing the steps, is a four-foot tall bronze bust sculpture of Muhlenberg displayed on an about eight-foot high limestone pedestal with a two-step, octagonal cement base and surrounded on three sides by a low 1.5-foot tall concrete wall. Trees line the back and both sides of the low wall.
The sculpture depicts Muhlenberg in civilian dress, with his hands resting on an open Bible before him. The bust faces to the east, toward Connecticut Avenue. Behind him on the next block is St. Paul's Lutheran Church.
The pedestal features a star in the middle of an inscription which reads:
John Peter
Gabriel
Muhlenberg
1746-1807
(star here)
Serving
His Church
His Country
His State
Along the front face of the wall, on its right end, is an inscription that reads:
In Gratitude
to
John F. Harbeson. FAIA
Architect
On top of the wall are three plaques that list events in Muhlenberg's life as a statesman, clergyman, and soldier.
Along the front face of the wall, below the above-mentioned plaques, and directly behind the statue, is an inscription that reads:
A listing of the principal donors to the memorial is given in the south side entrance to the Narthex of St. Paul's Lutheran Church
The pedestal is carved along the front top to resemble the molding along the top of a pulpit and features carvings on three sides. When facing the statue, on the left side is an image of a cross laid over an olive branch and the years, 1768-1776 inscribed below it. The back features an image of a saber over an olive branch and the years, 1774-1783. The right side features an image of a fasces over an olive branch and the years, 1787-1807.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Noyes Armillary Sphere
listingDescription: The Noyes Armillary Sphere by Carl Paul Jennewein was installed at the bottom of the Great Cascade in the 1930s. The sphere was vandalized in the 1960s and later disappeared after it had been removed from Meridian Hill Park for repair.

images.altText: Historic photo of a metal armillary sphere at the base of a cascading waterfall.
images.caption: The original Armillary Sphere, photographed in 1935. (Photo: Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, photograph by Harris & Ewing, LC-DIG-hec-40875)

bodyText:
The Noyes Armillary Sphere by Carl Paul Jennewein was installed at the bottom of the Great Cascade in the 1930s. The sphere was vandalized in the 1960s and later disappeared after it had been removed from Meridian Hill Park for repair. The National Park Service is designing and building a replacement armillary sphere thanks to a generous donation.

An armillary sphere is a map of astronomical objects first used in China approximately 200 B.C.E. Similar spheres were used frequently in Europe during the 7th century to illustrate the Ptolemaic theory of the earth-centered universe. The metal rings of the sphere represent the great circles of the heavens arranged in degrees for angular measurement. An armillary sphere appears on Portugal's flag, referencing the importance of maritime navigation in the nation's history.

Cast in bronze, the Armillary Sphere was designed to be 6 feet 6 inches high, 5 feet 8 inches in diameter and 17.79 feet in circumference, and rested on a pedestal of green Conway granite 3 feet 4 inches high designed by the park architect, Horace Peaslee. To this day, the pedestal exists in its original location within Meridian Hill Park.

The sphere contained the signs of the zodiac in bas-relief on the outside of the circle, along with the hours of the day marked in Roman numerals. A bronze arrow formed the axis of the sphere, and in the center was the figure of the winged "Child Greeting the Sun."

The original sphere was laid out in two equal circles that crossed each other at right angles and bisected one another. One circle represented the Meridian and the other the Equator. The meridian was divided into four 90° areas and the equator into 360°. A third circle, the Ecliptic, passed obliquely through the meridian and equator and intersected the equator at an angle of 23 1/4° at two points known as the equinoxes. Two smaller circles at either end represented the Arctic and Antarctic regions and were placed at a position 23 1/4° from their respective poles. A circle representing the line of longitude was placed at right angles to the meridian but bisecting the sphere east and west and thus passing through the north and south poles. A bronze gnomon shows the Axis of the earth and casts a shadow upon the equatorial band. On the inside of this band are represented the minutes of the day in 5 minute increments and there are star symbols that represent the hours of the night.

If you're an armillary sphere enthusiast, check out the Sarah Rittenhouse Armillary Sphere in Montrose Park.
audioDescription:
(201 words)
The site of the Armillary Sphere is located at the south end of Meridian Hill Park, in the Columbia Heights neighborhood of Washington, DC.
From the intersection of 16th street and W streets, NW, proceed north on the east side 16th street about one hundred feet (30 meters). Turn right into the park entrance and proceed about one hundred feet (30 meters) to the east, 30 feet (9 meters) to the right, and 50 feet (15 meters) to the left, and you will be at the south end of the reflecting pool.
At the center of the plaza area on the south side of the pool is a circular bush, about five feet tall and 12 feet wide. This was the location of the Armillary Sphere. This section of the plaza is semicircular, with the curved side to the south. Along the curved south side of the plaza is a curved concrete balustrade with 6 urns on top of the railing. At each end of the balustrade, it is topped with a 6-foot tall obelisk.
To the north of the sphere site is the reflecting pool, which measures about one hundred twenty feet (36 meters) across and sixty feet (18 meters) long.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Old Stone House
listingDescription: Georgetown's Old Stone House is the oldest building on its original foundation in the District of Columbia, predating the establishment of the District itself.

images.altText: A man stands in front of the Old Stone House circa 1900.
images.caption: The Old Stone House, built in 1766, is the oldest structure on its original foundation in D.C.

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
The Old Stone House is the oldest structure on its original foundation in Washington, D.C. Built in 1766 in the British colony of Maryland, the house was already 59 years old when the British invaded Washington, D.C. in 1814. Although it is preserved for its architecture today, it was originally preserved through a case of mistaken identity and a desire to remember George Washington.

In 1791, George Washington and city planner Pierre L'Enfant were surveying the newly established District of Columbia. L'Enfant's ambitious plan for the city's layout depended on negotiating with local landowners for right of way. During one of these meetings, Washington and L'Enfant stayed in Georgetown's Fountain Inn at 31st and K Streets. The inn was better known to locals as Suter's Tavern, after its owner John Suter. 

Over on Bridge Street (now M Street), John Suter's son, John, Jr., ran a clock shop in today's Old Stone House. As the years passed, local memory conflated the two buildings associated with the two John Suters. Thus, the desire to honor and remember George Washington's 1791 visit combined with a fuzzy memory led to the Old Stone House's preservation while so much changed around it.

The house was the site of a car dealership when the federal government purchased the property in 1953. The National Park Service opened the house to the public in 1960. Today, the house is a rare example of pre-Revolutionary architecture. Among the House's furnishings, you may find a clock built by one-time owner John Suter, Jr.

Hours:

Open daily (ground floor only), with holiday hours from 11:00 a.m.-7:00 p.m.

title: Peirce Barn
listingDescription: Peirce Barn is one of the outbuildings that used to be part of the Peirce farm. Today the barn is used as an educational space.

images.altText: A large barn surrounded by trees.
images.title: Peirce Barn
images.caption: Peirce Barn

bodyText:
The Peirce Family settled in Montgomery County, Maryland shortly after the American Revolution. The land purchased by Isaac Peirce would soon become part of the land selected to become the District of Columbia and the new capital of the United States.  

The Peirce-Shoemaker farm--also known as Cloverdale--consisted of many buildings. The National Park Service manages the Mill, Barn and Springhouse.

For many years, Peirce Barn was known as the Art Barn.  Associates of Artists Equity operated a gallery and classes out of the structure.  

Today Peirce Barn is a space used by the Park Service to conduct educational programs as well as interpret the history of mills and industry in the Rock Creek Valley. There is a restroom available towards the back of the barn.

Peirce Barn hours vary.
audioDescription:
(289 words)
Peirce Barn is located at the southeast corner of Tilden street NW and Shoemaker street NW, about four hundred fifty feet (four hundred ten meters) north from the intersection of Tilden street and Beach Drive in Rock Creek Park.
A twenty-foot-wide cement pathway leads about twenty-five feet (seven meters) to the barn from Tilden street. Shoemaker street ends along the left side of the barn, where there is handicap parking and a bicycle rack on the sidewalk. Shoemaker street then bends around to the left and returns to Tilden street.
The barn is a three-story building approximately twenty-six feet wide and thirty-five feet long and is constructed of blue granite. The white front wall of the barn is made of wood boards. The rear wall contains a single white wooden window on each of the three levels. The right-side wall facing Rock Creek contains four irregularly spaced white wooden windows, two on each of the first two floors. The left-side wall has one window on the first and second level.
On the front side, are three small one by three-foot windows located above the brown wooden double barn door and a two by three-foot window above the brown wooden main entry door on the right side. The entry door features an x pattern on both its upper and lower halves. Three windows are located at the third floor just below the gabled roof. The roof is of gabled wood shingles with a single brick chimney.
Facing the front of the barn, a fifteen-step cement staircase with metal rails on both sides leads from the right to a gravel pathway below that runs north-south between the barn and Peirce Mill, which is about 50 feet (fifteen meters) to the south.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Peirce Barn Restrooms

images.title: Peirce Barn Restrooms

bodyText:
The restroom facilities are located behind Peirce Barn and consist of two unisex facilities.

These facilities will be open independently of Peirce Mill or Peirce Barn.

There is also a water bottle filling station on this building.

title: Peirce Mill
listingDescription: The most successful water-powered gristmill along Rock Creek, Peirce Mill ran commercially from the 1820s until 1897. Restored in the 1930s, 1970s, and the first decade of the 21st century, the mill today serves as an educational site connecting visitors to Rock Creek Park's rich heritage.

images.altText: A three story brick house with several windows. A mill is next to it, and a fence surrounds both the
images.title: Peirce Mill
images.caption: Peirce Mill operated from 1829-1897, and was restored by the National Park Service from 1933-1936.

bodyText:
Peirce Mill was built on Rock Creek in 1829 at the behest of Isaac Peirce. Using the moving water as a power source, the mill ground corn, wheat, and rye. Succeeding generations further developed the mill, sawmill, orchard, and tree nursery. In 1890, an act of Congress incorporated the mill and 350 acres of the property into Rock Creek Park. The mill operated until the turbine's shaft broke in 1897. At the turn of the century, park managers went to work improving the site, improving roads and bridges and adding a new dam that provided a nice aesthetic for picnickers. In the 1920s, the mill was converted into a tea room complete with electric lights. In 1933, New Deal legislation transferred Rock Creek Park to the National Park Service. The National Park Service restored the mill and grounds to their historic layout by 1936. 

The mill is open seasonally. To find out about hours, visit the Operating Hours and Seasons page.

Learn about the history of the mill on the Peirce Mill History page.
audioDescription:
(282 words)
Peirce Mill faces northwest at the northwest corner of Tilden Street and Beach Drive, NW, in Rock Creek Park.
The mill is a rectangular twenty-seven feet wide by forty feet long, and has a gabled roof structure with two and one-half stories in the front sloping down to three and one-half stories in the rear. It is constructed of blue-grey and brown stone granite.
The mill is approached from the northwest by a forty-foot long stone path. The front door is painted brown and is flanked on either side by a double hung window with wooden sashes and sills painted white. The three windows of the second story are of the same design. Two five-foot long log benches are set on either side of the front door.
Moving clockwise from the front, the left side of the building has two windows on each of three levels. Facing the back, a forty-five-foot cement walkway leads northwest from the bike/walkway path to the wooden back door. Three windows line the second and third stories, and windows sit on either side of the back door.
On the remaining side, sets of two windows are on the second and third levels. The first floor has windows on either side of a wooden dutch door. A ground-level door is set at the back corner of the building.
Along the left side of the building to the northeast, a fifty-foot stone water channel runs from the northeast and turns left as it approaches the building, diverting water under a ten-foot tall wooden water wheel connected to the structure. The channel continues southeast and runs another seventy-five feet downhill and under the bike/walkway as it returns water to Rock Creek.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Peirce Springhouse
listingDescription: Caution: There is no safe crossing to approach this feature.

images.altText: A stone house in front of a grassy field with woods in the background
images.title: Peirce Springhouse
images.caption: Peirce Springhouse

bodyText:
Caution: There is no safe crossing to approach this feature.

The Peirce Springhouse is one of several out buildings managed by the National Park Service that made up the Cloverdale or Peirce Plantation.
audioDescription:
(403 words)
The Springhouse is located on Tilden Street, NW, eight hundred feet west and uphill from the intersection with Beach Drive, on a grass median strip between the dual lanes of traffic on Tilden Street.
There is no walkway access to this area, and both directions of Tilden street are heavily trafficked.
The blue granite Springhouse structure has two stories, with a brick chimney and a gabled wood shingled roof. The ground floor has three windows; the upper level has one window at either end of the building. The front and back windows both have wooden brown shutters, and front and back doors are also wooden and painted brown.
The house is about forty-feet long and twenty-feet wide. It sits in the slope of the large incline of Tilden street, and the first floor and front door are sunken into the ground about two feet in the front and four feet in the back.
A stone wall sunken into the ground makes an approximate one-hundred fifty-foot perimeter around the house. A small stone staircase of six steps leads down to the house on the right side.
A thirty-foot tall tree stands just to the left of the house, and a larger fifty-foot tree sits in the back, providing an abundance of shade to the entire area.
A two-foot high wood railing guards the house from the street along the backside.
About fifty feet downhill and to the east is a three by four-foot wayside. The sign is a faded light brown and in poor condition. Titled in large letters across the top and bracketed with a floral pattern on both ends reads: Springhouse. A similar floral pattern with two horizontal lines runs across the bottom of the sign.
Text on the left side below reads:
This small stone structure was built by Isaac Pierce in 1801. Constructed around a natural spring, it was used as a cooling place for cheese, milk and butter products during the hot summer months. It also provided a clean water supply.
A fireplace provided warmth during the winter for cheesemaking and buttermaking activities.
The right side of the sign shows a picture of a small two-story house with two windows on the front upper level. A large tree sits to the left and the house is enclosed by a wood rail fence running in front of the property. Beneath the picture is written:
Pierce Springhouse (1801).
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Picnic Grove 1
listingDescription: Picnic Grove #1 is located near Peirce Mill. It can be reserved from May through October and has a brick pavilion with a fireplace and restrooms attached. Maximum capacity at this site is 75 people.

images.altText: A grassy area with pavilion, picnic tables and several trails. It is shadowed by tall trees.
images.title: Picnic Grove 1
images.caption: Picnic Grove 1 has access to bathrooms, a large grassy area and several picnic tables

bodyText:
Location Description

Picnic Grove #1 has a single story brick pavilion with a fire place. The ground slopes away from the picnic pavilion towards the creek. Between the pavilion and the creek there is a paved multi-use hiking and biking trail. The trail goes under the Tilden Street bridge to the north and over a the creek on a foot bridge to the south.  Access to the Reservation 630 Trail is to the south west of the pavilion and the Western Ridge Trail continues to the south over a small foot bridge.  Several picnic tables are scattered through the open space around the pavilion.

Restrooms

 Yes- Public restrooms are attached at the rear of the pavilion near a gravel path.

Parking

 Yes- There is a medium sized parking area next to the pavilion that can fit 50 cars with street parking available for over-flow.  

Reservations and Permits

This site is reservable in advance from April through November and available on a first-come, first-served basis from December through March.

To make a reservation, please go to the website www.recreation.gov and search for "Rock Creek Group Picnic Areas." You can also make reservations by phone at 1-877-444-6777 (10:00 a.m. - 10:00 p.m. ET).

Reservations are by the half day. A half day is from 9:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. and 3:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. (or dark whichever comes first).

Contact United States Park Police to assist with Picnic Grove issues or if you think someone is occupying your reserved space- 1 (202) 610-7500.

Maximum Capacity

75 people
audioDescription: Picnic Grove #1 has a single story brick pavilion with a fire place. Public restrooms are attached at the rear of the pavilion near a gravel path. There is a medium sized parking area next to the pavilion with street parking available for over-flow. The ground slopes away from the picnic pavilion towards the creek. Between the pavilion and the creek there is a paved multi-use hiking and biking trail. The trail goes under the Tilden Street bridge to the north and over a the creek on a foot bridge to the south. Access to the Melvin Hazen Trail is to the South West of the pavilion and the Western Ridge Trail continues to the south over a small foot bridge. Several picnic tables are scattered through the open space around the pavilion.

title: Picnic Grove 10
listingDescription: Picnic Grove 10 has a maximum capacity of 75 people and is one of the many sites in Rock Creek Park that can be reserved between May and October. It has several picnic areas and is the northernmost picnic area in the park. Beach Drive NW is closed north of Picnic Grove 10 on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays.

images.altText: Four picnic benches in the woods.
images.title: Picnic Grove 10
images.caption: Picnic Grove 10

bodyText:
Location Description

Picnic Grove 10 is located on Beach Drive NW. It is accessible by vehicle and has a medium sized parking lot associated with it. Beach Drive NW is closed north of Picnic Grove 10 on Saturdays, Sundays, and Holidays. The picnic area is a narrow strip of land between the road and the creek. There are several picnic tables scattered among the trees and there is a stone chimney or grill as well. 

Restrooms

Yes- The restrooms are across from Picnic Grove 10 and are open seasonally. Check the restroom page to see if they are in season.

Parking

Yes- There is a medium sized parking area next to the picnic area.

Reservations and Permits

This site is reservable in advance from April through November and available on a first-come, first-served basis from December through March.

To make a reservation, please go to the website www.recreation.gov and search for "Rock Creek Group Picnic Areas." You can also make reservations by phone at 1-877-444-6777 (10:00 a.m. - 10:00 p.m. ET).

Reservations are by the half day. A half day is from 9:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. and 3:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. (or dark whichever comes first).

Contact United States Park Police to assist with Picnic Grove issues or if you think someone is occupying your reserved space- 1 (202) 610-7505.

Maximum Capacity

75 people
audioDescription: Picnic Grove 10 is located on Beach Drive NW. The road is closed to the north of the site. There are several picnic tables scattered in the narrow green space between parking area, road and creek. Tall trees provide ample shade. An historic stone chimney sits close to the creek.

There is an open, grassy area next to the pavilion but the site is otherwise surrounded by trees. On the opposite side of the parking area from the picnic pavilion there is a grassy area. An un-mowed meadow sits next to the mowed area. The Western Ridge Trail crosses through this picnic area.

Restrooms

No. The closest public restrooms are located within the Rock Creek Park Nature Center and Planetarium. They are only open during operating hours of the Nature Center.

Parking

Yes- There is a large parking area next to the picnic area.

Reservations and Permits

To make a reservation, please go to the website www.recreation.gov and search for "Rock Creek Group Picnic Areas." You can also make reservations by phone at 1-877-444-6777 (10:00 a.m. - 10:00 p.m. ET).

Contact United States Park Police to assist with Picnic Grove issues or if you think someone is occupying your reserved space- 1 (202) 610-7505.

Maximum Capacity

75 people

Restrooms: No. The closest public restrooms are located within the Rock Creek Park Nature Center and Planetarium. They are only open during operating hours of the Nature Center.

Parking: Yes- The picnic area is accessed by a small pull out that can fit two or three vehicles. Parking is only permitted in the pull out. No parking is allowed on the shoulders of the road or in the grass.

Reservations and Permits: This is a first-come, first-served picnic area and is limited to no more than 25 people.
audioDescription: Picnic Grove 16 is a small picnic area on a slight hill. The area is surrounded by trees on three sides and the road on the fourth. There is a single picnic table and a small stone fire pit in the top left corner of the area. The parking area is small and can only fit two or three cars.

title: Picnic Grove 2
listingDescription: Picnic Grove 2 is split into north and south sections on opposite sides of the creek. Both sections have sidewalks or multi-use trails that provide safe access to Peirce Mill. Maximum capacity is limited to 25 people per section of the picnic area.

images.altText: A stone grill and picnic table next to the creek
images.title: Picnic Grove 2 south
images.caption: Picnic Grove 2 south

bodyText:
Location Description: Picnic Grove 2 is a split area located along Beach Drive NW near Peirce Mill.

Picnic Grove 2 south is located opposite Peirce Mill at the intersection of Tilden Street NW and Beach Drive NW. There is a medium sized parking area with informational signs about the fish ladder that runs around the dam near the parking area. A sidewalk leads from the southern edge of the parking area across the Tilden Street Bridge towards Peirce Mill. To the north, there are several picnic tables and one historic grill. 

Picnic Grove 2 north is located near the intersection of Broad Branch Road NW and Beach Drive NW. It is on the opposite side of the creek from Picnic Grove 2 south but the same side as Peirce Mill. Picnic Grove 2 north is not improved and has no tables near it.

Restrooms: No- The closest restroom facilities are located behind Peirce Barn or at Picnic Grove 1.

Parking: Yes.

Picnic Grove 2 south has a medium sized parking area. 

In Picnic Grove 2 north, parking is only available on one side of the space as the other side is the thru-way for cyclists and pedestrians accessing the multi-use trail that goes to Peirce Mill.

Reservations and Permits: Both sides of Picnic Grove 2 are available on a year-round, first-come, first-served basis. Each side has a maximum capacity of 25 people.

For information on special use permits or group permits visit our Permits and Reservations page.
audioDescription: Picnic Grove 2 is split into north and south sections. The southern section is accessible from Beach Drive NW near the intersection of Tilden Street NW and has picnic tables, an historic grill and a medium sized parking area. An accessible sidewalk roughly five feet wide allows for views of the scenic Peirce Mill Dam and allows visitors to safely cross the Tilden Street Bridge on a protected sidewalk towards Peirce Mill. The northern section of picnic area 02 is accessible from Broad Branch Road NW and has a smaller parking area. There are no improvements in the Northern section--no picnic tables or grills are available on the west side of the creek. A partially paved multi-use trail leads from the parking area towards Peirce Mill and Barn where there are picnic tables and restroom facilities.
