title: Picnic Grove 24
listingDescription: Picnic Grove 24 can be reserved from May through October and is located near the Rock Creek Park Tennis Center and Carter Barron Amphitheater. Maximum capacity in this picnic grove is limited to 75 people. There is a playground and restrooms at this location.

images.title: Picnic Grove 24

bodyText:
Location Description

Picnic Grove 24 is located across from the Rock Creek Park Tennis Center. The area is open and flat and has a picnic pavilion, a playground and restroom facilities. The picnic grove shares a parking lot with the Rock Creek Park Tennis Center.

Restrooms

Yes- Public restrooms are located in this picnic area.

Parking

Yes- This picnic area shares a large parking lot with the Rock Creek Tennis Center and Carter Barron Amphitheatre.


Reservations and Permits

This site is reservable in advance from April through November and available on a first-come, first-served basis from December through March.

To make a reservation, please go to the website www.recreation.gov and search for "Rock Creek Group Picnic Areas." You can also make reservations by phone at 1-877-444-6777 (10:00 a.m. - 10:00 p.m. ET).

Reservations are by the half day. A half day is from 9:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. and 3:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. (or dark whichever comes first).

Contact United States Park Police to assist with Picnic Grove issues or if you think someone is occupying your reserved space- 1 (202) 610-7505.

Maximum Capacity

75 people

The location sits just below the level of the road and has a few picnic tables scattered through the narrow space between the road and the creek. The area is prone to flooding after heavy rains and can be sandy or muddy. 

Restrooms: No- The closest restrooms are located at Picnic Grove 6.

Parking: No. There is no parking associated with this site as it is reserved for US Park Police vehicles. This is a walk-in only site.

Reservations and Permits: This is a first-come, first-served picnic area and is limited to no more than 25 people.
audioDescription: Picnic Grove 5 is located on Beach Drive NW close to the intersection with Joyce Road NW. It is directly across from the US Park Police Headquarters District 3 Substation. The location sits just below the level of the road and has a few picnic tables scattered through the narrow space between the road and the creek. The area is prone to flooding after heavy rains and can be sandy or muddy. The picnic area is located behind a closed gate when Beach Drive is closed to vehicular traffic on Saturdays, Sundays and Holidays.

title: Picnic Grove 6
listingDescription: Picnic Grove 6 can be reserved from May through October. It is close to the intersection of Beach Drive NW and Joyce Road NW. This picnic area has a large parking lot, a picnic pavilion, and access to restrooms. Maximum capacity of this site is limited to 75 people.

images.altText: Four picnic benches in a wooded area.
images.title: Picnic Grove 6
images.caption: Picnic Grove 6

bodyText:
Location Description

Picnic Grove 6 is located along Beach Drive NW north of the intersection with Joyce Rd. NW. There is a single story brick pavilion that can be reserved. The ground is relatively flat with many trees scattered throughout the area. Other picnic tables are scattered along the banks of the creek. These can not be moved. At the far side of the picnic area is the historic Joaquin Miller Cabin. Only the exterior of the cabin is accessible. A narrow, paved trail runs past the parking area and along the road-side edge of the picnic area. The paved pathway provides a safe and accessible way for cyclists and pedestrians to access Beach Drive to the south or to go north towards Milk House Ford.

Restrooms

Yes- Public restrooms are located to the north of the picnic area and across Beach Drive.

Parking

Yes- There is a large parking area that is available for all visitors. It can not be blocked off or reserved.  

Reservations and Permits

This site (meaning the picnic pavilion) is reservable in advance from April through November and available on a first-come, first-served basis from December through March.


To make a reservation, please go to the website www.recreation.gov and search for "Rock Creek Group Picnic Areas." You can also make reservations by phone at 1-877-444-6777 (10:00 a.m. - 10:00 p.m. ET).

Reservations are by the half day. A half day is from 9:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. and 3:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. (or dark whichever comes first).

Contact United States Park Police to assist with Picnic Grove issues or if you think someone is occupying your reserved space- 1 (202) 610-7505.

Maximum Capacity

75 people

title: Poplar Alley

images.altText: A narrow alley way between two rows of houses
images.title: Poplar Alley
images.caption: Poplar Alley in Georgetown

bodyText:
This street, and many small alleyways like it, had their own communities. While some were rough around the edges, others were vibrant, loving spaces. The Alley Dwelling Act forced change. What was on the surface a way to ‘clean up’ the more worse for wear areas of Georgetown (and the City of Washington), in reality was a way to force African Americans from their homes.
Many of these structures were built in the early 1800s by affluent Georgetown residents for their enslaved African American and poor white staff members. Eventually, families were able to purchase the homes. Many owned several structures and would rent rooms out. The Alley Dwelling Act put an end to leasing rooms and demanded that these become single family homes. Property values were assessed and though a family may have owned a home for generations, the current generation could not afford the property taxes that were newly increased and levied against them. Many of the homes, without electricity, heat, or indoor plumbing were deemed “unsafe for human habitation” and were set to be demolished. However, instead of demolishing these homes, many of them were upgraded, flipped, and then sold to “New Dealers” coming to town to work for the newly expanded government. The Alley Dwelling Act was the final nail in the coffin of Herring Hill.

Poplar Alley is lined with privately owned residences. Please respect the privacy of the neighbors.

title: Pulpit Rock
listingDescription: Popular with President Theodore Roosevelt, Pulpit Rock is a rocky outcropping along Rock Creek.

images.altText: A rocky embankment next to a river.
images.title: Pulpit Rock
images.caption: Pulpit Rock

bodyText: Pulpit Rock is a bluff that overlooks Rock Creek. The narrow trail and rocky height makes it a popular hiking destination. The Theodore Roosevelt spur trail will take hikers to the top.

title: Rapids Bridge
listingDescription: Rapids Bridge crosses Rock Creek and provides an overlook of a particularly rocky section of the creek between one of the bridle trails and Beach Drive.

images.altText: A bridge over a rocky river
images.title: Rapids Bridge
images.caption: Rapids Bridge

bodyText: Rapids bridge is a narrow foot bridge that crosses Rock Creek. It joins Beach Drive and one of the bridle trails in the park.

title: Reflecting Pool
listingDescription: The Reflecting Pool at Meridian Hill Park stretches across the bottom of the plaza below the cascading fountain. The reflecting pool is drained for repairs.

images.altText: People lounge around the edge of the reflecting pool and fountains in Meridian Hill Park
images.title: Meridian Hill Reflecting Pool
images.caption: People lounge around the edge of the reflecting pool and fountains in Meridian Hill Park

bodyText: Currently drained for restoration work
audioDescription:
(245 words)
The Reflecting Pool sits at the south end lower level of Meridian Hill Park, in the Columbia Heights neighborhood of Washington, DC. The park is bordered by 15th, 16th, W, and Euclid streets NW, and sits on a prominent hill one and one-half miles (2.5 kilometers) north of the White House.
From the intersection of 16th and W streets, NW, proceed north on the east side of 16th Street about one hundred feet (30 meters). Turn right into the park entrance and proceed about one hundred feet (30 meters) to the east and you will be at the south end of the Reflecting Pool. The pool sits in the middle of a larger plaza. On the far east side of this plaza lower level is the James Buchanan Memorial.
The pool measures about one hundred twenty feet (36 meters) across and sixty feet (18 meters) long. A 1.5 foot high ledge lines the pool and provides a one-foot top-side space for sitting. Fountains shoot water up about two feet from the pool's four corners.
Beyond the pool to the north are the cascade waterfalls, a cement structure of thirteen waterfall steps. Water flows down the steps and into a pool basin below.
South of the Reflecting Pool, the plaza projects to the south in a semi-circular area with a three-foot-tall balustraded cement wall on the south edge. A large bush in the middle of this semicircular area marks the former site of the armillary sphere.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Reservation 630
listingDescription: Reservation 630 is a section of Rock Creek Park that runs from the Creek near Picnic Grove #1 to Reno Road NW.

images.altText: A trail marker sign in front of a trail surrounded by woods
images.title: Reservation 630
images.caption: Reservation 630

bodyText:
Reservation 630 covers an area of land that extends from Rock Creek close to Picnic Grove #1 and follows an un-named tributary to the west all the way to Reno Road NW. It is bisected by Connecticut Avenue NW. West of Connecticut Ave. NW the park is bound to the north by Tilden Street NW and Sedgewick Street NW and on the south by Rodman Street NW. To the east of Connecticut Avenue NW the park land is bound by no roads but touches to the backs of several properties running along Tilden Street NW to the north and Quebec Street NW.

Trail head access is available at:

Tilden Street NW near 34th Street NW
Rodman Street NW near 34th Street NW
Connecticut Avenue NW (between Sedgewick Street NW and Quebec Street NW)
Picnic Grove #1 near the Western Ridge Trail

The park is also home to the Reservation 630 Community Garden.
audioDescription: Reservation 630 is an extension of Rock Creek Park that follows an unnamed tributary for Rock Creek. It runs from 34th Street NW east to the creek.

title: Riley Spring Bridge
listingDescription: Riley Spring Bridge is one of the many footbridges crossing Rock Creek

images.altText: A bridge over a river surrounded by trees.
images.title: Riley Spring Bridge
images.caption: Riley Spring Bridge

bodyText: Riley Spring Bridge crosses Rock Creek. The bridge spans the creek with the Valley Trail on one side and Beach Drive on the other.

title: Robert Emmet Memorial
listingDescription: The standing figure of Robert Emmett, Irish patriot and an early leader in the cause for Irish Independence, was presented to the United States in 1916. The statue, dedicated April 22, 1966, is on indefinite loan from the Smithsonian Institution.

images.altText: A large bronze statue on top of a stone monument in a grassy plaza
images.title: Robert Emmett Memorial
images.caption: Robert Emmett Memorial

bodyText:
The standing figure of Robert Emmet, Irish patriot and an early leader in the cause for Irish Independence, was presented to the United States in 1916. The statue, dedicated April 22, 1966, is on indefinite loan from the Smithsonian Institution.

Dedicated: April 22, 1966
Sculptor: Jerome Conner

Inscriptions

Base
ROBERT EMMET
IRISH PATRIOT
1778-1803
Lidia-saon-eine
Center paver
The Emmet Statue Committee
Hon. Victor J. Dowling, Chairman
Presented this statue to the Smithsonian Institution as a gift to the American people on June 28, 1917 in the presence of President Woodrow Wilson.
(a clover leaf is inscribed here) Erected on this site on April 22, 1966 in recognition of the fiftieth anniversary of the proclamation of Irish Independence
Pedestal, back
I wish to procure for my country the guarantee which Washington procured for America.
I have parted from everything that was dear to me in this life for my country's cause.
When my country takes her place among the nations of the Earth, then, and not till then let my epitaph be written.
Extracts from Emmet's speech from the dock September 19, 1803
audioDescription:
(307 words)
The Robert Emmett Memorial sits in a small triangular park along Massachusetts Avenue, NW, and is bordered by S street, NW to the north and 24th street to the east. There are crosswalks at each corner, but the only sidewalk is on the Massachusetts Avenue side. Massachusetts frequently carries heavy traffic.
The triangle is a grassy patch of land and the memorial sits about thirty feet (9 meters) from the 24th and Massachusetts Avenue intersection, near the center of the triangle. From the intersection of Massachusetts and 24th, walk about thirty feet (9 meters) northwest along Massachusetts. On the right, a path of three-foot wide asphalt circles lead to the statue. There are bushes on either side of the path.
On the right, just before reaching the pathway to the statue, a three by four-foot wayside sits about ten feet from the sidewalk.
Proceeding up the path to the statue, three-foot diameter asphalt pavers lead to and encircle the Emmett statue. An eight-foot long curved stone bench is on the right of the path, just beyond the wayside but before reaching the statue.
The seven-foot tall bronze statue sits on a five-foot high pink stone pedestal, surrounded by circular stone pavers and encircled with two to four foot high bushes and shrubs as well as a few trees.
A three stone wide cobblestone border runs along the base of the statue. Inscribed on the front pedestal panel is text that reads:
ROBERT EMMETT
IRISH PATRIOT
1778-1803
A faded image that appears to be a design of a harp sits below, and beneath is an inscription that reads:
Lidia-saon-eine
Emmett stands proudly, looking slightly upward and wearing a coat with long tail and knickers. His right arm is outstretched, and right hand is held open. His weight is on his back-left leg and his right foot points forward.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Rock Creek Park

images.altText: Black and white of stone bridge over water with trees on both sides, one hanging over bridge
images.title: Rock Creek Park
images.caption: Rock Creek Park

relatedParks.fullName: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Frederick Law Olmsted

bodyText:
In 1886, Olmsted Sr. warned that “the charmingly wooded glen of Rock Creek [was] in private hands, subject any day to be laid waste”. Throughout his career, Olmsted fought hard to warn anyone who would listen of the dangers that lay in keeping such beautiful land private.

It wasn’t until Olmsted Jr. was chosen to be part of the McMillan commission, in charge of developing both the core and park system of Washington, D.C., that Rock Creek Park would get its deserved attention.

Once on the commission, Olmsted Jr. encouraged his colleagues to endorse the acquisition of land for new public parks and scenic drives throughout the city, including the preservation of Rock Creek Valley in its entirety.

By 1918, Olmsted Jr. and his brother John were busy on the plan for Rock Creek Park. They proposed dividing the landscape into six distinct areas that remain today. The topographical and psychological backbone of the park, their report stated, would be the area along the banks of the creek and its tributaries. This “Valley Section”, as it was described, would be preserved in its natural state, with only the addition of scattered picnic spots.

Rock Creek Park’s “woodland” would consist of the western hills and plateaus, contained in the South by Military Road. Olmsted Brothers saw the “woodland” area as a spot for intensive use; their report recommended the installation of hiking paths and numerous picnic groves. Olmsted Brothers even saw an area beyond their “woodland”, designated “wilder woodland”, and it was to be preserved to the highest degree.

title: Rock Creek Park Golf Course
listingDescription: At the Rock Creek Park Golf Course, you will find an 18-hole course defined by hills and narrow fairways. (Please note: The back nine holes are closed until further notice due to playing conditions.)

images.altText: A golf course surrounded by trees.
images.title: Rock Creek Park Golf Course
images.caption: Rock Creek Park Golf Course

bodyText:
At the Rock Creek Park Golf Course, you will find an 18-hole course, putting greens, snacks and beverages, and a Pro Shop. The course is defined by extreme hills and narrow fairways.

Please note: The back nine holes are closed until further notice due to playing conditions.

Book a tee time and inquire about lessons through PlayDCGolf.

Learn more about the course and its history on the Rock Creek Park website.

quickFacts.value: Rock Creek Park Golf Course was listed in the National Register of Historic Places as a contributing resource to the Rock Creek Park Historic District in 1991.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Rock Creek Park Headquarters & Klingle Mansion
listingDescription: Klingle Mansion was once part of the Linnaean Hill estate in Washington, DC and was owned by members of the Peirce and Klingle families. It is now the location of park headquarters and administration for Rock Creek Park.

images.altText: A large two story stone house
images.title: Rock Creek Park Headquarters & Klingle M
images.caption: Rock Creek Park Headquarters & Klingle Mansion

bodyText:
Klingle Mansion was built in 1823 on land given to Joshua Peirce by his father Isaac Peirce. Joshua established a tree nursery on the land, and called the area Linnaean Hill.

Joshua and his wife Susannah had no children and so passed the estate to their adopted their nephew--Joshua Klingle--after whom it is now named.

Today this space is used as the headquarters of the park. It is not open to the public.
audioDescription: A large stone building with three brick chimneys and nine 6-pane windows. A gravel driveway is in front of the building and it sits on a landscape surrounded by trees in autumn hues.

title: Rock Creek Park Horse Center
listingDescription: The horse stables offer boarding, lessons, and trail rides.

images.altText: A large red and white building
images.title: Rock Creek Park Horse Center
images.caption: Rock Creek Park Horse Center

bodyText:
The Rock Creek Park Horse Center is located between the Rock Creek Park Nature Center and the Rock Creek Park Maintenance Yard. A small parking area is available at the horse center with additional parking available next door at the Rock Creek Park Nature Center.

The horse stables offer boarding, lessons, and trail rides, pony rides, summer camps, and therapeutic riding.

The address of the Horse Center is

5100 Glover Road NW 
Washington, DC 20015


To contact the Rock Creek Park Horse Center visit their website.
audioDescription: The Horse Center occupies several acres of space between the Rock Creek Park Nature Center and the Rock Creek Park Maintenance Yard. To the right is a small one story building where there is office space and a large indoor meeting room. A covered walkway crosses a narrow grassy area and connects to a single story stable building. Beyond the single story stable building (a distance of about 300 feet) is a small, enclosed riding ring with a wooden fence. A large red barn full of mulch and manure is just across from the back wall of the stable. To the left of the Horse Center entrance is a long asphalt area (parking on left side) and a large gray barn on the right. Past the barn is a set of four or five outdoor riding rings with equipment used by the horse center riders. Trails wide enough to accommodate a horse (6-8 feet wide) exit near the outdoor riding ring and the red barn.

title: Rock Creek Park Tennis Center
listingDescription: The Rock Creek Park Tennis Center surrounds William H.G. Fitzgerald Tennis Stadium, home of Citi Open. The facility has 15 hard courts and 10 clay courts. They also offer a variety of services including lessons, court reservations, tournaments, tennis pros, professional racquet stringing, a pro shop, and a snack bar!

images.altText: A large building leading to tennis courts.
images.title: Rock Creek Park Tennis Center
images.caption: Rock Creek Park Tennis Center

bodyText: The Rock Creek Park Tennis Center surrounds William H.G. Fitzgerald Tennis Stadium, home of DC Open. The facility has 15 hard courts and 10 clay courts. They also offer a variety of services including lessons, court reservations, tournaments, tennis pros, professional racquet stringing, a pro shop, and a snack bar!
audioDescription:
(330 words)
The Rock Creek Park Tennis Center is a tennis venue located between 16th Street to the east and Rock Creek Park to the west in the northwest quadrant of Washington, DC.
From the intersection of 16th Street, NW and Morrow Drive, travel west on Morrow Drive about six hundred fifty feet. Turn left and proceed south another six hundred feet. The Rock Creek Park Tennis Center is on the left, to the east.
The Tennis Center houses fifteen hard tennis courts and ten clay courts. Set in the center is the William H.G. FitzGerald Tennis Center. The yellow cement stadium with blue trim is an open, four-sided structure that seats seven thousand five-hundred people.
Written on the west side face of the stadium is:
William H.G. FitzGerald Tennis Center
Written on the southwest face of the stadium is:
The William R. Morris, Jr.
Memorial Stadium
A blue awning below reads in white letters:
Citi Open
Washington's Summer Tradition.
Citi Open is repeated several times on the awning as part of the design.
Set on a cement plaza at the east side of the stadium is an approximately sixteen-foot tall sculpture. Two six-foot tall curved bronze beams are intertwined atop a ten-foot tall black granite monolith. The pedestal tapers from its base and has a flat top. A bronze plaque on the top of the pedestal reads:
SERVE
JOHN SAFER
Inside the stadium is a blue tennis court surrounded by bleacher seating on all four sides. The railings of the stadium are all painted blue.
A parking lot runs along the west side of the stadium and winds around a forest area at the south end. Five tennis courts line the north side of the main stadium and three rows of five other courts are set along the east side. In indoor tennis court facility sits at the south end of the main stadium.
Further north is the Carter Barron Soccer Fields, which run about four hundred feet north and stretch six hundred feet west to 16th street.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Rock Creek Tennis Center baseball diamonds

images.altText: A grassy baseball field
images.title: Tennis Center baseball diamonds
images.caption: Rock Creek Tennis Center baseball diamonds

bodyText: There are four baseball diamonds located near the Rock Creek Park Tennis Center.
audioDescription: Two backstop fences of baseball fields sit at an angle from each other. A tree line and neighborhood homes are in the background.

title: Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway
listingDescription: The Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway is a scenic driving route through Washington, DC. The road has all-way-one-way directional traffic twice a day to help alleviate congestion during the busy Washington area commute.

images.altText: A four lane road way with a bridge over top.
images.title: Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway
images.caption: Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway

bodyText:
The Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway is a scenic motorway that runs from the Potomac River, north along Rock Creek for a distance of 2 miles, terminating at Beach Drive. 

The Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway is a major commuting thoroughfare in to and out of the city of Washington. Closures are in effect Monday through Friday between Shoreham Drive NW/Beach Drive NW and Virginia Avenue NW.

On weekdays, all traffic is directed southbound towards downtown Washington, DC between 6:45 AM and 9:30 AM.  

In the afternoon, all traffic is directed northbound between 3:45 PM and 6:30 PM.  

There are some holidays when traffic on the parkway is not reversed. Please be aware of and respect all signage, cones, and barricades that will be directing traffic flow.
audioDescription: Cars driving on a scenic motorway that has bridges crossing over it. Trees are on both sides of the roadway.

title: Rolling Meadow Bridge
listingDescription: Rolling Meadow Bridge is one of the bridges that cross Rock Creek

images.altText: A bridge over a rocky river
images.title: Rolling Meadow Bridge
images.caption: Rolling Meadow Bridge

bodyText: Rolling Meadow Bridge is one of the many bridges that span Rock Creek. The concrete foot bridge transports visitors from Beach Drive to the Valley Trail.
audioDescription: A concrete and metal bridge that crosses the creek. The bridge is narrow and long where it crosses the creek. On one side of the bridge is a dirt easement that runs beside Beach Drive. On the other side is the narrow and rugged Valley Trail.

title: Rose Park Tennis Courts

images.altText: Two tennis courts with a net between each side.
images.title: Rose Park Tennis Courts
images.caption: Rose Park Tennis Courts

bodyText:
Two young women of color—sisters—made a name for themselves on this court. Any idea who they were?

It’s not the Williams Sisters. The Peters sisters (Margaret and Roumania) grew up in the little house just there on O Street and often played tennis here in Rose Park. As they got older, their talents on the tennis courts would earn them both scholarships to Tuskegee University where they would hone their skills and terrify opponents. They won 14 American Tennis Association championship titles in the 1940s and 1950s and even played with movie stars.  

The sisters returned to Georgetown and continued to teach tennis in Rose Park. Not until the early 2010s were their accomplishments recognized officially by the US Tennis Association.

Rose Park Tennis Courts are open to the public and are actively used by members of the community.
audioDescription: Three tennis courts side by side. The courts are surrounded by fencing and tall hedges. The courts are located in a neighborhood with homes and trees nearby.
managedByOrg: DC Department of Parks and Recreation

title: Sarah Rittenhouse Armillary Sphere
listingDescription: The memorial to Sarah Louise Rittenhouse (1845-1943) is an armillary sphere on a marble pedestal. She is considered the founder of Montrose Park in Georgetown and is given credit for saving the park area from a housing development planned in the early 1900's. This memorial was a gift from the Georgetown Garden Club and was dedicated in 1956.InscriptionsIn Tribute toSarah Louisa Rittenhouse1845-1942Through Her VisionAnd Perseverance ThisLand BecameMontrose ParkAn etching on th

images.altText: metal astronomical sphere on top of a stone base
images.title: Montrose Park Armillary Sphere
images.caption: Armillary Sphere in Montrose Park

bodyText:
The memorial to Sarah Louise Rittenhouse (1845-1943) is an armillary sphere on a marble pedestal. She is considered the founder of Montrose Park in Georgetown and is given credit for saving the park area from a housing development planned in the early 1900's. This memorial was a gift from the Georgetown Garden Club and was dedicated in 1956.

Dedicated: 1956

Memorial Description

The bronze armillary sphere is no longer on the granite pedestal after it was damaged in 2019. Proposals for replacement are being worked on at this time.


Inscriptions
In Tribute to
Sarah Louisa Rittenhouse
1845-1942
Through Her Vision
And Perseverance This
Land Became
Montrose Park
An etching on the back of the pedestal reads:
Erected by the Georgetown Garden Club
1956
audioDescription:
(244 words)
The Sarah Rittenhouse Armillary Sphere is located in Montrose Park along R Street NW in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, DC.
From the intersection of R Street and Avon Place NW, travel fifty feet (45 meters) west along the north side of R Street. Turn right and proceed up two brick steps into a brick-paved elliptical plaza area. Set in the center surrounded by garden space is a three-foot tall bronze alloy spherical sundial with a one-foot-tall black iron bell-shaped base. The sundial is set atop a four-foot tall square marble pedestal. Etched across the front face of the pedestal reads:
In Tribute to
Sarah Louisa Rittenhouse
1845-1942
Through Her Vision
And Perseverance This
Land Became
Montrose Park
An etching on the back of the pedestal reads:
Erected by the Georgetown Garden Club
1956
The memorial is surrounded by bushes around its base, and the round interior of the plaza has triangular garden areas on all four sides, each ranging from approximately twenty-two to thirty-two feet wide at their outer edges. Twenty-foot long brick pathways lead through the gardens and up to the memorial from all four sides.
The outer plaza has an approximately two-hundred-forty-foot circumference. Two sets of benches are set at east and west sides. Behind the benches are four-foot-tall holly bushes that line the east, west, and south perimeter.
Tennis courts are located about one hundred fifty feet (45 meters) to the northeast and ninety feet (27 meters) to the west.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Sarah Whitby Home Site
listingDescription: Sarah Whitby was an African-American woman who lived with her family in what would become Rock Creek Park.

images.altText: A grassy field with a picnic bench surrounded by trees changing colors in Fall
images.title: Sarah Whitby home site
images.caption: Sarah Whitby home site

bodyText:
The Sarah Whitby home site is an archeological site in Rock Creek Park.  

Sarah Whitby and her family lived along Broad Branch Road NW. Sarah was a former enslaved person who came to Washington, DC with her husband when they were emancipated during or shortly after the American Civil War.  

For more information on Sarah Whitby, read Chapter Two of the three-part series on the Sarah Whitby Site and African American History.
audioDescription:
(210 words)
The Sarah Whitby home site is located on Ridge Road, NW, about 400-feet north of the intersection with Broad Branch Road NW in Rock Creek Park.
The site is an open, about two and one-half acre, manicured grass field that slopes uphill from south to north. Traveling north on Ridge Road, the road rises at an incline and bends around to the right at about 500 feet. The road continues uphill for another 500 feet before making a left-hand turn and rising further into the park.
The field is on your right as you travel north and uphill into the area from the Broad Branch intersection. At about 400 feet from Broad Branch Road, three thirty-foot trees sit along the road to the right. At the base of these trees are two picnic tables and a stone barbeque pit.
A forest surrounds this entire area on the opposite side of the road from the field, and along the west side of the field.
At the bottom of the hill, on the right side as you face north, is a three-foot tall brown sign that reads Closed at Dark. Above on the left of the sign is the number 28, and to the right a white image of a picnic table.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Senator Newlands Memorial
listingDescription: Senator Francis Newlands (1846-1917) of Nevada is most well known for his Newlands Reclamation Act of 1902 which created the Bureau of Reclamation and led to the creation of dams and irrigation projects in the American west. He was also the founder of Chevy Chase, Maryland. The memorial has been a source of controversy as Newlands also argued for the restriction of immigration and voting rights for African Americans.

images.altText: A circular fountain surrounded by benches and grass
images.caption: Senator Newlands Memorial

bodyText:
Senator Francis Newlands (1846-1917) of Nevada is most well known for his Newlands Reclamation Act of 1902 which created the Bureau of Reclamation and led to the creation of dams and irrigation projects in the American west. He was also the founder of Chevy Chase, Maryland. The memorial has been a source of controversy as Newlands also argued for the restriction of immigration and voting rights for African-Americans.

The fountain is in the center of Chevy Chase Circle, which sits on the border between the District of Columbia and Maryland. Newlands was responsible for developing the area as a streetcar suburb in the 1890s.

The fountain was authorized by Congress in 1932. Legislation provided for the design of a fountain and adequate landscaping around the area. Funds were provided by Newlands' widow, Edith McAllister Newlands. The fountain was dedicated in 1938. 

Be sure to visit our Fountains page to learn the operating status of the fountain in Chevy Chase Circle.

Cost: $12,000 donated by Mrs. Newlands with no expense to the United States.

Dedicated: 1938

Designer: Edward Donn, Jr.

Memorial Description:

In the center of Chevy Chase Circle is a sandstone and concrete fountain. The fountain is 60 feet in diameter and throws a two-inch jet of water 30 feet in the air.

Inscriptions:

Pool edge, south
Francis Griffith Newlands
1848-1917
Senator from Nevada
His Statesmanship Held True Regard for the Interests of All Men
Founder of Chevy Chase
This Fountain Erected in 1933 - Authorized by Act of Congress
Plaque
The Chevy Chase Land Company of Montgomery County, Maryland
On the Occasion of its 100th Anniversary
1890-1990
Rededicates this Circle and Restores this Fountain
In Memory of its Founder
Senator Francis G. Newlands
Pool wall, top
Newlands Memorial Fountain
audioDescription:
(491 words)
The Senator Newlands Memorial is located at Chevy Chase Circle, on the border between the Chevy Chase neighborhood of Washington, DC NW and the community of Chevy Chase, Maryland. The circle is intersected by Connecticut Avenue from the north and south, and Western Avenue from the southwest and northeast.
The memorial consists of a large fountain, about one hundred twenty feet in circumference, with water that shoots up twenty feet in a plume from its center into a pool area below. A two-foot tall high cement perimeter wall surrounds the fountain. An eighteen-inch wide stone walkway rings the fountain at a one-step elevation along its base.
Access into the circle is very difficult. Busy traffic around the circle is a constant, though there are two dedicated walkways to access the memorial. Extreme caution should be used in crossing via the walkways into the circle.
A seventy-two-foot long, eight-foot wide stone walkway leads into the fountain area from the street at north, south, east, and west points.
A twenty-foot wide garden area of bushes and flowers rings the outer edge of the circle. Just beyond the bushes, a line of wood benches circles the inner plaza area.
At the south end of the fountain wall, a four by two-foot-tall stone block is inscribed with:
Francis Griffith Newlands
1848-1917
Senator from Nevada
His Statesmanship Held True Regard for the Interests of All Men
Founder of Chevy Chase
This Fountain Erected in 1933 - Authorized by Act of Congress
On the stone plaza floor in front of the inscribed block is a three by two-foot bronze plaque with raised lettering that reads:
The Chevy Chase Land Company of Montgomery County, Maryland
On the Occasion of its 100th Anniversary
1890-1990
Rededicates this Circle and Restores this Fountain
In Memory of its Founder
Senator Francis G. Newlands
Along the top of the fountain wall at its south end is an inscription carved into the wall that reads:
Newlands Memorial Fountain
On the east side of the circle, just outside the bench area, is a five-foot tall, one and a half-foot wide cement boundary stone monolith sitting on a white base. On its southern face is a nine by twelve-inch design of the Maryland flag, featuring a checkerboard and cross design in alternating corners. Beneath is inscribed: Maryland. The opposite, north face has an equal-sized design of a man standing on a pedestal and woman below him to the right. Beneath is inscribed: District of Columbia. The monolith has a ribbed design of horizontal and vertical lines surrounding the emblems, though the pattern appears on all four sides.
An identical five-foot tall cement monolith sits on the west side of the circle, just outside of the bench area. This monolith has a darker tone due to black soot on its surface. Here the order of emblems alternates compared to the monolith on the east, with the District of Columbia emblem on the south, and Maryland on the north.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Serenity Statue
listingDescription: The sculpture was erected as a gift to the American people from Charles Deering in memory of William Henry Scheutze. William Henry Scheutze (1853-1902), a naval officer who graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1873, went on to serve as navigator on the U.S.S. Iowa during the Spanish American War and was active in the U.S. Naval White Squadron in Chicago.

images.altText: A marble statue of a woman sitting in a chair. The statue is surrounded by trees.
images.title: Serenity Statue
images.caption: Serenity Statue

bodyText:
The sculpture was erected as a gift to the American people from Charles Deering in memory of William Henry Scheutze. William Henry Scheutze (1853-1902), a naval officer who graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1873, went on to serve as navigator on the U.S.S. Iowa during the Spanish American War and was active in the U.S. Naval White Squadron in Chicago. The gift was accepted under an Act of Congress (43 Stat. 21) on March 12, 1924.

Cost: The statue cost Charles Deering $4500. It was erected at no cost to the American Public.

Dedicated: July 1925

Sculptor: Jose Clara

Memorial Description

The Serenity statue is a seated figure of a woman made of white carrara marble. It sits on a small granit base. The face of the statue has been damaged. Serenity no longer has a nose.

Inscriptions

SERENITY
IN REMEMBRANCE OF WILLIAM HENRY SCHEUTZE
LIEUTENANT COMMANDER UNITED STATES NAVY
MDCCCLIII-MCMII
audioDescription:
(232 words)
The Serenity Statue is a public artwork located in Meridian Hill Park in Washington, DC. The statue sits on the western edge of the park along a winding pedestrian walkway. The park is bordered by 15th, 16th, W, and Euclid streets NW, and sits on a prominent hill one and one-half miles (2.5 kilometers) due north of the White House.
From the 16th street and Euclid street, NW entrance, turn right and follow the pathway south about three hundred eighty-five feet (117 meters). The statue will be on your left set about 15 feet off the path, among the trees and shrubs that line the walkway. Across the path is a grass slope that runs downhill about twenty feet to the wall of Meridian Hill Park. Trees line the park edge. 16th street can be seen running north-south below.
The seven-foot-tall white marble sculpture sits on a six foot-wide, eight foot-long, foot and a half-high base. The statue is of a woman wearing long, flowing classical robes which are tied at her waist. She has long hair and stares straight forward. She sits on a rocky ledge with her arms casually resting on the rocks behind her. Her left-foot rests on a broken sword and her nose has been noticeably worn away.
The front of the base is inscribed:
SERENITY
IN REMEMBRANCE OF WILLIAM HENRY SCHEUTZE
LIEUTENANT COMMANDER UNITED STATES NAVY
MDCCCLIII-MCMII
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Thompson Boat Center
listingDescription: Boat rentals and lessons on the Potomac River

images.altText: A two story structure with four garage doors on the ground level. Boats are stacked on dock
images.title: Thompson Boat Center
images.caption: Thompson Boat Center on the Potomac River

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Thompson Boat Center sits on the Potomac River near the intersection of the Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway and Virginia Avenue. The boathouse provides rentals of canoes, kayaks and other non-motorized watercraft.  

Information on rentals and lessons are available on the Boating in DC website.

Please note, there is a fee for parking in the parking lot at the Thompson Boat Center.
audioDescription: Thompson Boat Center sits on the Potomac River near the intersection of the Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway and Virginia Avenue. The boathouse sits between the tidal lock for the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal and the Potomac River. The boat dock angles away from the front of the building and leads to edge of the water. Canoes, kayaks and other watercraft are stacked along the docks and in the boat house garages.

title: Trailhead: Black Horse Trail at Beach Drive

images.altText: A dirt path in a forest.
images.title: Black Horse Trail at Beach Drive
images.caption: Trailhead: Black Horse Trail at Beach Drive

bodyText: This trailhead is where the White Horse Trail and Black Horse Trail intersect. It is a popular trail that paralells Rock Creek.

title: Trailhead: Black Horse Trail at Milkhouse Ford
listingDescription: This popular trail in Rock Creek Park connects historic Milkhouse Ford with the White Horse Trail

images.altText: A sandy embankment next to a river on the left and a forest on the right.
images.title: Black Horse Trail at Milkhouse Ford
images.caption: Trailhead: Black Horse Trail at Milkhouse Ford

bodyText: The Black Horse Trail at Milkhouse Ford is a popular trail with both pedestrians and equestrians. The trail is broad and relatively flat and connects Beach Drive and the White Horse Trail.

title: Trailhead: Black Horse Trail junction with White Horse Trail

images.altText: A trail on the side of a forest.
images.title: Black Horse Trail junction
images.caption: Trailhead: Black Horse Trail junction with White Horse Trail

bodyText: The two popular horse trails in the park cross at this point.

title: Trailhead: Cross Trail #5
listingDescription: Cross Trail #5 runs in an east-west direction and is a part of the popular Milkhouse Ford Hike

images.altText: A dirt tail leading into a forest.
images.title: Trailhead: Cross Trail #5
images.caption: Trailhead: Cross Trail #5

bodyText: Cross Trail #5 runs in an east-west direction. This trailhead is located on the east side of Cross Trail #5 and is near the historic Milkhouse Ford. It is part of the park's popular highlighted Milkhouse Ford Hike

title: Trailhead: Cross Trail #6 at Black Horse Trail

images.altText: A trail cuts through trees and up a hill
images.title: Cross Trail #6 and Black Horse Trail
images.caption: Cross Trail #6 as it comes down to intersect with the Black Horse Trail

bodyText: Cross Trail #6 runs between the Rock Creek Park Horse Center and the Black Horse Trail near Rock Creek.

title: Trailhead: Cross Trail #9 at Beach Drive

images.altText: A dirt trail next to a road. The trail leads up on a hill surrounded by trees.
images.title: Trailhead: Cross Trail #9 at Beach Drive
images.caption: Trailhead: Cross Trail #9 at Beach Drive

bodyText: Cross Trail #9 does not have a parking lot associated with it on Beach Drive NW. It is accessible by foot only and is the recommended route to return to the Nature Center on the Boulder Bridge Loop.

title: Trailhead: Fort DeRussy Trail and White Horse Trail
listingDescription: This section of the White Horse Trail takes visitors past historic Fort DeRussy, a part of the Civil War Defenses, as well as being part of the Potomac Heritage National Scenic Trail.

images.altText: Two trails leading to different directions in the woods
images.title: Fort DeRussy Trail and White Horse Trail
images.caption: Trailhead: Fort DeRussy Trail and White Horse Trail

bodyText:
This popular trail is enjoyed by pedestrians and equestrians alike. The wide dirt trail takes park visitors past historic Fort DeRussy and continues down to Rock Creek. 

The trail parallels Military Road NW and Bike Trail #3, which is the paved option for cyclists to navigate safely between Oregon Avenue NW and Beach Drive NW.

Note: Bicyclists are not allowed on dirt trails in Rock Creek Park.

title: Trailhead: Pinehurst Trail
listingDescription: The Pinehurst Trail runs for about 1.5 miles from Beach Drive to the DC/MD border. It follows the Pinehurst Branch Tributary.

images.altText: A dirt trail leading into a green forest. There is a trail sign with three trails described
images.title: Trailhead: Pinehurst Trail
images.caption: Trailhead: Pinehurst Trail

bodyText:
The Pinehurst Trail runs for just under 1.5 miles from the western border between the District of Columbia and Maryland to Beach Drive. The trail follows the Pinehurst Branch, a small tributary of Rock Creek. 

The Pinehurst Trail is blazed with goldenrod colored markings.

title: Trailhead: Valley Trail at Parkside Drive NW

images.altText: A large brown side with white lettering "Rock Creek Park" and the Park Service logo
images.title: Parkside Drive NW Entrance
images.caption: Parkside Drive NW Entrance and access to the Valley Trail

bodyText: This trailhead provides access to the Valley Trail in the North Floodplain area of the park. This trailhead does not have a parking area. Obey all posted signs as the only parking available is on a nearby residential street.

title: Trailhead: Valley Trail at Rapids Bridge

images.altText: A dirt trail leading in to woods
images.title: Trailhead: Valley Trail at Rapids Bridge
images.caption: Trailhead: Valley Trail at Rapids Bridge

bodyText:
This trailhead is accessible by foot and is part of the popular Boulder Bridge Loop. Located close to Rapids Bridge, it requires hikers to cross Beach Drive from the parking pull out near the bridge or from the Black Horse Trail on the opposite side of Rapids Bridge.

Hikers are urged to use caution when crossing Beach Drive to access this section of the trail.

title: Trailhead: Western Ridge Trail at Broadbranch Road NW

images.altText: A brown and white sign next to a trail cutting through the trees
images.title: Trailhead: Western Ridge @ Broadbranch
images.caption: Western Ridge Trail near Broadbranch Road NW

bodyText:
This trailhead is at the intersection of Beach Drive NW and Broad Branch Road NW. The paved hiker/biker trail (Bike Trail #4- Glover Rd South to Beach Drive), Black Horse Trail and White Horse Trail intersect near this trailhead.

The Western Ridge Trail is blazed with green markings and runs from the DC/Maryland border in the north to Bluff Bridge in the southern section of the park.

title: Trailhead: Western Ridge at White Horse Trail

images.altText: A trail in a forest with leaves changing from green to yellow
images.title: Trailhead: Western Ridge at White Horse
images.caption: Trailhead: Western Ridge at White Horse Trail

bodyText:
The Western Ridge Trail is one of the popular trails in Rock Creek Park. It runs in a north-south direction from Boundary Bridge to Bluff Bridge.

This trailhead is located near historic Fort DeRussy and is the juncture between the Black Horse Trail, the Potomac Heritage National Scenic Trail and the Fort DeRussy Trail. It is very close to Bike Trail #1 and Bike Trail #3.

Note: Bicycles are not allowed on the Western Ridge Trail.

title: Trailhead: White Horse Trail
listingDescription: The trailhead, located near the outdoor riding ring of the Rock Creek Park Horse Center is the starting point of many popular loop hikes in the park, including the Rapids Bridge hike and the Boulder Bridge hike.

images.altText: A dirt trail leading in to a forest.
images.title: Trailhead: White Horse Trail
images.caption: Trailhead: White Horse Trail

bodyText:
This trailhead is located near the Rock Creek Park Horse Center's outdoor riding area. To access the trailhead, enter the Horse Center and veer to the left through their small parking area and then pass a large gray barn on the right. The outdoor riding area is straight ahead and surrounded by fencing. 

Circle around the left hand side of the riding arena where you will find the trail head. 

This trail is a bridle trail and is meant for both horse and pedestrian traffic. Pets are allowed on the trail but they must be leashed at all times. 

This trail will bring visitors down to Rock Creek where they can access:
Picnic Grove 22
Joaquin Miller Cabin
Milkhouse Ford
Rapids Bridge
Boulder Bridge
and Beach Drive NW.

This trailhead is the beginning of the Rapids Bridge hike following orange markings and the Boulder Bridge hike following pink markings.
audioDescription: The trailhead is an open flat dirt path that starts in a grassy area and then enters the forest.

title: VI Army Corps Monument
listingDescription: This plaque commemorates the scene where President Abraham Lincoln was under enemy fire during the Battle of Fort Stevens on July 12, 1864. The plaque was dedicated by the Associated Survivors of the Sixth Army Corps on July 11, 1920. The plaque was placed on a boulder denoting the spot where a Federal surgeon was wounded near President Lincoln. The boulder was dedicated in 1911.

images.altText: A plaque commemorating Lincoln at Fort Stevens during the Civil War.
images.title: VI Army Corps Monument
images.caption: VI Army Corps Monument

bodyText:
This plaque commemorates the scene where President Abraham Lincoln was under enemy fire during the Battle of Fort Stevens on July 12, 1864. The boulder was removed from the battlefield near present-day Walter Reed National Medical Center and denotes the spot where President Lincoln stood during the battle. It was dedicated in 1911. The plaque was dedicated by the Associated Survivors of the Sixth Army Corps on July 11, 1920. 

Dedicated: Boulder placed in November 1911. Plaque was dedicated July 12, 1920.

Memorial Description:

A granite boulder with a bronze plaque sits atop the reconstructed ramparts.The plaque shows Abraham Lincoln standing on the rampart during the battle. Standing next to the president is Major General Horatio Wright, commanding Sixth Corps. 

Inscriptions

LINCOLN UNDER FIRE AT FORT STEVENS
July 12, 1864
The image below is a bas-relief of a man in the center with top hat and long suit coat tending to a wounded man on the right falling with his head thrown back. Another man tries to pull the man in top hat away from the left. A man in the lower left corner watches on while holding a staff.
Wreaths with hanging ribbons are etched on either side of the relief.
Beneath the bas-relief is engraved:
ERECTED BY THE ASSOCIATED SURVIVORS
SIXTH ARMY CORPS WASHINGTON D.C.
July 12, 1920.
audioDescription:
(337 words)
Fort Stevens is located in the northern corner of Washington, DC, within the center of a block bordered by 13th Street, NW to the west, Georgia Avenue to the east, Rittenhouse Street to the north, and Quakenbos Street to the south.
The park area rises about thirty feet from street level at the northwest corner of 13th and Rittenhouse Streets to the eastern end where the fort is situated. A flagpole in the center of the hilly field marks the fort location. Lined in front to the north are a wall of grassy bunkers, about four feet tall. One six-foot tall hill to the left has a white wooden double-sided door on its face.
A cement bunker wall with wood-log designed vertical ridges spans about one hundred yards across the top of the hill. The wall stands about five feet tall with seven three-foot wide, three-foot tall openings. Pointed out of two of those openings are sixteen-foot long cannons set on cement platforms and directed out to the north.
About six feet left of the left cannon, sitting on the grass just beyond the cement bunker wall is a stone marker with a bronze plaque set on its face. The stone is about five feet tall, four feet wide, and two feet deep. The plaque measures about one foot high by two feet wide. It features a one-inch raised border and is engraved across the top to read:
LINCOLN UNDER FIRE AT FORT STEVENS
July 12, 1864
The image below is a bas-relief of a man in the center with top hat and long suit coat tending to a wounded man on the right falling with his head thrown back. Another man tries to pull the man in top hat away from the left. A man in the lower left corner watches on while holding a staff.
Wreaths with hanging ribbons are etched on either side of the relief.
Beneath the bas-relief is engraved:
ERECTED BY THE ASSOCIATED SURVIVORS
SIXTH ARMY CORPS WASHINGTON D.C.
July 12, 1920.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Walter Pierce Park

images.altText: A woman walks a dog on a path shaded by colorful autumn trees.
images.title: Walter Pierce Park
images.caption: Walter Pierce Park

bodyText: Walter Pierce Park is a small park partially managed by the District of Columbia Parks and Recreation group and partially by the National Park Service. The National Park Service administers the hill leading down to the creek and the Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway and the section between the city managed portion and the Smithsonian Zoological Park. The acreage is not accessible and is listed as a cemetery.

title: Waterfront Park and Percy Plaza
listingDescription: The central feature of Georgetown Waterfront Park. The fountain is a popular place for people to relax and play in the summer months.

images.altText: A stone plaza by the Potomac River flanked by colorful fall trees.
images.title: Waterfront Park and Percy Plaza
images.caption: Waterfront Park and Percy Plaza

bodyText:
Waterfront Park and Percy Plaza is the central feature of Georgetown Waterfront Park. The plaza is occupied by a large fountain that is operational seasonally where children can play and splash in the running water.

Be sure to visit our Fountains page to learn the operating status of the fountain at Percy Plaza.
audioDescription:
(145 words)
Percy Plaza is located at the east end of the Georgetown Waterfront Park, south of K street NW at the intersection with Wisconsin Avenue in Washington, DC.
The plaza sits between gently rolling hills and shade trees on either side. The space is about one hundred fifty feet wide and runs one hundred twenty feet south to a walkway along the Potomac River.
The centerpiece of the plaza is a high-arching water fountain that forms a one-hundred-foot-wide stream of water. One-foot tall planters line the south side of the path and benches are set along the east and west sides.
The plaza sits north of the Potomac River and provides spectacular views of the lush trees and vegetation on Roosevelt Island across the river to the south, the white rectangular marble building of the Kennedy Center and tip of the Washington Monument to the southeast.
END OF DESCRIPTION
passportStampLocationDescription: Passport Stamp is available at Old Stone House

passportStampImages.altText: Red Circle inscribed with Georgetown Waterfront Park, Washington, DC
passportStampImages.title: Georgetown Waterfront Park Stamp

title: Waterfront Park: Donor recognition
listingDescription: The plaque overlooks the Potomac River and recognizes the donors who made the park possible.

images.altText: An angled plaque lists donors who helped develop the park.
images.title: Waterfront donor recognition plaque
images.caption: Donor recognition plaque

bodyText:
The donor plaque overlooks a set of large terraced steps that lead from the park sidewalk to the water's edge.  

The plaque recognizes donors that made the development of the park possible.
audioDescription:
(316 words)
Located along the north edge of the Potomac River at the east end of Georgetown Waterfront Park in Washington, DC is the Waterfront Park: Donor recognition wayside.
From the Wisconsin avenue and Water street, NW intersection, travel south about one hundred eighty feet (54 meters), pass the water fountain and plaza area on your right, and proceed through to a walkway that runs parallel to the Potomac River. A series of two-foot tall granite pillars with rounded tops are lined along the south edge of the walkway, stretching about twenty feet across. The wayside will be to the right of these as you face the river, set in front of a metal railing, which stands about three feet-tall and runs about one hundred feet to the right.
The three by four-foot metal sign has a black granite surface and is engraved in white lettering to read:
The National Park Service and the Friends of Georgetown Waterfront Park are grateful to all donors, including the major donors listed below, whose generosity helped create this beautiful riverside park for all to enjoy.
The Government of the District of Columbia
Eastbanc/Millennium Partners
Loraine Guyer Percy and U.S.Senator Charles H. Percy
Sharon Percy Rockefeller and U.S. Senator John D. Rockefeller IV
Diane and Norman Bernstein Sachiko Kuno and Ryuji Ueno
The Bernstein Companies Herbert and Patrice Miller
Sally Blumenthal Pepco
Corinne Bronfman Prince Charitable Trusts
Foley & Lardner LLP Ann Satterthwaite
The Georgetown Business Nancy and Nicholas Robert
Improvement District TKF Foundation
Michael and Steven Gewirz, Ann and Bob vom Eigen
Georgetown Jefferson Associates The Owners
Helen and David Kenney of Washington Harbour
Tables and chairs are set along the plaza walkway and benches line the north side of the path. One-foot tall planters line the north side of the path and beyond to the north is a fountain waterpark and plaza area that stretches north to bordering Water street.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Waterfront Park: Labyrinth
listingDescription: Follow the path and relax with the help of this ancient meditative pathway.

images.altText: A paved, spiraling maze pattern on a grass lawn.
images.title: Labyrinth
images.caption: Waterfront Park Labyrinth

bodyText:
Visit the Labyrinth at Georgetown Waterfront Park!

Labyrinths are used in many faiths in many parts of the world as conduits for meditation, prayer and mental health. It is an ancient method that can help decrease the stress in a hectic world. Visitors to Georgetown Waterfront Park are encouraged to visit the labyrinth and take part in traveling this ancient meditative pathway.

Labyrinths and mazes differ since labyrinths have only one path--there are no dead ends in a labyrinth and no way to get lost.

Visitors to the labyrinth are encouraged to follow the tan part of the pathway into the labyrinth. Follow these steps for a mentally calming experience.

Prepare:

Take a moment to relax and reflect. Take deep breaths and slowly step on to the tan pathway.

The Journey In:

Release concerns and quiet the mind, continue to take slow, deep breaths.

The Center:

Receive what this moment offers--some people choose to kneel while others stand still for a moment. Others like to close their eyes or bow their heads.  

The Journey Out:

Review and reflect on your way out of the labyrinth. Keep taking those deep relaxing breaths.

Exit:

Carry the experience into your life and come back and visit the labyrinth again!
audioDescription:
(252 words)
The Waterfront Park: Labyrinth sits on the west end of the Georgetown Waterfront Park in Washington, DC, on the south side of Water street, NW at the intersection with 33rd street. A walkway leads across Water street at this location.
Three, three-foot wide cement planters stand between the street and a pedestrian walkway that runs east-to-west along the waterfront park, a six hundred fifty-yard (594 meters), one hundred twenty-foot (36 meters) wide stretch of grass lawn and gently rolling hills along the Potomac River. Trees and benches line the walkway and a twenty-foot wide garden area sits on the south side of the path.
Just beyond the walkway and set in the grass lawn, is a sixty-foot wide (18 meters) circular maze of one-foot-wide tan lines set over a green surface. Visitors are encouraged to follow the tan path from the south-side entrance and try to find its center as it winds, bends, and switches back and forth throughout the circle.
A one by two-foot white sign with brown lettering is set on a stake at the Labyrinth's north side. A brown border across the top reads in white lettering:
Rock Creek Park
National Park Service
U.S. Department of the Interior
Below in brown lettering is written:
Labyrinth
An Ancient Meditation Path
Walking a Labyrinth
Prepare Take a moment to relax and reflect
The Journey In Release concerns and quiet the mind
The Center Receive what this moment offers
The Journey Out Review and reflect
Exit Carry the experience into your life
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Waterfront Park: Stone marker, middle
listingDescription: The angled granite installation bears etchings of key bridge and recreational activities on the river.

images.altText: An angled stone marker with etchings by the water.
images.title: Georgetown Waterfront Park Stone Marker
images.caption: Georgetown Waterfront Park Stone Marker (Middle)

bodyText:
The Stone marker is a large shiny, black, rectangular granite slab, set on the ground and raised up about two feet from the back side.

A gray granite bench about one foot tall is incorporated into the left side and bends around the full backside of the piece allowing a space for visitors to sit and view the Potomac River.

The slab features three photographs that have been etched onto the granite surface. At the left side is a one by two-foot image of a bridge with water flowing out of its side in five places into the river below. Wavy horizontal lines are etched below the image. To the right is a four-foot tall etching of the corner of a bridge archway as it sits in the water. A shiny reflection of the bridge appears in the calm water below. On the right is a photograph representation of eight men facing the camera as they row in a crew shell on a river.

The area provides a pleasant view of the Key Bridge to the north and Theodore Roosevelt Island across the river to the south.
audioDescription:
(411 words)
Located along the north edge of the Potomac River at the west end of the Georgetown Waterfront Park in Washington, DC is the Waterfront Park: Stone marker.
From the 33rd street and Water street, NW intersection, travel south about one hundred-ninety-feet (57 meters) along a pedestrian pathway that leads through the grass lawn of Georgetown Waterfront Park. The Stone marker is set on the ground at the south side of a promenade and along a metal rail that angles out about ten feet towards the Potomac River and runs parallel with the river's edge.
T
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Waterfront Park: Stone marker, south
listingDescription: A set of two dark granite slabs that show life in Georgetown along the Potomac River

images.altText: A triangular stone sculpture with etchings.
images.title: Georgetown Waterfront Park Stone Marker
images.caption: Georgetown Waterfront Park Stone Marker (South)

bodyText:
Located along the north edge of the Potomac River at the east end of the Georgetown Waterfront Park in Washington, DC is the Waterfront Park: Stone marker.

The Stone marker consists of two shiny, black granite slabs, set on the ground and raised up about one foot from their back sides. The left slab is in the shape of a triangle. It features an etching in the left corner of a sailboat, approaching the viewer as it floats under a current of calm, etched wavy, horizontal lines. The center of the slab features an image of a Native American man standing at the front end of a canoe and rowing right to left down the river. Two people sit behind him and a fourth person stands and rows from the back of the canoe.

The right granite slab is also raised from the backside and has a rectangular shape. A gray granite slab bench runs ten feet along the right and fifteen feet along back side of the formation. A large etching is on the top half of the slab, about nine feet across. It features an image of old sail ships docked along the riverside in front of a row of buildings. A series of wavy line etchings separate this image from three smaller ones below, each about three by two inches. The faded left image appears to be a map of Washington, DC and the Potomac and Anacostia Rivers at its south end. The middle image is poorly faded, and only appears as light gray on the top half and darker gray below. The third image is also badly faded. Georgetown is visible written in the lower left corner, and a sketch of a two-story house in the lower right that is labeled Dumbarton House.
audioDescription:
(382 words)
Located along the north edge of the Potomac River at the east end of the Georgetown Waterfront Park in Washington, DC is the Waterfront Park: Stone marker.
From the Potomac street and Water street, NW intersection, travel south about one hundred fifty feet along a pedestrian pathway that leads through the grass lawn of Georgetown Waterfront Park. The Stone marker is set on the ground at the south side of a promenade and along a metal rail that runs parallel to the Potomac River.
The Stone marker consists of two shiny, black granite slabs, set on the ground and raised up about one foot from their back sides. The left slab is in the shape of a triangle. The front and left sides measure thirteen feet long, the right side is six feet. It features an etching in the left corner of a sailboat, approaching the viewer as it floats under a current of calm, etched wavy, horizontal lines. The center of the slab features an image of a Native American man standing at the front end of a canoe and rowing right to left down the river. Two people sit behind him and a fourth person stands and rows from the back of the canoe.
The right granite slab is also raised from the backside and has a rectangular shape of fifteen feet across the front, and eight feet on its left side. A gray granite slab bench runs ten feet along the right and fifteen feet along back side of the formation.
A large etching is on the top half of the slab, about nine feet across. It features an image of old sail ships docked along the riverside in front of a row of buildings. A series of wavy line etchings separate this image from three smaller ones below, each about three by two inches.
The faded left image appears to be a map of Washington, DC and the Potomac and Anacostia Rivers at its south end. The middle image is poorly faded, and only appears as light gray on the top half and darker gray below. The third image is also badly faded. Georgetown is visible written in the lower left corner, and a sketch of a two-story house in the lower right that is labeled Dumbarton House.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Waterfront Park: stone marker, north
listingDescription: The dark marble slab overlooks the Potomac and features etchings (some faded) of the industrial past along the waterfront.

images.altText: An angled stone marker with etchings by the water.
images.title: Georgetown Waterfront Park Stone Marker
images.caption: Georgetown Waterfront Park Stone Marker (North)

bodyText:
Located along the north edge of the Potomac River at the west end of the Georgetown Waterfront Park in Washington, DC. is the Waterfront Park: Stone marker.

The marker is a shiny, black slab of granite laid on the ground and risen at the back about two feet at its right back corner, and about six inches at its left corner. The Potomac River is directly on front of you and Theodore Roosevelt Island sits across the river. The Washington Monument and Kennedy Center are to the south.

The slab features etchings of images along its surface. Furthest left is a picture of a four-story brick building with PIONEER MILLS written below the fourth-floor windows. It sits along a riverbank and a canal boat can be seen floating by in the foreground. To the right is a very faded image that appears to show about ten men with horses standing along a riverbank under trees. Further right is another faded image. This one appears to show canal boats lined up end-to-end sitting in a canal way. Another image to the right is also badly faded. Buildings with smokestacks can be seen in the top right corner. One last image is on the far-right side but can barely be seen. A series of horizontal, wavy lines are etched beneath all four images across the bottom of the granite slab.
audioDescription:
(400 words)
Located along the north edge of the Potomac River at the west end of the Georgetown Waterfront Park in Washington, DC. is the Waterfront Park: Stone marker.
From the 34th street and Water street, NW intersection, travel south about one hundred thirty-five-feet (40 meters) along a pedestrian pathway that spans the western side of the Georgetown Waterfront Park. The path will turn left as it reaches the Potomac River. Proceed another two hundred twenty feet (67 meters) east and you will be at the Waterfront Park: Stone marker.
The marker is a shiny, black slab of granite laid on the ground and risen at the back about two feet at its right back corner, and about six inches at its left corner. Looking at the face of the slab you are facing southeast. The Potomac River is directly on front of you and Theodore Roosevelt Island sits across the river. The Washington Monument and Kennedy Center are to the south.
The slab sits in a shaded plaza overlook area that sticks out about thirty feet from a promenade that runs south along the river from this point. To the west about thirty feet is a patch of grass about thirty feet long with trees and benches.
The slab features etchings of images along its surface. Furthest left is a picture of a four-story brick building with PIONEER MILLS written below the fourth-floor windows. It sits along a riverbank and a canal boat can be seen floating by in the foreground.
To the right is a very faded image that appears to show about ten men with horses standing along a riverbank under trees.
Further right is another faded image. This one appears to show canal boats lined up end-to-end sitting in a canal way.
Another image to the right is also badly faded. Buildings with smokestacks can be seen in the top right corner.
One last image is on the far-right side but can barely be seen. A series of horizontal, wavy lines are etched beneath all four images across the bottom of the granite slab.
A gray granite bench about one-foot high is incorporated along the right side of the slab, and bends around the corner to span the entire back side, allowing for seating in front of the Potomac River. A metal railing lines the outer edge of the overlook area, about ten feet from the granite structure.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Whitehaven Park
listingDescription: Whitehaven Park is a small park that stretches from Dumbarton Oaks Park in the Georgetown Neighborhood of Washington, DC to the Glover Archbold Park in the Glover Park Neighborhood of Washington, DC.

images.altText: A grassy covered open space surrounded by trees. A bulletin board sits near a trail.
images.title: Whitehaven Park
images.caption: Whitehaven Park

bodyText:
Whitehaven Park is located in northwest Washington, DC and stretches between the Georgetown neighborhood of the city in to the Glover Park neighborhood. 

The western most side of the park joins up against Glover Archbold Park and a cross trail bisects the main Glover Archbold trail and can be traversed east all the way to Dumbarton Oaks Park.

There is limited street parking available along the edges of the park. This parking is restricted and is shared with area residents. Public Transit options are available.

title: Woodley Lane Bridge
listingDescription: Woodley Lane Bridge is an informational panel located near the site of the old bridge which was replaced by the Connecticut Avenue bridge.

images.altText: An information panel describes the former Woodley Lane Bridge at this location.
images.title: Woodley Lane Bridge
images.caption: Woodley Lane Bridge information panel.

bodyText:
Woodley Lane Bridge was constructed in 1888 and represented the latest style in light-weight bridges. Often referred to as the "High" bridge, it stood 54 feet above the creek, 450 feet long, 32 feet wide and was supported by two red sandstone abutments. In 1897, the bridge was dismantled while the new, larger Taft Bridge was being constructed. The span provided access to "Woodley," President Grover Cleveland's summer estate [which is] still standing today, located northwest of the bridge. The name "Woodley" is believed to have been derived from the large stand of immense oak and chestnut trees found upon the grounds.

The information panel sits near the US Park Police Edgewater Police Stable parking area and is accessible to the public. The bridge abutments might be visible in the winter and autumn when vegetation is sparse.
audioDescription:
(368 words)
The "Woodley Lane Bridge" wayside is located in the northwest quadrant of Washington, DC, off of Beach Drive NW.
From the Connecticut Avenue overpass of the William Howard Taft Bridge, travel north on Beach Drive and turn right into the parking lot after about one hundred feet (30 meters). Proceed into the lot over a seventy-five-foot (23 meters) bridge over Rock Creek. Continue into the parking lot about one hundred feet (30 meters) and the wayside will be on the right, set about ten feet off the parking lot in a grassy area.
The grass area is about sixty feet wide and forty feet long. Rock Creek runs right to left across the north end of the lawn. Trees and overgrowth line the side of the creek, and the arches of the Taft Bridge loom in the background about two hundred feet to the north.
The southeast end of the parking lot is home to the United States Park Police Horse Mounted Training Center, housed in a one-story tan and brown building about one hundred feet wide. Two picnic tables sit in front of the building.
The wayside is a two by three-foot light tan sign, titled at the top in black letters to read:
Woodley Lane Bridge
1888-1897
Below is a black and white image of a creek running from right to left. A bridge structure spans the valley at the right side and is titled: Calvert Street Bridge. On the left a lower road structure is labeled Woodley Lane Bridge. Text below reads:
View of Rock Creek Valley circa 1890-1895
Courtesy Columbia Historical Society
Text at the bottom of the sign reads:
Woodley Lane Bridge was constructed in 1888 and represented the latest style in light-weight bridges. Often referred to as the "High" bridge it stood 54 feet above the creek, 450 feet long, 32 feet wide and was supported by two red sandstone abutments. In 1897, the bridge was dismantled while the new larger Taft Bridge was being constructed. The span provided access to "Woodley," President Grover Cleveland's summer estate still standing today, located northwest of the bridge. The name "Woodley" is believed to have been derived from the large stand of immense oak and chestnut trees found upon the grounds.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Woodley Park Playground
listingDescription: Woodley Park Playground is located on Cortland Place NW near the Klingle Valley Trail.

images.altText: Playground equipment with platforms and a curling slide.
images.title: Woodley Park Playground
images.caption: Woodley Park Playground

bodyText:
Woodley Park playground is located off of Cortland Pl NW a short walk from the Klingle Valley Trail. 

Two slides, climbing features and a small sandbox are enclosed by a split rail fence. Just down the hill from the slides is a set of swings.

title: trailhead: cross trail #5 & Western Ridge Trail
listingDescription: Cross Trail #5 runs between the Western Ridge Trail and Milkhouse Ford and is part of the popular Milkhouse Ford Hike

images.altText: A dirt trail in a forest with yellow and green leaves.
images.title: Cross trail #5 & Western Ridge Trail
images.caption: Trailhead: Cross trail #5 & Western Ridge Trail

bodyText:
Cross Trail #5 runs in an east-west direction between the Western Ridge Trail and Milkhouse Ford. It runs along--or very close to--the historic roadbed that was Milkhouse Ford Road.

Cross trail #5 follows a gradual slope and parallels a small tributary of Rock Creek.
